editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: THE Compleat PLANTER AND CYDERIST.
CHAP. I. Of the Seminary and NurÅ¿ery.
div.p: Of preparing the ground for the Seminary.Â§. 1. AGainÅ¿t the Beginning of October carefully prepare Ground by Digging, Levelling, and CleanÅ¿ing it from GraÅ¿s, Stones, Weeds, and Roots, making the Mold very. Fine: chooÅ¿e not a wet or very Å¿tiff Clay Land, nor over-rich with Dung, but Å¿uch as being it Å¿elf good, you may make better only with a little mixture of very rotten Dung: Let it be fenced from the cold as well as you can, Å¿o that it be free from Å¿hade and droppings of Trees.

How to Å¿et Stones for Stocks.Â§. 2. When you Å¿et Stones, (which if they be Stones of Fruit Å¿oon ripe, you muÅ¿t
keep in Sand till October) do it by a Line, pricking holes about Å¿ix Inches diÅ¿tance one from another, and then put in the Stones about two Inches deep, with the Å¿harp end uppermoÅ¿t: When one Row is finiÅ¿hed, remove your Line a Foot farther, and Å¿et another Row in the Å¿ame manner; but let your third Row be about a Yard diÅ¿tant from the Å¿econd, that you may have liberty to go between every two Rows to Weed, &c. And Å¿et your Plum-Å¿tones and CherryÅ¿tones each apart by themÅ¿elves, and Å¿o proceed to Å¿et as many as you have a mind. PoÅ¿Å¿ibly Å¿ome of theÅ¿e Stones may not come up till the Å¿econd Spring after Å¿etting, and may not fruÅ¿trate your deÅ¿ire, if you then expect them. Some keep their Stones in Sand or Earth, in Tubs (well cover'd for fear of Mice) placed in a dry Cellar, in a HouÅ¿e, and then in February they Sow them (having prepared their ground) in Trenches, as PeaÅ¿e are Sown. The Stones of Apricocks and Peaches are apt to Å¿pring too forward, if Å¿et too Å¿oon, and be nipt by FroÅ¿ts. In like manner you may Å¿et Stones of Sloes, Haws, &c.

How to Å¿et Nuts, &c. Â§. 3. After the Å¿ame manner you are to Å¿et all kind of Nuts, Acorns, AÅ¿h-keys, or the Seeds or Kernels of any other kinds of Shrubs or Trees; but becauÅ¿e it's neceÅ¿Å¿ary that your young Wallnut-Trees and CheÅ¿nut-trees Å¿hould grow longer in your Seed-plot
than Stone-Fruit, before they will be fit to be removed to the place they are to Å¿pend their Lives in: you muÅ¿t Å¿et them at much farther diÅ¿tance, that they may have more room to grow big, without hurting one another.
How to Å¿ow Seeds.Â§. 4. To raiÅ¿e Stocks from Seeds, or Kernels of Apples, Pears, or Crabs, (each of which Å¿ort are to be Å¿owed by themÅ¿elves) you muÅ¿t go thus to work.

When either you or any Neighbour hath made Cyder, Verjuice or Perry, take the MuÅ¿t, Murc, (or as Å¿ome call it the Pouz) which is the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the fruit after the Juice is preÅ¿Å¿ed out, the Å¿ame day or the next day after, before it heats, and with a Riddle Å¿ift out the Seeds on a clean Floor, or Cloth, and theÅ¿e you muÅ¿t Å¿ow (as Å¿oon as you can conveniently) upon Beds of very fine Earth, very thick; for Å¿ome being bruiÅ¿ed in the grinding or pounding the fruit, and others not being ripe, may never come up; then Å¿ift Mold upon them, about two Fingers breadth in thickneÅ¿s. This way is much better than to Sow the Seeds with the MuÅ¿t, Murc, or Pouz together, (as Å¿ome do) becauÅ¿e the MuÅ¿t will heat them, and many of the Seeds will putrifie, and others will not be able to root or Å¿hoot up, becauÅ¿e they are Å¿o impriÅ¿on'd in that dry and tough Å¿tuff, clinging about them.
The Beds of Earth you Å¿ow them on may be made about two Foot in breadth, with a good diÅ¿tance between the Beds, that you may the better come to Weed them, and draw them up as you have occaÅ¿ion.
How to Å¿ecure them from prejudice.Â§. 5. To keep Fowls or Birds from Å¿craping them up, lay Å¿ome white Thorn on the Beds till the Ground be well Å¿etled.
Some cover the Beds with Fern or Straw, to keep them warm in the Winter, which may not do amiÅ¿s, but then it muÅ¿t be taken off at the Springs approach.
If Moles or Mice get in (which you may eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cover, becauÅ¿e the Mice leave Å¿hells of the Seeds on the top of the Beds) they muÅ¿t be deÅ¿troyed.
For Mice, lay PoiÅ¿on, or Oatmeal mixt with GlaÅ¿s pounded Å¿mall, and Butter, and caÅ¿t bits of it upon the Beds, or Å¿et Traps for Moles or Mice, better known than deÅ¿cribed.

The next Spring you will Å¿ee theÅ¿e Stones and Seeds come up plentifully; firÅ¿t the Leaves, almoÅ¿t of the Å¿hape of the Kernel Å¿plit in two, and from betwixt them will the Stem Put forth. Keep them clean from the Weeds all the year, which muÅ¿t be plucked up while they are young, leÅ¿t if they get Root, in drawing them up, you root up the Seedlings with them; but if in the Weeding any Seedlings come up, Å¿et them again almoÅ¿t to the top; then water them.

TheÅ¿e Weeds, and Å¿uch as are pluckt up any where elÅ¿e, thrown up into a heap, will rot, eÅ¿pecially if any Lime be Å¿catter'd amongÅ¿t them, and become very good Manure; but this Å¿hould be before they are Seeded, for then the Manure made of them will be apt to make the ground it is caÅ¿t upon more Å¿ubject to Weeds.
If a dry time happen, you may Å¿ome time in the Summer water the Beds.
The proper Seeds for Å¿tocks, and Å¿tocks for each kind of Fruit.Â§. 6. Your Seminary is to be Å¿tored with Stocks raiÅ¿ed of Stones and Seeds of theÅ¿e following, viz.
Peach-Å¿tones are to yeild Stocks for Peaches and Nectarines.

Stones of the Wheat-Plum (which is a Plum ripe in AuguÅ¿t, and is white) or of the white Pear-Plum, or of Å¿ome other good white Plum (in defect of them) whoÅ¿e Tree puts forth large Shoots, Branches,Stones of the white Pear-plum or Wheat-plum make the beÅ¿t Å¿tocks for Peaches, Nectarines and Apricocks to be inoculated on. and Leaves, or for want of them, Stones of the MuÅ¿tle-Plum, black Pear-Plum, Primordian, or any other black or red Plum, whoÅ¿e Tree is of free growth, and large leaved, will yeild you excellent Stocks for Peaches, Nectarines, Apricocks, and Plums; but Å¿tocks raiÅ¿ed from the Å¿tones of DamÅ¿ons are the worÅ¿t, and very bad, being dry Å¿tocks, and not Å¿o Å¿appy as the before-mentioned.
The Seeds of Pears yield the beÅ¿t Å¿tocks for Pear-trees.
Grafting Pear-Grafts or Cyens on a white Thorn or Quince Å¿tock, will make the Tree to be of Å¿mall growth, and the Fruit bad, having hard and Å¿tony Cores, if grafted upon a Thorn Tree.

Black Cherry Å¿tones and Red Cherry Å¿tones yield Å¿tocks to Graft or Inoculate Cherries on; but the Black Cherry Å¿tocks are beÅ¿t; for they yield goodly Å¿traight large Plants, and full of Sap, and become greater Trees than thoÅ¿e produced of Red Cherry Å¿tones, and conÅ¿equently more proper for Orchards and Fields.

To Inoculate an Apricock very low on a white Pear-Plum Å¿tock, or on a Wheat-Plum-Å¿tock, and then after a Years growth Inoculate a Peach or a Nectarine on it, is highly approved; only this way there will be two Years loÅ¿s of time: And note that the red Roman Nectarine will Å¿carce take on a Plum-Å¿tock any other way.

Stocks raiÅ¿ed of Crab kernels are better than thoÅ¿e raiÅ¿ed of Apple kernels.The Seeds or Kernels of Crabs and Apples yeild Å¿tocks the moÅ¿t proper to Graft any kind of Apple upon, and though the Å¿tocks raiÅ¿ed of Apple-Å¿eeds or Kernels do Å¿hoot more clear and Å¿mooth, and come forward faÅ¿ter, and are of a quicker and larger growth in Å¿tock than Å¿tocks raiÅ¿ed of Crab-kernels or Seeds, and Grafts grafted on them will grow quicker than on Crab-Å¿tocks, yet by the univerÅ¿al conÅ¿ent and experience of all, Å¿tocks raiÅ¿ed from the Seeds or Kernels of Crabs are preferred either for
Orchards or Fields, Cyder, Baking, or Table, far before Å¿tocks raiÅ¿ed of Seeds or Kernels of Apples, and that for theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons: Crab-Å¿tocks are more free from Canker, and more hardy, and Å¿o better able to endure cold and courÅ¿e Land, and becauÅ¿e they root better, and Å¿o will make large Trees, and will make Buds, BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and Fruit more hardy and Å¿trong to endure froÅ¿t and cold weather in the Spring: it alÅ¿o not onlp preÅ¿erves, but quickens, enlivens, makes brisk and poignant the GuÅ¿t of any delicate Apple.

But if you intend to propagate any delicate Apple which is over tart in taÅ¿te, Graft it on Å¿ome Å¿tock raiÅ¿ed of the Gennet Moyl, or Å¿ome Å¿weet Apple Tree, which will Å¿weeten its juice Å¿omething. So a Pear is improved by Grafting on a Quince-Å¿tock, but the Tree will not be large, but Å¿erve well for a Dwarf-Tree.

However where you cannot conveniently be Å¿tored with Crab-kernels, Apple-kernels are not Å¿o much inferiour to them, but they may well enough be made uÅ¿e of (as they commonly are) for raiÅ¿ing Å¿tocks to Graft Apples upon.

Objections againÅ¿t Crab Å¿tocks got out of Woods and Hedges to Graft Apples on.Do not furniÅ¿h your Å¿elf with Stocks for Apple-trees by getting young Crab-trees out of Hedges, rough grounds, and Woods, becauÅ¿e the Workmen in getting them break Å¿ome, and hurt others of the principal Roots; and it Å¿ometimes falls out that they
have been cut down, and Sprung up again, out of the remaining Å¿tump, or otherwiÅ¿e hurt, which though not eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cern'd, becauÅ¿e skin'd over, yet will be a prejudice to them for ever; alÅ¿o many of the Å¿tocks Å¿o got out of Woods and Hedges, have, for want of room, and by reaÅ¿on of Å¿hades and the dropping of other Trees about them, been checkt and baffl'd in their growth, and Å¿o become crooked, Å¿cabby, ill grown, rough, and unkindly, and never like to make good and thriving Trees. Some that furniÅ¿h themÅ¿elves this way with Å¿tocks, chooÅ¿e Å¿uch as are largeÅ¿t, and thoÅ¿e having for the moÅ¿t part, thick and hard Bark, and old Roots, which come on but Å¿lowly when they are removed to make Apple-Trees. LikewiÅ¿e if theÅ¿e Å¿tocks be not Grafted very low, (and if they are, a Years growth or two will be loÅ¿t) they will put forth Branches and Suckers of their own every Year, in Å¿uch abundance, that without conÅ¿tant pruning of them, the Grafts will be in danger of being Å¿tarved, and a better advantage may be made of Crab-trees in Hedg-rows and rough Grounds, by grafting them where they are, where they will thrive the better.

The only objection is, that a Man cannot be furniÅ¿hed with Trees of a good largeneÅ¿s, to bear Å¿o Å¿oon by Å¿tocks raiÅ¿ed by Kernels and Stones as thoÅ¿e got out of Woods, &c. or thoÅ¿e raiÅ¿ed by Suckers,
that may be of Å¿everal Years growth before uÅ¿ed.

To which it's anÅ¿wered and approved by daily experience, That if at the Å¿ame time that you get Crab-tree Å¿tocks (of Å¿ix or Å¿even Years growth) out of the Wood or Hedges, or Suckers, and Å¿et them in order to be grafted, you Å¿ow Kernels or Stones, the Stocks and Suckers you Å¿o graft for Å¿ix or eight years may continue larger and bigger than Trees that come of Kernels and Stones, but yet theÅ¿e leÅ¿Å¿er Trees Å¿hall Å¿o get ground of the other, that by the tenth or twelfth year they Å¿hall not only overtake them, but out-Å¿trip them in growth.

Stocks for Pears, Plums, and Cherries, of Å¿uckers, not good.And as to the way of raiÅ¿ing of Stocks for Pears, Plums, and Cherries, by Suckers, it's to be obÅ¿erved, that Trees Å¿o raiÅ¿ed will be ever apt to caÅ¿t up Å¿uch Suckers themÅ¿elves, and Å¿uch as do, are Å¿eldome found to be good bearing Trees, becauÅ¿e they expend their Sap Å¿o much that way.

NevertheleÅ¿s Suckers Å¿pringing out of the Roots of Pear-Trees, Plum-Trees, and Cherry-Trees, may be good Stocks for to graft Pears, Plums, and Cherry-Grafts on for Wall-Trees and Dwarf-Trees, becauÅ¿e they make Trees of Å¿mall growth.

And one Å¿hall very difficulty Å¿tore himÅ¿elf with Crab-Tree Stocks from the Wood and Hedges, and from Suckers, to Å¿uch a number as he may deÅ¿ire, becauÅ¿e many of them will prove bad and miÅ¿carry; whereas
as from Kernels, or Seeds and Stones, it's almoÅ¿t the Å¿ame labour to have thouÅ¿ands as hundreds, and Å¿uch as will almoÅ¿t all of them be fit and proper for uÅ¿e.

You may alÅ¿o raiÅ¿e Stocks to graft Apples and Pears on, by Å¿etting cuttings of the Gennet Moyl, and KentiÅ¿h Codlings, and the Quince-Tree for Pears, by Å¿etting thoÅ¿e in the place where the Trees of Apple and Pear are to grow, in Dwarfor Wall Trees: and alÅ¿o the ends of Roots, cut off from young Trees, taken up to be traÅ¿planted, and Å¿et in Beds of good Earth, will Å¿hoot forth tops, and become good Stocks, which may Å¿erve for Dwarf Trees and Wall Trees.

Or you may Inoculate Buds on the Å¿mall Roots of great Trees that grow at fartheÅ¿t diÅ¿tance from the Bodies, and after a years growth to cut off the Root about a Foot in length, with the new Å¿hoot growing upon it, and tranÅ¿plant it; becauÅ¿e a Tree will be raiÅ¿ed thus Å¿ooner than from 2 Seed or Stone.
In caÅ¿e of an exigent for a Å¿tock or two, this way may be practiÅ¿ed, but it will be found too troubleÅ¿ome for a general uÅ¿e.

Suckers Å¿pringing from the Root of the Wheat Plum-tree, or white Pear-Plum-tree, make excellent Å¿tocks for Peaches, Nectarines, Apricocks, and Plums; but to have plenty of Å¿tocks for large Å¿tandards for Orchards or Fields, there is no better way of
raiÅ¿ing them, than by ripe Kernels or Seeds of Crabs, or for want of them, of Apples, (the ripeneÅ¿s of the Seed or Kernel is known by its being black) and of Pears for Pear-Å¿tocks, and of Cherry-Å¿tones for Cherry-Å¿tocks, and of Peach-Å¿tones for Peach-Å¿tocks, to Inoculate Peaches and Nectarines on, and of Wheat-Plum and white Pear-Plum-Å¿tones to graft or Inoculate Peaches, Nectarines, Apricocks, and Plums on; with which a Man may eaÅ¿ily provide himÅ¿elf.

Of removing and tranÅ¿planting Seedlings or Seed plants from the Seminary into the NurÅ¿ery.Â§. 7. In the later end of October, or beginning of November, after one Summers growth in the Seed-plot, you ought, and muÅ¿t in no wiÅ¿e neglect to draw up with your hand Å¿uch of your Crab, Apple, or Pear-Seedlings, as you find grown a Foot or more in height, but thoÅ¿e which are not grown a Foot in height you may let remain in your Seed-Plot another year; and as for thoÅ¿e proceeding from Stones, they need not be removed, but grafted or inoculated in the Seminary, the Å¿tones being Å¿et at Å¿ix Inches diÅ¿tance, as afore is Å¿aid; but very many will in October remove thoÅ¿e coming of Å¿tones as well as of Seeds or Kernels, and like it beÅ¿t; becauÅ¿e Å¿uch as grow two or three years upon the Seed-bed before removing, thruÅ¿t their Roots very deep in the Earth, and are not only very hard to be drawn up, but their Roots, when Å¿et again, (though a great part be cut off) muÅ¿t of
neceÅ¿Å¿ity be thruÅ¿t down very deep into the Earth; and then Å¿uch Å¿pread their Roots deep and below the good Soil, by thruÅ¿ting their young Roots from the loweÅ¿t part where the Root was cut off, and Å¿o they neither have Å¿o good NouriÅ¿hment from the Earth, (as Å¿preading below the beÅ¿t Soil) nor are they Å¿o eaÅ¿ily tranÅ¿planted when ready, as thoÅ¿e drawn the firÅ¿t year, and are Å¿et very Å¿mall.

How to order the Seedlings after drawn up.Â§. 8. When the Seed-plants or Seedlings are drawn up, cut off the Å¿ide-Å¿prigs from about the top, and the Å¿trings from about the Roots, and Å¿nip off the ends or extremities both of the top, that it may not run too faÅ¿t upwards, but the Body may grow in bigneÅ¿s, and of the Tap or Heart-Root, that it may not run directly downwards, (leÅ¿t it run farther than the good Soil) but may be more apt to Å¿pread its Roots in breadth, and near the top of the Ground, where the beÅ¿t Soil is.

Then have Beds prepared of good fertil dry Earth, not over-rich, leÅ¿t upon removal afterward into a much worÅ¿e Soil, (as for the moÅ¿t part Orchard and Field-ground is) your Trees coming of a Å¿udden from Å¿uch delicate Food to Å¿uch courÅ¿e Fare, pine away, if they do not periÅ¿h. And this is rationally thought to be the cauÅ¿e why many Trees bought out of London-NurÅ¿eries (which are vaÅ¿tly deep with fat
and rich Manure) decay, or come on very poorly when they are brought into the Country.

Therefore upon every removal or tranÅ¿planting, either of Seed-plants, or young Trees, endeavour to have Earth as good, or better (to place next the Roots at leaÅ¿t) than that out of which they were taken.

If any of theÅ¿e Å¿pring upright, top them early, (that is, cut off about an Inch long at a Bud at the uppermoÅ¿t end of the Seed-plant, that the cut may be covered with a freÅ¿h Å¿prig) and it will make them grow bigger Bodied, and Å¿pread at the cut place, and Å¿o become Å¿ooner ready for GraÅ¿ting. And let not the Roots be too long; about a handful in length (or leÅ¿s) is Å¿ufficient; for if the Roots be long, and Å¿et deep, the Trees afterwards are taken up with more difficulty, and worÅ¿e Roots. And the reaÅ¿on why all Seed-plants ought to be tranÅ¿planted or removed after one Summers growth on the Seed-bed, is, becauÅ¿e they get good Roots, which of themÅ¿elves thruÅ¿t down one Å¿ingle Root for the moÅ¿t part, and that into the bad Soil. But if you would have Å¿tocks an Ell or more high, to Graft or Inoculate for Standerds, you muÅ¿t not top them, or cut off their Tops; becauÅ¿e topping them makes them to Å¿pread at the cut place, and their growing up to ceaÅ¿e.

If you would Plant and Orchard, and have excellent Å¿ound Trees, early, and great bearers,
and the Trees free from Cankering, remove your Seed-plants into the places, and in the order you intend your Apple or Pear-Trees to grow, and let the Seed-plants or Stocks grow there two years, and then graft them, and order them as you do Trees that are Å¿et in Orchards, and by this means there will need no removal after Grafting, and you'l be quit of the many miÅ¿chiefs that attend TranÅ¿planting, and have better bearing, freer growing, and Å¿ounder Trees than any you can tranÅ¿plant out of the NurÅ¿ery into the Orchard, only you muÅ¿t carefully preÅ¿erve them from Cattel, Hares, and Conies, both before and after Grafting, until they have attain'd a Å¿ufficient height and bigneÅ¿s.

Of Å¿etting the Seedlings, Å¿tocks, or Å¿eed plants.Â§. 9 Let every Bed you make for Å¿etting theÅ¿e Plants or Stocks in, be about two Foot broad, leaving room betwixt each Bed to walk and work about them, without prejudicing the Plants or Stocks; Å¿et two rows a Foot or more diÅ¿tant from each other on every Bed, by drawing a Line and pricking holes a full Foot a Å¿under; let the holes be Å¿o deep that if the Roots be not very long, you may Å¿et your plants or Å¿tocks about two fingers breadth deeper in the ground than they grew in the Seed-Plot; cloÅ¿e the Mold about them, and if it be a very dry time, water them the very Å¿ame
day, the better to Å¿ettle the Earth about them.

If you can get old Fern, (in Å¿ome places call'd Brakes or Brackin) or for want of it, Straw or new Dung, cover the Beds with it, which will keep the Roots warm in the Winter, and preÅ¿erve them from overmuch heat in the Summer; if the Land be any whit Å¿tiff, this cover will make it mellow, and when rotten enrich it, and very much hinder the growth of Weeds, which ought duly to be pluckt up; and put new Fern, &c. as the old rots: and be Å¿ure you draw the biggeÅ¿t of the Å¿tocks firÅ¿t, and Å¿et them by themÅ¿elves, and the leaÅ¿t by themÅ¿elves, and Å¿et Å¿tocks of Crab-kernels by themÅ¿elves, and of Apple-kernels by themÅ¿elves, and Å¿tocks raiÅ¿ed of Plum-Å¿tones, Cherry-Å¿tones, Peach-Å¿tones, each diÅ¿tinctly by themÅ¿elves in Å¿traight rows.

If you intend to raiÅ¿e any Å¿tocks to be Å¿et out in Fields before they are grafted, you muÅ¿t not top them upon their firÅ¿t removal, neither need you remove them before they are grown high enough to Å¿tand in the Fields; if you find that they Å¿pread their Roots, and run not downwards, as in gravelly, and Å¿uch kind of Soils they will not be apt to do, (and by the firÅ¿t you draw up you may judge of the reÅ¿t, whether they do or no) if you reÅ¿erve any for this uÅ¿e, you had beÅ¿t chooÅ¿e Å¿uch as grow Å¿traight, and at convenient diÅ¿tance one
from another, which you may contrive to do in drawing out the firÅ¿t two years Å¿uch as be of Å¿tature to be tranÅ¿planted from among them; dreÅ¿s theÅ¿e once or twice a year, by cutting off the biggeÅ¿t Å¿ide-branches, to haÅ¿ten their growing tall, but leave on the top, and Å¿ome Å¿mall Å¿ide-branches, for this cauÅ¿eth them to thrive in bigneÅ¿s the more, which they ought to do proportionable to their height, or elÅ¿e they will be too weak to bear a top.
ObÅ¿erve this alÅ¿o in your Grafted Trees in your NurÅ¿eries or elÅ¿ewhere.

Grafts muÅ¿t not be grafted on different kinds.Â§. 10. All Stocks and Cyens or Grafts that proÅ¿per when they are joynted together, are congenerous, or of the Å¿ame kind, and nearly related in Å¿ome degree; therefore Cherry-Grafts, or Cyens, Grafted or Inoculated on Plum-Å¿tocks, will not proÅ¿per long, nor Plum-grafts on Cherry-Å¿tocks, neither do Apple-grafts on Pear-Å¿tocks, nor pear-grafts on Apple or Crab-Å¿tocks. Neither will an Apple Cyens grow grafted upon a Sallow, Poplar, Alder, Elm, or HorÅ¿e-plum.

Apple-Å¿eeds, &c. will not produce the Å¿ame kind of Apple, &c. they were had out of.Seeds or Stones of Fruits gathered from Trees that have been grafted, or inoculated on Å¿tocks of different kinds from the Graft or Cyens, produce of themÅ¿elves (not being grafted or inoculated) not the Å¿ame Fruit as that was from whence the Seed or
Stone came, but a different and moÅ¿t commonly a far worÅ¿e Fruit; and as concerning the Seeds of Apples, it's to be obÅ¿erved, That although they produce not Trees bearing the Å¿ame kind of Apples as thoÅ¿e the Seeds were had of, yet without grafting they will bring forth a good harÅ¿h Fruit that may yield good Cyder; and thus it's Å¿aid we came by Å¿ome of our beÅ¿t Cyder-Apples. Neither are Å¿ome Å¿orts of Crabs Å¿o contemptible a Fruit as they are generally accounted; for being gathered very ripe, and kept a good while to mellow, Å¿ome of them will make good Cyder, or ground with other mellow Fruit, do much enrich the Cyder, and are the beÅ¿t refiners of foul Cyder; and generally Crabs yield a Å¿trong Liquor, Å¿o that Å¿uch kind of CrabÅ¿tocks may rather help to mend Å¿ome Apples of weak Juice, than make them worÅ¿e. And this inconvenience is always found in Trees coming of Seed, and not grafted or inoculated, That they are very long before they bear Fruit, whereas Å¿tocks grafted or inoculated from Trees, which experience aÅ¿Å¿ures are of good bearing kinds, and Fruits, commonly bear well in three or four years, and Å¿o continue. If you would have Å¿ome Trees raiÅ¿ed of the Seeds of Apple-kernel, view your Seminary about Michaelmas, and Å¿ee which of your Seedlings have produced the broadeÅ¿t, faireÅ¿t; and largeÅ¿t Leaf and Shoot, and thoÅ¿e elect for your Trees to be
Å¿et without Grafting, for it's commonly obÅ¿erved that thoÅ¿e Seed-plants or Trees that have very large, fair, and broad Leaves, bear the faireÅ¿t and largeÅ¿t Fruit.

Meer grafting betters not Fruit.Â§. 12. Mere Grafting doth not meliorate the Fruit at all; as if you graft a Cyen upon the Å¿ame Tree you took it from, the Fruit will be the very Å¿ame, without the leaÅ¿t alteration from what the Tree bore before it was Å¿o grafted; but Fruit may Å¿omething participate of the nature of the Stock wherein it's grafted, Å¿o as to be made by it either better or worÅ¿e; as if you graft a very Å¿our Apple Cyen upon a Å¿weet Apple Tree, the Fruit will be Å¿omething better: So a Å¿weet Apple Cyen, grafted on a very harÅ¿h four Crab-Å¿tock, hath produced a better Fruit than the Tree from whence the Apple-graft was had. So a Pear-Cyen, grafted on a Quince-Å¿tock, hath mended the Pear; and though the Graft doth keep its own Nature, and mightily predominate on what Stock Å¿oever it's grafted, yet Å¿uch an union as that of the Stock and the Graft, in natural Bodies, is hardly conceivable without Å¿ome commixture of their Natures, and there are Å¿ome reaÅ¿ons from experience which make this more than probable, as

I. The Seeds of a grafted Tree take much after the Å¿tock, and it's Å¿omething Å¿trange to conceive the Kernel Å¿hould participate
Å¿o much of the Å¿tock and the Fruit be nothing influenced by it.

II. ThoÅ¿e that produce the beÅ¿t Fruit by their Å¿tones or Å¿eeds, yet vary from the Fruit the Å¿eed or Å¿tones were taken out of, which in all likelihood proceeds from the mixture of the quality of the Å¿tock and Cyen in that Tree the Å¿tone came from.

III. It's manifeÅ¿t that amongÅ¿t Trees of one kind, in the Å¿ame Orchard, you Å¿hall have Å¿ome one of them bear better Fruit than any of the reÅ¿t Å¿ometimes; and it's not known what to impute this excellency more probably to, than that the Stocks they were grafted on might be Crab-trees that bore Crabs of Å¿everal kinds, Å¿ome better, Å¿ome worÅ¿e.

So that to conclude, it cannot be amiÅ¿s to be Å¿o far curious about the Stocks you graft, as rather to chooÅ¿e Å¿uch Seeds and Stones to raiÅ¿e them from, as come from Trees that bear the beÅ¿t Fruit in their kind (if you can have them) than to take them at adventure, which makes Å¿ome chooÅ¿e Seeds out of fair, large, juicy Crabs, to raiÅ¿e Å¿tocks to graft Å¿ome delicate Apple-grafts on.

Concerning the Pith of a Tree.Â§. 13. It's held by Å¿ome, That the Kernel of the Fruit hath a great dependance upon, and Sympathy with the Pith of the Tree, and that hollow Trees, though they grow and bear Fruit, yet that Fruit hath few Kernels in it, and thoÅ¿e little better than withered Husks; and experience evidences that there are Å¿ome hollow Fruit-trees that bear Fruit Å¿o much more excellent than any of the Å¿ame kind the Owners have had, or could elÅ¿ewhere meet with, that they have been very deÅ¿irous to propagate from them, but never could, any manner of way, raiÅ¿e young ones of thoÅ¿e old Trees, that would bear Å¿o good a Fruit as the old Trees: which Å¿eems to intimate, That the Fruit of a Tree may be the better for the Piths being conÅ¿um'd; and if that be true, as it muÅ¿t be Å¿o, becauÅ¿e the Pith conveys to the Fruit a worÅ¿e Å¿ort of Juice than any other part of the Tree doth; and therefore being freed from that infection by the conÅ¿umption of the Pith, the Fruit becomes more choice and delicate: and that the Pith is the conveyance of a courÅ¿er or other Å¿ort of juice, is rendred in Å¿ome Å¿ort probable, becauÅ¿e (as hath been before obÅ¿erved) the Kernels of Fruit depend much upon the Pith, which almoÅ¿t never produce Å¿uch good Fruit as the Å¿eeds or Å¿tones come out of, but generally much worÅ¿e.

ReaÅ¿ons why every one ought to Graft, Plant, and raiÅ¿e his own Trees.Â§. 14. BecauÅ¿e moÅ¿t men are through ignorance indifferent whether they have Fruit-trees of their own or no, becauÅ¿e for a little money they can have Plants from others, ready brought up to their hands; yet it's far better to have them of their own bringing up and Propagation, and to have Seminaries and NurÅ¿eries of their own for this purpoÅ¿e, for theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons,

I. BecauÅ¿e this way a Man Å¿hall be Å¿ure to meet with no failure, either in the kind, great bearing, or goodneÅ¿s of the Trees and Fruit; in all which he Å¿hall frequently be diÅ¿appointed and loÅ¿e much time and expence, if he have his Trees upon the reputation and truÅ¿t of others, who make a Trade of Å¿elling them, and are therefore many times incurious, careleÅ¿s, and perhaps knaviÅ¿h in raiÅ¿ing them, and in Å¿tead of the right kinds, (if they can get either eaÅ¿e or any thing by it) will not Å¿tick to put him off with another.
II. This trouble and expence of buying young Plants, and getting them home, (many times from places very remote) and the prejudice they often receive in the carriage, will be wholly prevented.

III. This way a man Å¿hall, with almoÅ¿t the Å¿ame labour and charge, both furniÅ¿h himÅ¿elf Å¿ufficiently, and have Å¿o many more as to defray the Charge he may be at about it, if he will Å¿ell them, or to gratifie his friends, if he had rather beÅ¿tow them.

IV. He will this way be provided with Å¿tocks for Apples, Pears, Plums, Cherries, and all choice Wall-Fruit, raiÅ¿ed from Kernels and Å¿tones of Fruit, which are incomparably better than Å¿tocks procured any other way.

And laÅ¿tly thoÅ¿e that propagate Trees for Sale have their NurÅ¿eries exceeding fat, rich, and fertil, whereby Trees removed out of them into the Orchard, &c. of others, which are always almoÅ¿t of a far courÅ¿er and worÅ¿e Soil, frequently prin, pine away, and very often dye; and if they live, they Å¿eldome prove fair, large, or well bearing Trees; and it often happens, that the Air and Soil into which they are removed, is heterogeneous and unÅ¿uitable for Trees coming out of the Air and NurÅ¿ery you have them: For it's a Å¿ure Rule, always to tranÅ¿plant or remove Trees or Stocks from a worÅ¿e to a better Soil upon every removal, and then they will proÅ¿per well. So Trees removed out of the South into the North Å¿eldom proÅ¿per, whereas Trees removed out of the North into the rich Southern Soils, like well: So Trees brought up in NurÅ¿eries in LancaÅ¿hire, and tranÅ¿planted into Ireland, thrive and bear exceeding well.

About the Bark of Trees on Barren ground.Â§. 15. Stocks or Trees that grow on barren ground, have commonly their Bark very white and hard, whereas thoÅ¿e on good Land have their Bark very Å¿mooth, green,
and plump, and the laÅ¿t years Å¿hoots large and full; but the others Å¿hoots are Å¿hort, Å¿mall, and meagar.

How to raiÅ¿e a Fence of Crab-treesÂ§. 16. If one have a mind to raiÅ¿e a good new Fence about a Field he deÅ¿igns to incloÅ¿e, which he can keep for four or five years together, to bear Corn, or Clover-graÅ¿s to Mow, that Cattel may be Å¿o long kept out of it, he may do it rarely well, by Å¿owing Apple-Kernels of as many Å¿orts as he will on the top of a new-made Ditch-bank, making the dead Hedge (that is uÅ¿ually on the top of the Bank) on the utÅ¿ide of the Ditch, to defend them.

When they are grown up, he may plaiÅ¿h this Hedge, leaving at every four or five yards diÅ¿tance one of the beÅ¿t Trees to grow up, which of themÅ¿elves will bear good Cyder-Fruit, (which he may gueÅ¿s at by the broadneÅ¿s and largeneÅ¿s of the Leaves they bring forth) or may be grafted to bear what pleaÅ¿eth the owner: and by this means in a little time, and with Å¿mall charge, he Å¿hall have a fruit-bearing and impregnable hedge.

Remove out of the Seminary all Stocks, whether raiÅ¿ed of Seed or Å¿tones.Â§. 17. Let all Stocks whatever, that are removed, grow a year or two before you graft them; and notwithÅ¿tanding Å¿ome opinions to the contrary, no Å¿ort of young Plants or Stocks, that come of Seed or Stones, ought to be grafted or inoculated in the place where they were Å¿owed, before that they
have been removed; becauÅ¿e if they be not removed, they thruÅ¿t down a Å¿ingle Root or two commonly into Clay, Gravel, or moiÅ¿t ground, &c. which Root or Roots draw bad nouriÅ¿hment from below the good Soil, which always is neareÅ¿t the top of the ground, and thereby hurts Trees, Roots, and Fruits, and in caÅ¿e any of them be there grafted, and removed afterwards, they want good Roots, and are difficult to remove, becauÅ¿e not removed when young, of one or two Summers growth.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Ways, Manner, and Time of Grafting.
div.p: The time to Graft in.Â§. 1. FRom the middle of January until the beginning of March, if the Weather be open, without FroÅ¿t, and grow warm, the wind not being North or North-EaÅ¿t, you may graft Plums, Cherries, and Pears, but not Apples, till the Bark of the Stocks will a little riÅ¿e or peel from the wood, which is Å¿eldom before the middle of March, and often not till April, becauÅ¿e this is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the beÅ¿t way of grafting them; but if you will graft any Apples in the Cleft, you may do it from the beginning of March until the tenth of April, and that with Å¿ucceÅ¿s; but grafting in the Cleft early in the beginning of March, is beÅ¿t, eÅ¿pecially, if the weather be mild and open: and Graft not within Å¿ixteen hours before or after the Change or full of the Moon.

The grafting InÅ¿truments.Â§. 2. Your InÅ¿truments to graft with are to be a fine, neat, Å¿harp, Å¿mall, well-Å¿et Saw, to cut off the heads of Å¿ome Å¿tocks which
are grown too big for the Knife; a good Å¿trong Pruning-Knife, made a very little coming, which will be ready to cut off the heads of your Å¿maller Å¿tocks you intend to graft: alÅ¿o a good midling Knife to cleave Å¿ome of the Å¿maller Å¿ort of Å¿tocks with; alÅ¿o an InÅ¿trument like a broad ChiÅ¿el, the handle of Iron, and the edge alike on both Å¿ides, not Å¿loping on one Å¿ide, like that of Joyners, but plain as a Knife, and very thin, about three or four Inches in breadth; with which you may either cleave your larger Å¿tocks, or prune your Trees; alÅ¿o a little Mallet, or elÅ¿e a Å¿tick about a Foot long, made of an old Spade or Shovels handle, or Å¿ome other hard wood, to uÅ¿e inÅ¿tead of a Mallet, to drive your Knife when you cleave the Å¿tock: AlÅ¿o an Iron Tool about Å¿ix Inches in length, made turning at each end about an Inch and an half; if it be Å¿teeled at either end, it will be the better, and not Å¿o apt to bend when you open a Å¿trong Å¿tock: theÅ¿e ends are to be made flat, a little like a ChiÅ¿el, but not above half an Inch broad at moÅ¿t, only pretty Å¿trong; if yon will, one end may be pretty Å¿mall for the Å¿maller Å¿tocks, and the other bigger; the uÅ¿e of it is to Å¿upply the place of a Wedge, by holding open your Stock till you have Å¿et your Graft or Cyen exactly in its place in the Cleft of the Stock.
This repreÅ¿ents the Form thereof.
InÅ¿tead of this InÅ¿trument you may uÅ¿e a Wedge of hard wood, about a Foot long, eÅ¿pecially for great and large Å¿tocks.

You are alÅ¿o to have a Å¿harp Pen-knife, to Å¿hape your Grafts or Cyens with, and alÅ¿o a Whet-Å¿tone to quicken the edge of your Knives when dull, and a Basket to carry your Tools in, and another to carry your Grafts or Cyens in: AlÅ¿o you are to have Ruches, BaÅ¿tes, or Å¿oft Flags, to bind Grafts or Buds to the Stock. You may be furniÅ¿hed therewith at the Mat makers.

The manner of preparing clay: and how to clay grafts.AlÅ¿o you muÅ¿t have Clay prepared with HorÅ¿e-dung very well mixed and workt together as Mortar, about two parts Clay: If it be not well temper'd and wrought together, it will be apt to fall from your Graft, in caÅ¿e of much wet, or chop, or cleave if dry weather happen, and Å¿o you'l loÅ¿e your labour in Grafting; for you muÅ¿t Clay your Grafts cloÅ¿e on every Å¿ide an Inch above the top of the Stock, and an Inch below the bottom of the Clefts, that no Air
get in to wither the Graft; and keep Clay on the grafted part until the Å¿tock be covered over with the Graft. For Clay is as a Salve to a Wound, which heals it up, and it rather keeps out moiÅ¿ture than otherwiÅ¿e, if well cloÅ¿ed; and alÅ¿o preÅ¿erves from dry winds, Sun, and other annoyances: Therefore keep on the Clay a year or two, till the head of the Å¿tock be cover'd with the Graft, and the cleft healed up.

Choice of Grafts or Cyens.Â§. 3. TheÅ¿e Cyens or Grafts you get ought to be the laÅ¿t years Shoots, Å¿trong and very well grown, that grow on the top or out-Å¿ide of a Tree, that Å¿everal years experience of thoÅ¿e that know it, can faithfully aÅ¿Å¿ure you bears very well, and good fruit of its kind; and cut not off the tops of the Cyens until that you graft them, for Å¿o they will keep better; but immediately after grafting, the tops of Grafts are to be cut at a Bud, that they may Å¿pread the better, and of Å¿uch as are but Å¿hort, if there be BloÅ¿Å¿om-buds on the top, as it's commonly Å¿een in Pearmain-Cyens, and many other good bearing kinds. Grafts that are very Å¿mall and Å¿lender commonly fail, therefore chooÅ¿e the faireÅ¿t, fulleÅ¿t, and Å¿trongeÅ¿t Å¿hoot of the laÅ¿t years growth, and fulleÅ¿t of Buds, and of good bearing kinds, elÅ¿e you may have fair Trees, and little or no Fruit on them, and Å¿o fancy you have an Orchard, though Å¿eldom Fruit; for Å¿ome Trees will
grow and bloÅ¿Å¿om very well, yet rarely bear Fruits; the reaÅ¿on is, for that they were grafted from bad bearing Trees, and are of bad bearing kinds.

A Å¿hoot or Branch of the year next foregoing makes the beÅ¿t Cyens or Graft, and thrives beÅ¿t, though in HerefordÅ¿hire, when they graft old Trees, they commend and uÅ¿e Cyens of two or three years growth, yet thoÅ¿e are Å¿eldom found to have convenient Buds to put forth at, and often times have bloÅ¿Å¿oming Buds on them, and make not Å¿o good a growth, neither have they Å¿o good a joint to graft at as thoÅ¿e of the laÅ¿t year.

When you get Grafts, you had beÅ¿t cut off at leaÅ¿t three Inches of that which grew the year before with them, beÅ¿ides the laÅ¿t years Shoot, for Å¿o they will keep the better, and you may uÅ¿e about an Inch and an half of that old Wood in every Cyens when you Graft it.

Perhaps you may not have Å¿everal Å¿orts of Plums, Cherries, or Pears Å¿o near you, as that you may get Buds freÅ¿h enough for Inoculation: In this caÅ¿e you may procure Cyens, and graft them, and they will continue freÅ¿h, though you Å¿hould Å¿end for them from beyond Sea.

TheÅ¿e Cyens or Grafts of any kind may be grafted immediately after they are gotten, and that Å¿ucceÅ¿sfully; or they may be kept three Weeks or a Month before they are uÅ¿ed, and there ought to be a Fortnight
or three Weeks betwixt the time of their being cut, and their being grafted, that the Stocks in that time may be repleniÅ¿hed with Sap, and the Cyens more empty of it; and then they will quicker incorporate by more greedily attracting the Sap out of the Stock.

To keep your Cyens or Grafts after they are cut, you need not, as Å¿ome direct, bury them in moiÅ¿t Mold; for this may be a means to make them Å¿well and bud forth by receiving moiÅ¿ture from the Earth; and then when by grafting they are expoÅ¿ed to the cold open Air, they will be in danger to wither and die before they have nouriÅ¿hment from the Stock. You may lay them in a dry houÅ¿e, Å¿o it be near no heat, or under the Å¿hade of an old Tree or Hedge, and cover them all over with dry Mold, that the Air may not have too much Influence upon them: though they Å¿eem Å¿omewhat dry, yet if they cut with a freÅ¿h colour, and be not much withered, they will not grow the worÅ¿e, but rather the better; yea Å¿ome that have Å¿eemed withered, being carried 70 or 80 Miles, have grown well. And they may be carried hundreds of Miles in a Box of Mold, or their ends Å¿tuck in Clay, or a Turnip, and wrapped about with green freÅ¿h MoÅ¿s, that they bruiÅ¿e not; bind not many together; for if Å¿o, thoÅ¿e in the middle will dry, and be Å¿poiled in certain days, but rather lay them thin in the Mold.
Be very careful that the Buds be neither hurt or rub'd in the binding or carriage of the Å¿aid Grafts.

In providing Cyens or Grafts of Pears, Plums, and Cherries, you muÅ¿t cut them in the beginning of February, having reÅ¿pect to the forwardneÅ¿s or backwardneÅ¿s of the Spring, and the warmth or coldneÅ¿s of the Country you live in; but you muÅ¿t be Å¿ure to cut them before the Buds have any Å¿peck of white appear on them.
Cyens or Grafts for Apple-Trees will Å¿eldom be too forward any time before the beginning of March.
Grafts of Cherry and Plum-Trees muÅ¿t be grafted Å¿ooneÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e they bud earlieÅ¿t, and you are to begin with them ere they bud forth, then with Pear-trees, and laÅ¿tly with Apple-trees.
Elect the faireÅ¿t and largeÅ¿t Grafts on the top Branches of a Tree, and of the laÅ¿t years growth, and on the Sun-Å¿ide of the Tree, which will bear Å¿ooner than thoÅ¿e got on Å¿ide-branches.

Of joints and height of graftingÂ§. 4. There be Å¿ome indifferent whether they graft at a joint or no, but forecaÅ¿t to have a Bud directly behind the Å¿houlder of the Cyen; if Cyens with joints were Å¿carce, you might practice Å¿o on Å¿mall Stocks, that will Å¿peedily be cover'd, but if Cyens can be had with joints, never graft with others, for theÅ¿e will cover the Stocks Å¿ooner. However
this is the opinion of many, yet I always grafted at one of the loweÅ¿t Buds on the thicker end of the laÅ¿t years Shoot or Sprout, and valued not a joint of the former years growth, unleÅ¿s the Graft were too Å¿hort; for the Å¿traiter and Å¿moother your Graft is, the more exactly you may fit it to your Stock, eÅ¿pecially if your Stock be young, and have but a thin Sap, and this was very Å¿ucceÅ¿sful; however grafting at a joint may do well if the Stock have a thick Sap or Bark, as commonly your Wood-Å¿tocks and all large Trees have. The wood below the knot or Å¿eam is commonly crooked, and not Å¿o Å¿mooth and Å¿traight as the wood below a Bud on the thicker end of the laÅ¿t years Shoot; therefore rather graft at a Bud, becauÅ¿e you may joyn the Graft and Stock the more exactly.

Height to graft at.Â§. 5. If you Graft Apple or Pear-Cyens, graft a Foot or leÅ¿s from the ground; do the like for Wall-trees and Dwarf-trees, but if you graft Cherry or Plum-Cyens, for Å¿tandards in Orchards or Fields, graft them Å¿ix or Å¿even Foot high, and at that height let them begin to Å¿pread; and when you graft, cut the top of the Cyen or Graft off cloÅ¿e above a Bud, about four or five Inches above the Shoulder, if it be for a Standard-tree, two Buds above the Clay being full enough; but for Dwarfs or Wall-trees, you may let the Cyens or Grafts be Å¿ix Inches or more
long, with Å¿everal Buds, that they may Å¿hoot forth many Branches and Å¿pread from the very Stock. If you Graft old Apple, or Pear-trees, or their Branches, you muÅ¿t Graft according to the thickneÅ¿s of their Branches, which is uÅ¿ually Å¿even or eight Foot high or more. It will do well in Grafting Stocks for large Å¿tandards, to put but one Cyens or Graft into a Stock (unleÅ¿s the Stock be very large, or an old Tree you Graft) and if it put forth Å¿everal Shoots, to cut off all but one, that is the Å¿traighteÅ¿t and Å¿trongeÅ¿t: But for Dwarffs and Wallfruit, put in two Cyens if the Stock be big enough; let the later be Grafted near the ground, the former at Å¿uch height you think fit, and the Stock will allow.

The Å¿ize of Å¿tocks to be Grafted.Â§ 6. If the Plants that you removed out of the Seed-plot into the NurÅ¿ery, and Å¿uch Stocks for Stone-Fruit in the Seed-plot as you intend to Graft, be half an Inch over in thickneÅ¿s where they are to be Grafted, or little more, its enough; Its beÅ¿t not to have them above an Inch in the Diameter, both that you may loÅ¿e no time, and that the Stock may be eaÅ¿ier cover'd by the Cyen or Graft. In the cleft you may Graft any Stock, that is a little above half an Inch, to three Inches Diameter at the place to be Grafted at; but one Inch Diameter of the Stock at the Grafted place is the beÅ¿t,

How to mark Trees to know and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h their kinds.Â§ 7. In Grafting or Inoculating its neceÅ¿Å¿ary to have Å¿ome mark, to know what kind of Fruit is put upon each Stock: If you Graft many of one kind, (as it's neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Cyder-Fruit) you may obÅ¿erve to make every row to conÅ¿iÅ¿t but of one kind, and it's but entring in a Book, that Å¿uch a row hath Å¿uch a kind of Fruit in it, and no other; but where there are Å¿everal in one row, there may be a Stake knockt into the ground, at the beginning of every new Å¿ort, and Å¿o entred in your Book; and where you have very few of a kind (or for the whole NurÅ¿ery if you pleaÅ¿e) you may make marks of Å¿everal figures or Å¿hapes in the Bark of the Stocks, which marks enter in your Book, and what kind it denotes, and at two or three years when you remove it, the mark will be very viÅ¿ible, and by renewing the marks Å¿ometimes, you may continue it as long as you pleaÅ¿e; and if any Tree be Å¿tolen, you may own it by the mark, which is made with the point of a Pen-knife by cutting almoÅ¿t through the Bark of the Stock, the form of a Letter or any other figure or character whereby to know the kinds of Fruits.

Buds on the Stock at Grafting not to be pull'd off untill the Gr â¢ ft put forth.Â§ 8. Buds upon the Stocks that are engrafted, Å¿hould be let alone, all or moÅ¿t of them, untill the Grafts have put forth Buds of their own, and be able to draw up the Sap out of the Stock, and then rub off all the
Buds on the Stock, below the Grafts, that they may have all the Sap.

Â§ 9. Stocks that are white, when you Graft them will Å¿eldom make the Graft to grow well and proÅ¿per; the whiteneÅ¿s being cauÅ¿ed through the barrenneÅ¿s of the Soil, and obÅ¿erve what length the Stock did Å¿hoot out Sprouts the fore-going year, and commonly Å¿o long will the Graft Å¿hoot out, or more, if it take well.

div.head: CHAP. III. How to Graft Å¿everal ways.
div.p: Â§. 1. THere are Å¿everal ways of Grafting and all good, if JudiciouÅ¿ly and dexterouÅ¿ly performed: To which end, I Å¿hall endeavour to Å¿et down the moÅ¿t plain and exact deÅ¿cription of each way, for the better and truer information of the young Planter, and firÅ¿t begin with that call'd Å¿licing, or Packing on, which being deÅ¿cribed at large, may Å¿erve as a General direction for all.

Grafting call'd Slicing, or Packing on.Â§. 1. Cut off the top of Stock, in Å¿ome Å¿mooth and Å¿traight place, that may be AnÅ¿werable to the Å¿traightneÅ¿s of the Graft, when Å¿et on. If you do it with a Hand-Å¿aw, cut it Å¿mooth afterwards with a Knife, leaving the top flat and even.

Then prepare your Cyen or Graft, (firÅ¿t obÅ¿erving which Å¿ide is Å¿traighteÅ¿t at the bottom or thicker end, that Å¿o it may fit the Å¿traight part of the Stock when Å¿et on) by cutting the Graft or Cyen on one Å¿ide only, from the Joint, Knot, or Seam, if the
part below it be Å¿mooth and Å¿traight; (the Knot or Seam is a Circle round about the Graft, dividing and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing the laÅ¿t Summers growth from the former) or from Å¿ome one Bud on the lower part of the laÅ¿t years Shoot, or Sprout, down Å¿lopewiÅ¿e in the Wood till it be cut quite off, in that the Å¿lope may be about an Inch long or Å¿omthing more, obÅ¿erving it's bent, that when the Graft or Cyen is fixed to the Stock, it may Å¿tand almoÅ¿t upright; and cut the Graft or Cyen thin at the bottom of cut place, yet leave on all the Bark on the oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ide; then give a cut croÅ¿s through the Bark at the top of the Slope, and then cut a thin Chip of that Slope upward to the croÅ¿s cut, that there may be a Å¿houlder to reÅ¿t on the top of the Stock, but cut not this Å¿houlder too deep, little more than through the Bark will be enough, and this will cauÅ¿e a little riÅ¿ing in the Sloped part, which you muÅ¿t cut down, that the whole Slope may be plain and Å¿mooth, without dints or riÅ¿ings, and lie even and cloÅ¿e to the Å¿ide of the Stock. Cut then the top of the Cyen off, cloÅ¿e above a Bud, about four Inches above the Å¿houlder if it be for a Standard-tree, two Buds above the Clay being full enough; but for Dwarf, or Wall-trees, you may let the Cyen or Graft be Å¿ix Inches long with Å¿everal Buds, that they may Å¿hoot forth many Branches, and Å¿pread from the very Stock.

The Cyen or Graft thus prepared, lay the cut part of the Cyen or Graft upon the Å¿traight Å¿ide of the Stock, and if it may be, on the WeÅ¿t, or South-weÅ¿t Å¿ide of the Stock, and Å¿o meaÅ¿ure and mark the juÅ¿t length and breadth of; it then cut away Å¿o much of the Bark of the Stock, as the cut part of the Cyen or Graft may fit, drawing your Knife upwards; but as the Stock is bigger, and the Bark thicker than that on the Cyen, or Graft, Å¿o the Chip muÅ¿t be longer and broader, or els the paÅ¿Å¿age of the Sap in the Stock and Cyen or Graft (which is chieÅ¿ly betwixt the Bark and the wood) will not meet together, which Å¿hould and muÅ¿t be aimed at, as in the work you will eaÅ¿ily Å¿ee.

Then lay the cut part of the Cyen or Graft on the cut part of the Stock, and let the Å¿houlder of the Graft or Cyen reÅ¿t directly upon the top of the Stock, Å¿o that the cut parts of both may joyn even and Å¿mooth all along, and Å¿o bind them together cloÅ¿e, with courÅ¿e woollen Yarn, BaÅ¿Å¿es, or the inward peeling of the Witch-tree, if you bind with Å¿uch materials as will not be looÅ¿e or rotten by MidÅ¿ummer; about that time give the binding a cut croÅ¿s-wiÅ¿e with a Knife to Å¿et the priÅ¿oners at liberty: Have in readineÅ¿s Å¿ome Clay free from Å¿tones, well mixt with HorÅ¿e-dung, &c. (Vide Chap. 2. Sect. 2.) and daub it about the Stock and Cyen, an Inch above the head of the Stock,
and an Inch below the bottom of the Cyen or Graft; work it up round the Cyen or Graft till it be Å¿harp at the top, that the Rainwater may fall better off it; and with a Knife or rather a little Trowel dipt in water, Å¿mooth over the Clay, but in doing this, be very careful not to diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e the Cyen or Graft.
Thus you may Graft Pears, Plums, Cherries, and Apples, if it be before the Bark of the Stock will part from the wood of them, for when it will, the next way following is better for Aples.

Grafting in the Back or Rind.Â§. 2. The Å¿econd way call'd Grafting in the Bark is much like this, and Å¿ome prefer it before the beformentioned, or any other way; but it can only be uÅ¿ed for Apples, becauÅ¿e all Cyens of other Fruit, will be grown paÅ¿t uÅ¿e, before the Bark of the Stock will peel, which is about the end of March or beginning of April, but this will be time enough for Apples if your Stocks be in any thing good liking, which if they be not, they are not fit to be Grafted any way: Prepare then your Stock and Cyen or Graft, exactly as your were directed in Packing, only inÅ¿tead of cutting the Bark of the Stock, Å¿lit it on the South-weÅ¿t Å¿ide, from the top, almoÅ¿t as long as the Å¿loped part of the Cyen, and looÅ¿en the Bark at the top of the Å¿lit with the point of your Knife.

Have in readineÅ¿s a little InÅ¿trument made of Ivory, or of a Deer or Sheep-Å¿hanck or Silver, or of Å¿ome hard Å¿mooth wood; at one end let it be made of the Å¿hape of the Å¿lope part of the Cyen, but much leÅ¿s every way; thruÅ¿t it down betwixt the Bark and wood of the Stock where it was Å¿lit, to make room for the Cyen or Graft,Some peel off the outmoÅ¿t thin, brown rind of the Graft, on the oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ide to the cut and Å¿lope part of the Graft, that muÅ¿t enter between the Bark of the Stock and wood, but leave on all the inner green rind, and then thruÅ¿t the Graftdown between the wood and Bark of the Stock which does very well. then take it out and put in the Cyen, but firÅ¿t cut a little of the Bark at the thin end of the Å¿lope of the Cyen or Graft, that it double not in going down, yet leave it with a Å¿harpe edge; and becauÅ¿e when your Cyen is put in, it will bear the Bark hollow from the Stock, nick or Å¿lit the Bark, on each Å¿ide the Cyen, Å¿o that it may fall cloÅ¿e to the Stock, and to the edges of the Cyen; bind and Clay it as before.

This way of Grafting is commended by Å¿ome, as Mr. Langford, tho others diÅ¿approve thereof; yet I have Grafted large Stocks often this way, and very Å¿ucceÅ¿sfully, but with Å¿mall Stocks I Å¿eldom had the deÅ¿ired SucceÅ¿s, tho as careful in the operation as poÅ¿Å¿ible; but the firÅ¿t way I take to be the beÅ¿t for them, for theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons.

I. BecauÅ¿e Stocks may be Grafted Å¿o, Å¿ome years before they can be ready to Graft in the Cleft, and though Whip-grafting may be uÅ¿ed Å¿ooner than that way, yet there are other great inconveniences attending it.

II. The Stocks this way are leÅ¿s harmed than where a Cleft is uÅ¿ed, becauÅ¿e the Cleft lets wet into them, and rots and makes them not Å¿o fit for Grafting again, (if any fail to grow the firÅ¿t time) as theÅ¿e continue to be, though they Å¿hould once miÅ¿carry.
III. The Cyen will much Å¿ooner cover the Stock and make a more Å¿ound, healthful and Å¿wifter growing Tree.

IV. This is more Å¿peedy, eaÅ¿y, and Å¿ure to Å¿ucceed. Therefore if the Stock exceed three Inches Diameter at the place it's cut off, the beÅ¿t way is to Graft in the Rind or Bark, and you may Å¿et many Grafts round the Stock, and they will Å¿ooner cover the Stock; but if the Stock be from one Inch to three Inches Diameter, then Graft in the Cleft; if under one Inch Diameter, then by Å¿licing, Packing on, or Whip-grafting.

Grafting in the Rind is attended with Å¿ome inconvenience; for the Grafts uÅ¿ually make large Shoots the firÅ¿t Year, which in caÅ¿e the Wind happen to blow Å¿trongly on the oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ide of the Stock where the Graft is, commonly it is broken off, having as yet no other hold than in the Bark or Rind, and being top heavy with all, is eaÅ¿ily broken: but after one Year the danger is paÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e that which grows Å¿o plentifully at the joyning of the Graft and Stock the firÅ¿t Year being but Å¿appy Rind, the next Year is converted into Å¿olid Wood.
Some well approve by their experience the Grafting Stocks above three Inches Diameter, by placing two Grafts oppoÅ¿ite to each other in the Cleft, and other two oppoÅ¿ite to each other in the Bark, Å¿o that you may place four Grafts in Å¿uch a large Stock, and they will Å¿oon cover the Stocks head.

Â§. 3. There is another way of Grafting Å¿mall Stocks call'd Whip-grafting;Whip-grafting. and here your Graft or Cyen, and Stock ought to be exactly of the Å¿ame bigneÅ¿s as the manner of performing it plainly Å¿hews, viz. Slope off the Cyen or Graft a full Inch or longer, and do the like to the Stock, and tye the one upon the other; both the Stock and Cyen ought to be cut at the Å¿mootheÅ¿t and Å¿traighteÅ¿t place. You may if you will make a Shoulder on the Cyen, and cut the top of the Stock to Å¿uit with it, and then bind them together, and Clay them about the place. If you joyn the Inner Bark of the Cyen and Stock exactly together at either Å¿ide, it will grow, tho not Å¿o well as where the Cyen and Stock are of an equal proportion.

This way call'd Whip-grafting, is Å¿ucceÅ¿sful enough, Å¿o that Å¿pecial care be taken that both Stock and Cyen Å¿uit exactly where they are joyned together, which is Å¿omewhat troubleÅ¿ome to do; and Å¿o is it to find Cyens and Stocks of an equal bigneÅ¿s; beÅ¿ides the head will be apt to overgrow the Stocks; all that can be done to prevent it,
is to Graft theÅ¿e very low; or if high to give the Stock more liberty to thicken by Å¿litting the Bark of it with a Knife almoÅ¿t to the wood.

In this way of Grafting there is another little Knack may be added to very good purpoÅ¿e, and that is, when the Stock and Cyen are prepared (as you heard before) to be joined together, to make a Å¿lit, or Notch with a Knife in the bare place of the Stock downward, beginning towards the top of the Å¿lope, and Å¿o Å¿litting or Notching it a little way, and doing the like in the Å¿loped face of the Cyen, but beginning at the Å¿ame diÅ¿tance from the lower end of it, as you did before from the top of the Stock, and Å¿o carrying it upwards, and then joyn them by thruÅ¿ting the one Å¿lice into the other, till the bare place of the Cyen cover the bare place of the Stock.
This may be done likwiÅ¿e in Grafting by Packing, and in both conduceth much to Å¿trengthen the work, and is called by Å¿ome Lipping, or Tounging.
In Whip-grafting the cut parts both of the Graft and Stock, muÅ¿t joyn and anÅ¿wer one another from the top to the bottom.

This way of Whip-grafting is commended by Å¿ome, not only for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on as Å¿litting or Packing on is, but alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e the Graft Å¿oon covers the Stock, which is not impaired by Å¿litting or cleaving, and
the Graft having it's Wood, as well as it's Rind bound to the Stock, is not Å¿o apt to break off, as that which is Grafted only in the Rind, nor is the Graft apt to be top heavy, the Stocks being Å¿maller afford not Å¿o plentiful NouriÅ¿hment.

Grafting in the Cleft or Å¿lit.Â§. 4. The next way of Grafting is call'd Grafting in the Cleft, which is the moÅ¿t Antient and common way of Grafting, and if carefully managed, not inferior to any other way of Grafting, tho the modern Planters do Å¿omthing Å¿light it: You may Graft any Stock this way, from half an Inch to three Inches Diameter, and that if the Stock be no bigger than the Graft too, if you have neat Tools, and be ready in the managery thereof, and with good Å¿ucceÅ¿s, as I have frequently experienced. The manner is thus, viz.

Cut off the top of the Stock in Å¿ome Å¿mooth and Å¿triaght place, that may be anÅ¿waerble to the Å¿traightneÅ¿s of the Graft that is put into the Cleft; if you do it with a Hand-Å¿aw, cut it Å¿mooth afterwards with a Knife, leaving the top flat and even.

Then cleave the Stock with a Å¿trong Knife, (or the ChiÅ¿el before deÅ¿cribed at Sect. 2. in Chap. 2.) Let the Å¿lit run about two Inches deep, and let it be as near the middle of the Stock as you can, but not in the Pith or heart, and let the Å¿lit be on the
Å¿omotheÅ¿t Å¿ides of the Stock. Have in readineÅ¿s the Steel IinÅ¿trument before mentioned at Chap. 2. Sect. 2, or els a Stick of hard Wood near a foot long, at one end made like a Wedge; when you have taken out the Cleaver, put one end of the InÅ¿trument, or els the Wedge into the Å¿lit or cleft of the Stock, and open it Å¿o wide as to put in the Cyen, when it is prepared, and made ready for that purpoÅ¿e.

Which is by cutting the Graft or Cyen from the joynt, knot, or Å¿eam, if it be Å¿traight, or els from Å¿ome Bad on the thicker end of the laÅ¿t years Shoot or Sprout down aÅ¿lope on both Sides,The Å¿lope cut off the Graft Å¿hould be an Inch and half long at leaÅ¿t, if the Stock be big enough to allow it. Å¿omthing more than an Inch long, making it thin at the bottom, and in Å¿hape like a Wedge, very Å¿mooth and even without dints or riÅ¿ings, that it may joyn cloÅ¿e all along; Å¿o far as it goes into the Cleft of the Stock, let the outÅ¿ide of the Graft or Cyen be Å¿omewhat thicker than the inner Å¿ide, unleÅ¿s the Stock be Å¿o big as to pinch the Cyen or Graft much, then make the Cyen or Graft as thick on that Å¿ide that goes into the Stock as on the outÅ¿ide, which will prevent the Stocks hurting the Sappy part, and Bark of the Cyen or Graft, by preÅ¿erving the outÅ¿ide from being pinched too much.

You may let the Graft or Cyen have on the uppermoÅ¿t part of the Å¿lope, a Å¿houlder on one Å¿ide, or both, or neither; all theÅ¿e ways are uÅ¿ed, but Å¿houldering takes up more
time, and makes the Cyen or Graft weaker, and Å¿o apter by chance to be broke off; then with your Å¿harp Pen-knife cut away any Jags, or roughneÅ¿s, or blackneÅ¿s that remains after cleaving, on each Å¿ide of the Cleft of the Stock within, and Å¿o put in either one, or two Cyens or Grafts; if the Stock be large, place them Å¿o as the paÅ¿Å¿age of the Sap betwixt the Bark and Wood both of the Stock, and Cyen or Graft may meet and joyn all along the Cleft as near as you can; for you muÅ¿t be Å¿ure always to joyn the inner Å¿ide of the Bark of the Cyen or Graft to the inner Å¿ide of the Bark of the Stock all along the Cleft, that the Sap may come out of the Stock to feed the Graft and make it grow.

The Graft being thus placed in the Stock draw forth the InÅ¿trument, or Wedge, and Clay them cloÅ¿e on every Å¿ide, and an Inch above the top of the Stock, and an Inch below the bottom of the Cleft, and keep Clay on about the Grafted part untill the Stock be covered with the Graft, and it will be the Å¿ounder Tree.

If you put but one Graft or Cyen in (which is beÅ¿t unleÅ¿s the Stock be large,) then cut off a piece with a Å¿lope cut from the top of the Stock about an Inch and half deep on the worÅ¿t Å¿ide of the Stock, the Graft being to be put on the Å¿traighteÅ¿t and Å¿mootheÅ¿t Å¿ide, in cutting the Stock thus, the Graft will cover over the Å¿ooner.

Many cleave big Stocks croÅ¿Å¿wiÅ¿e again, and put in two more Cyens; but cleaving hurts the Stocks Å¿o much that it's better (if you will have more than two Cyens in one Stock) Graft the other two in the Bark, according to the Å¿econd way of Grafting, but forecaÅ¿ting one of them to be on the WeÅ¿t Å¿ide of the Stock; But two Grafts are enough for any Stock.

It's an Erronious practiÅ¿e to Å¿et the outÅ¿ide of the Stock and Graft even and Å¿mooth; becauÅ¿e the Bark of a big Stock is much thicker than the Bark of a Å¿lender Graft, and conÅ¿equently if the outÅ¿ide be Å¿mooth and even, the inÅ¿ide muÅ¿t needs be uneven, but where the Graft and Stock are almoÅ¿t of an equal proportion, there you may Å¿et them Å¿mooth on the outÅ¿ide, but where the Stock is large, Å¿et the cut part of the Graft more inward into the Cleft of the Stock.

When you cut Grafts it's very convenient to leave a Bud or two on the outÅ¿ide of the cut place, that in caÅ¿e any of the Grafts happen to be broken off, Å¿uch Bud or Buds on the outÅ¿ide, will Å¿pring out, and Å¿upply the defect, altho the Graft be broken off, even to the top of the Stock; or you may leave the Bud juÅ¿t at the Å¿houlder where the Graft joyns to the top of the Stock, and it will anÅ¿wer the Å¿aid intentions.

The only objection that is raiÅ¿ed againÅ¿t Grafting in the Cleft, is, that the Stock being Å¿lit or cloven, the Rain is apt to get in and decay the Stock, and Å¿ometimes the Graft too, therefore caution muÅ¿t be uÅ¿ed, not only the firÅ¿t year, but untill the head of the Stock be covered with the Graft, to keep well tempered Clay on the Grafted part both, of Cyen and Stock, and that as far as the Cleft extends it Å¿elf, to keep out both Wet and Air.

I have Grafted this way Stocks from half an Inch to above three Inches Diameter, and that very Å¿uccesfully, obÅ¿erving the aforeÅ¿aid rules, but a Stock of about an Inch Diameter is the beÅ¿t to uÅ¿e in this way of Grafting, which I like as well as any other, notwithÅ¿tanding the opinion of all modern Planters is to the contrary.

There is one Å¿mall obÅ¿ervation neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be noted in Cleft-Grafting, and of no little concernment to make Grafts thrive well, which is to cut the Graft Å¿o as to be Å¿et as deep into the Stock as poÅ¿Å¿ible, Å¿o as the Stock be not clove too far, which is by making the cut part of the Graft to be an Inch and half long, or longer if the Stock be large, and thereby the Graft will attract more Sap, and make a larger Graft by much, than one cut but Å¿hort from the Knot, Seam, or Bud. Therefore for that end make the cut part of the Graft an Inch and half long at leaÅ¿t.

Side grafting.Â§. 5. Side-Grafting is done by preparing the Cyen or Graft as in Whip-grafting, then without cutting off the head of the Stock, (but making it thin of Å¿ide-Branches) from a Å¿mooth Place of it on the WeÅ¿t Å¿ide, take off as much Bark as the Cyen will cover, as in Packing, and Å¿lit both Cyen and Stock accordingly as is directed in the third Sect. and fix them together accordingly; bind it cloÅ¿e, and Clay it.
If it grow at a years end cut off the top of the Stock at the Grafted Place Å¿lopewiÅ¿e, and Clay it.
Some done thus grow well, but Å¿uffer not the top of the Stock much to overgrow the Cyen the firÅ¿t year before it's cut quite off.

Some uÅ¿e another way, that is, to Å¿lit the Bark of the Stock in the form of a great T, and looÅ¿ning it with the point of a Knife, and then clapping in a Cyen, prepared as hath been Å¿aid before, (but without the Å¿lit for Lipping) bind and Clay it; this can be only uÅ¿ed when the Bark will part from the Stock.

Grefting by Approach.Â§. 6. There is another way call'd Grafting by Approach, Ablactation, or Enarching, which is by having a Stock or Stocks grow Å¿o near another Tree, whoÅ¿e Fruit you would propagate, that the Stock and the Branch of that Tree may be joyned together in the manner following.

Cut the Å¿ide of the Branch, and of the Stock (where they will meet) about three Inches in length, till you come near the Pith of each, and fit them both together, that the paÅ¿Å¿age of the Sap may joyn, and the green inner Å¿ide of the Bark of the Stock and Tree; in which poÅ¿ture bind and Clay them: AÅ¿Å¿oon as you find the Cyen and Stock to be well cemented together, cut off the head of the Stock about four Inches above the binding, and in March following, cut off the Stub you left of the Stock, and alÅ¿o the Cyen underneath, cloÅ¿e to the Grafted place, that it may Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t by the Stock only.
It is alÅ¿o uÅ¿ed to be done by cutting off the head of the Stock at firÅ¿t, and Å¿lopeing half off about two Inches long, and joyning the Cyen thereunto, being cut accordingly.

This manner of Grafting is unneceÅ¿Å¿ary, and Å¿carÅ¿ly practicable in common Fruit-trees, but for Oranges, Lemons, Pomgranats, Vines, JeÅ¿Å¿amines and Å¿uch like Shrubs, it may be uÅ¿ed. AlÅ¿o it's Å¿aid that
Trees of different kinds will Å¿ooner take this way than any other.

Â§. 7. I once Å¿aw a man Graft half a dozen Å¿mall Stocks thus; After he had cut off the top of the Stock, he cut it on each Å¿ide from the top a Å¿lope about an Inch and half, directly like a Wedg reverÅ¿t, then he clove with his Pen-knife the Graft from the bottom in the middle of the Graft an Inch and half, then he plac'd this Graft on the S â¢ ock, one Å¿ide of the Graft on one Å¿ide of the Stock, and the other on the other, but joyn'd Sap to Sap, and then bound and Clayd it; theÅ¿e Grafts took well, and it's an eaÅ¿y way of Grafting.

Â§. 8. Some have an Iron InÅ¿trument made for the purpoÅ¿e, which will make a Nick or Notch in the Stock up to it's head, an Inch and half long through the Bark, and Å¿ome depth into the Wood, in form of an v, or rather after this form, V, then fit the Graft, and put it into the Noch, joying Sap to Sap, and bind them together with BaÅ¿s, and Clay them. This way is much commended.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Inoculating.
div.p: Â§. 1. INoculating is the taking off a Bud from one Tree, and putting it between the Bark and the Wood of another Tree or Stock; the end and intention is the Å¿ame with other ways of Grafting; and moreover by this way, divers Å¿orts of Fruits, which are not apt to take or grow by ordinary ways of Grafting, are by this eaÅ¿ily encreaÅ¿ed.

The manner of Inoculating.Â§. 2. About a fortnight before or after MidÅ¿ummer (which is the beÅ¿t time, though it may be done from the beginning of May untill AuguÅ¿t) when you have pitcht upon Å¿uch Stocks as are fit to be Inoculated, to get the Bud from, chooÅ¿e out a Å¿trong and well liking Branch, or Shoot of that years growth, upon a Tree that bears exceeding well, and Å¿uch kind of Fruits as you would by this operation produce, and about the mid le, or lower end of it, (for the top will be too tender) fix upon a leaf that hath a freÅ¿h and fair Bud growing out betwixt
it and the Bark, and about half an Inch below and above the Bud, cut off the Branch, and Å¿o you will have a piece of it about an Inch long remaining, with a Bud and Leaf on, this you muÅ¿t cleave juÅ¿t through the midÅ¿t, Å¿o as the Bud may be directly in the middle of the one half; and then Å¿nip off a part of the Leaf; and holding it by the remainder, clap it to a Å¿mooth Straight place on the Stock, and with a Pen-knife Å¿core out, on each Å¿ide of it, Å¿o much of the Stock as it covers, or rather a little broader, (becauÅ¿e when the Bark on which the Bud is, is taken off from it's own Wood, and applyed to the Stock, it will cover a wider Å¿pace of the Stock than it did before) After you have thus marked your Stock, with-draw the Cyen again, and cut the Bark through where you had marked it; then cut the Bark croÅ¿s and Å¿traight from the uppermoÅ¿t end of one Å¿core to the upper end of the other, and cut the Bark again croÅ¿s and Å¿traight from one Å¿core to the other, but not Å¿o low as the Lower ends of the Å¿cores, by a quarter of an Inch; then take the oblong Å¿quare piece of Bark, that is cut on every Å¿ide, quite off the Stock, and raiÅ¿e up that part of the Bark that remains betwixt the Å¿ide-Å¿cores at the bottom of the work, from the Wood, till you come to the lower end of the Å¿ide-Å¿cores.

Take then a GooÅ¿e-quill, cut in the faÅ¿hion of an Apple-Å¿coop, or Å¿craper, and having with your Nail a little looÅ¿ned the upper part of that Bark that is on the Cyen, thruÅ¿t the Quill betwixt the Bark and the Wood, that it may Å¿eparate them, and take off with the Bark a little Wood or Root of the Bud over againÅ¿t it: If you Å¿ee a hole on the inÅ¿ide over againÅ¿t the Bud, when you have taken the Bark off, caÅ¿t it away, that little labour is loÅ¿t, and try another till you find it otherwiÅ¿e.

Then put in the lower end of that Bark or Cyen betwixt the Bark that was raiÅ¿ed on the Stock and the Wood, and Å¿o bind it on the Stock gently with Woollen-yarn, or narrow Shreds of Linnen Cloth, or gentle Stuff, or with BaÅ¿Å¿es, or BaÅ¿t, of which the RuÅ¿Å¿ia Matts are made, but Å¿o that the Cyen may Lye cloÅ¿e to the Wood of the Stock that was made bare, and have an eÅ¿pecial care that you hurt not the Bud.
Â§. 3. There are Å¿ome other ways of Inoculating uÅ¿ed, differing only in the manner of the cut, both in the Bark of the Stock, and of the Cyen.
And firÅ¿t, Å¿ome proceeding in all other things, as is before directed, cut the Bark out of the whole length of the Å¿ide-Å¿cores, and apply the Cyen to the disbarked place.

Â§. 4. Others cut one Å¿lit only down the Bark of the Stock, and another croÅ¿s the the top of it, like a great T, when this is done, they prepare the Cyen or Bark as before directed (only cutting it Å¿harp pointed at the lower end before they take the Bud off it's Wood) Then raiÅ¿e the Bark of the Stock up on each Å¿ide the Å¿lit, and put in the Cyen, beginning at the top and Å¿liding it downward gently, and let the top of the Bud joyn cloÅ¿e to the croÅ¿s-cut in the upper end, and Å¿o bind the Bark gently upon it, but not juÅ¿t upon the Bud: This is the common way uÅ¿ed by Gardiners.

Â§. 5. Others make the croÅ¿s-cut in the middle of the downright Å¿core on the Stock, and lifting up the four corners of the Bark, and making the Cyen Å¿harp at both ends, put it under the Bark of the Stock at both ends, and then bind it; but in doing this, there is danger of hurting the Bud or Cyen.
Â§. 6. Mr. Rea commends the making the croÅ¿s-cut at the lower end of the downright cut, and having opened the Å¿ides, put in the Cyen upwards, being made Å¿harp at the upper end only.
You muÅ¿t be nimble and quick in Inoculating, and preparing the Bud, els the Air by Å¿udden drying the Bud or Cyen and the cut part of the Stock will much be hurt.
Thus much to Å¿atisfy the curioÅ¿ity of Å¿uch as have a mind to make tryal of every way, but the firÅ¿t is eÅ¿teemed beÅ¿t.

NeceÅ¿Å¿ary rules and obÅ¿ervations on Inoculaing.Â§. 7. LeÅ¿t one Bud fail, or any miÅ¿chance break it, put two in every Stock, but not directly under one another on the Å¿ame Å¿ide of the Stock. The Branch or Shoot, you cut one Cyen off may yield you Å¿everal.
Â§. 8. About a Month after the Inoculating, or Å¿ooner if you perceive the Bark Å¿well where the binding is, cut off the binding.

If it grow it will fix to the Stock, keep it's colour, and that part of the Leaf and Stalk that was left, will drop off, and the Bud appear fair; Then Å¿ometime before the next Spring, cut off the top of the Stock a hands breath above the place it was Inoculated at, and all the Å¿ide-branches that grow any where upon the Stock; and at Spring the Bud will put forth; and if any other Sprouts or Buds appear on the Stock, cut them off.

Â§. 9. If the firÅ¿t Inoculation fail, or the Buds dye, the Stocks may be Inoculated again the next Summer, and of Å¿uch as are Inoculated timely in the year, it may be Å¿ometimes Å¿een whether they grow or not,
time enough to Inoculate them again the Å¿ame year.
Â§. 10. Apricocks will have Buds ready Å¿ooner than other Fruit, Å¿o that you may begin with them and follow with the other.

Â§. 11. Stocks raiÅ¿ed of Peach-Å¿tones are commonly big enough to be Inoculated the Å¿econd Summer, Å¿ometimes the FirÅ¿t after they are Å¿et: when they or any other stocks are an Inch and half in compaÅ¿s, or thereabouts, they are big enough to be Inoculated.

Â§. 12. ThoÅ¿e you intend for Wall or Dwarf-trees, are to be Inoculated within a handfull of the ground, and not Pruned at all, till you remove them, and then you will better Å¿ee whats neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be cut off; and theÅ¿e you may remove after one years growth, or two, with more Å¿afety.

If you Inoculate any Plums, Pears, Cherries, or other Fruit, that you intend for an Orchard, or other place for tall Standards, you may do it higher on the Stocks, viz. Å¿ix or Å¿even foot high, and Prune theÅ¿e up in the NurÅ¿ery, and let them grow there, two or three years (according as
they grow in hight) before they be removed.

Â§. 13. After Stocks that are Inoculated have made one or two years growth, you muÅ¿t cut off the head of the Stock, that remain'd above the Bud: At your firÅ¿t cutting it, cut it cloÅ¿e to the new Branches, that it may grow over the cut; let it be cut a little Å¿lope, and Clay'd over, if you deÅ¿ire the Branch Å¿hould quickly cover it; and the Å¿ooner it doth the better.

Â§. 14. Care muÅ¿t be had in chooÅ¿ing Branches or Shoots from which you are to have your Buds, that they be of Shoots of the Å¿ame years growth you Inoculate; and of Å¿trong growth, the Bark firm, and not Å¿pungy; Å¿uffer them to fade as little as may be before you uÅ¿e them; and the Shoots muÅ¿t be got from Trees that your own or others experience can faithfully aÅ¿Å¿ure you not only to be good Fruit, but very good bearers; and if the Fruit you deÅ¿ign to raiÅ¿e, be at Å¿uch a diÅ¿tance that you cannot have Buds to Inoculate the Å¿ame day they are cut, put them in wet MoÅ¿s or GraÅ¿s in a Box, and Å¿o they will keep a day and a night very well. But if by carriage in the Air or otherwiÅ¿e they are a little withered, you may revive them by Å¿etting them in water,
which will make the Buds come cleaner from the Wood.

Â§. 15. Nectarins, Peaches, and Apricocks are Å¿eldom raiÅ¿ed otherwiÅ¿e than by Inoculation; becauÅ¿e they will rarely or never grow by Grafting; but Pears, Cherries, or Plums take and grow full as well by Grafting as Inoculation. The Bark of Cyens taken from Å¿ome Plums, is Å¿o tender and Å¿pungy they will often miÅ¿carry when Inoculated: Å¿uch one be Å¿ure to raiÅ¿e rather by Grafting, tho many Plums will hit very well being Inoculated.
Cyens of Apples fail for the moÅ¿t part, when you Inoculate Buds of them, becauÅ¿e their Bark is tender, and Buds weak.
Cherries and Pears take very Å¿ure being Inoculated on young freÅ¿h Stocks, whoÅ¿e Bark is not very thick.

Â§. 16. Upon conÅ¿ideration of all, I adviÅ¿e the Planter to raiÅ¿e all his Fruit-trees by Grafting, as being both the Å¿ureÅ¿t and eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t way; only his Peaches, Nectarins, and Apricocks can be propagated only by Inoculating; yet where Inoculating Å¿ucceeds well, it's eÅ¿teemed and prefer'd before Grafting, for the following reaÅ¿ons. 1. BecauÅ¿e the Stock will be big enough to Inoculate by two or three years Å¿ooner than to Graft, and your Plant groweth much
faÅ¿ter after the nature is Å¿o alter'd than it did before, and will be Å¿ooner ready to tranÅ¿plant than if it be Å¿uffer'd to grow two or three years longer, as it muÅ¿t be before it be ready to be Grafted. 2. It makes a Å¿ounder Tree than one that is Grafted, eÅ¿pecially in the Cleft; becauÅ¿e it covereth the Stock Å¿peedily and well. 3. It hurts not the Stock Å¿o much as Grafting; and if it chance to fail, it may be Inoculated next year again, and Å¿ometimes the Å¿ame year. 4. Some look upon Inoculating to be more Å¿peedy, eaÅ¿y and delightÅ¿ome than Grafting, and may be practiÅ¿ed by Gentlemen, who in June may lye on the ground and do it; whereof they cannot Å¿o well bear the cold without danger of taking hurt in February, or March, which is the choice of Grafting Å¿eaÅ¿on.
If you do Inoculate any Buds of Pear, Cherry, or Plum, let the Shoots be very Å¿trong and large, but you had better Graft them.

Â§. 17. Not only the Pith, but alÅ¿o the Wood of the Bud is caÅ¿t away in Inoculating, and nothing made uÅ¿e of but the Buds and Bark of any young Shoot, and yet they bring forth the
Å¿ame Fruit as the Tree whence they are got.

Â§. 18. It's debated among Planters what time of the day is beÅ¿t for Inoculating;Time of the day to Inoculate.
