Å¿ome perÅ¿ons argue Å¿tiffly for the morning; becauÅ¿e there paÅ¿leth up much more Sap or juice in the day-time than in the night, as they obÅ¿erve in piercing the Birch-Tree, and other Trees to get the liquor out of them for PhyÅ¿ical uÅ¿es; and conÅ¿equently the Bud Inoculated in the morning, muÅ¿t be more likely to grow, having the whole days plenty of Sap to invite it to unite with the Stock, than if it be Inoculated late in the day, and Å¿o muÅ¿t be diÅ¿couraged in it's new habitation by the niggardly proviÅ¿ion of the nights Sap.

If you follow this advice, you had beÅ¿t wrap Å¿ome broad Leaves or Fern about the Stock; Å¿o as to Å¿hade the Cyen from the Scorching heat of the day following, to prevent it's drying before the Stock hath undertaken the charge of preÅ¿erving it.
But this work may be done in the heat of the day, if the heat be not violent, and then you muÅ¿t (as at all times you ought) be very quick in the doing of it.

And for all that hath been Å¿aid before, the afternoon may be as good a time as any; becauÅ¿e if the Bud have leÅ¿s liquor afforded it in the night, then the coolneÅ¿s of that time makes it leÅ¿s thirÅ¿ty; and as it's thirÅ¿t encreaÅ¿eth by the heat of the next day, a more plentiful Stream will be very Å¿eaÅ¿onable to Å¿atisfy it.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Pruning Fruit-Trees.
div.p:
Â§. 1. AFter Grafts have had their full growth the firÅ¿t year, they muÅ¿t be Pruned, Å¿uch as need it; ThoÅ¿e that are Grafted low and yet muÅ¿t be made Standards, or tall Trees, leave only one Shoot, the Å¿trongeÅ¿t and biggeÅ¿t, and let not that Shoot begin to Å¿pread untill it be Å¿even foot high at leaÅ¿t; therefore cut off all the Å¿idebranches, till they are grown to the hight you deÅ¿ire. If to Å¿pred low, let Å¿ome be left on each Å¿ide, that the boughs on any one Å¿ide may grow Å¿traight upright. As for Wall-plants it's no matter of how many Branches they Å¿pread, the more the better. Now unleÅ¿s young Grafts put forth a Å¿trong and luÅ¿ty Shoot, Prune not off all the Å¿ide-branches, leÅ¿t the body of the Plant be too Å¿mall and limber to bear his head; therefore if the body be very Å¿lender Å¿uffer Å¿ome of the Å¿ide-twigs to grow, untill the Body be of a Å¿ufficient Å¿trength to bear the top, and from year to year Prune off thoÅ¿e Shoots and Branches as are Å¿uperfluous,
and grow too near one another, interfere, fret and gall each other, and preÅ¿erve only Å¿uch as are fit to make the Tree of a comly form; and Å¿uffer them not the firÅ¿t three years (at leaÅ¿t) to grow thick and buÅ¿hy-headed, by cutting off Å¿ome of the inÅ¿ide-Å¿hoots, and Å¿uch as grow croÅ¿s one another, or pendent.
Â§. 2. What you cut off the Body, or any Branch, do it cloÅ¿e and even, that the Bark may grow over it.

Â§. 3. If you cut part of any Shoot, or of a Cyen for Grafting, cut it cloÅ¿e at a Bud, that the cut may be cover'd with a freÅ¿h Sprig, and the wound may again grow up, and a Stub-end not be left behind.

Â§. 4. At what hight Å¿oever, or whereÅ¿oever you would have the Tree, or any Branch, or Shoot to Å¿pread, there top it, that is cut off a Bud, an Inch of the very top cloÅ¿e at a Bud, and there it will Å¿pread.

Â§. 5. When Trees grow big that a Knife will not Prune them, uÅ¿e the broad ChiÅ¿el (mention'd in Chap. 2. Sect. 2.) with which, and a Mallet, you may take off a Bough or large Branch, as you will, without either hurting the Bark of the Tree, by cutting too near, or leaving a Stump,
by not cutting near enough; one of which is not eaÅ¿ily avoided by the chance blows of an Ax, or Hatchet, and being amongÅ¿t thick boughs your ChiÅ¿el and Mallet will be more governable than other InÅ¿truments; If the boughs are very large you may uÅ¿e a Saw firÅ¿t, and then Å¿mooth it with the ChiÅ¿el.

Â§. 6. Trees growing in Orchards, Fields, or Hedges, &c. muÅ¿t be Pruned from year to year as need is, in November, or December, by cutting off Å¿uperfluous Branches and Å¿uch as croÅ¿s one another, and grow too cloÅ¿e; leave no dead Twigs or Branches, and Å¿crape off the MoÅ¿s on the body, or Branches of the Tree.
Â§. 7. Concerning the Pruning and ordering of Wall-trees, Å¿ee hereafter, Chap. 10. And you muÅ¿t not Prune thoÅ¿e Plants you intend for the Wall, untill tranÅ¿planted and Å¿et at the Wall.

Â§. 8. Prune not much and often, if you love Fruit more than a Tree to thrive in Wood; therefore whilÅ¿t your Tree is young, bring it unto a handÅ¿ome Å¿hape and order, and when it comes to beat Fruit forbear Pruning, unleÅ¿s in caÅ¿e of broken, or Å¿uch boughs as grow croÅ¿s, or gall, or fret others.

Touching the height of Fruit-trees.Â§. 9. And here I muÅ¿t beg leave to thwart and contradict the opinions of all our modern Planters, who applaud the making Trees not to be above an ell high before they Å¿pread: Their reaÅ¿ons are theÅ¿e that follow.
1. BecauÅ¿e the low Trees Å¿ooner attain to be Fruit-bearing Trees, and grow fairer than the tall; the Sap and juice waÅ¿ting in its long ball and paÅ¿Å¿age, which in the Å¿horter Trees expends it Å¿elf Å¿oon in the Branches.
2. You may Plant more of them in the like quantity of Land, becauÅ¿e the Å¿hadow of the one Tree doth not reach the ground of the other, as that of the tall Tree doth.
3. The lower and broad Å¿preading Tree is the greater bearer, by reaÅ¿on the bloÅ¿Å¿oms in the Spring are not Å¿o obvious to the bitter BlaÅ¿ts, nor the Fruit in the Autumn to the fierce and deÅ¿tructive Winds.
4. Fruits are more eaÅ¿ily gather'd from a low than a tall Tree, beating or Å¿haking down Fruit from Å¿uch Trees being to be rejected by all judicious CyderiÅ¿ts.
5. Any Fruit on a low well Å¿pread Tree, is better and fairer than that on a tall Tree, by the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on that the Tree is fairer, becauÅ¿e the Sap is not Å¿o much waÅ¿ted in the low and humble Tree, as in the tall and lofty by its large Trunck.

NotwithÅ¿tanding theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons Å¿eem plauÅ¿ible, yet experience aÅ¿Å¿ures, that a Tree of a reaÅ¿onable height (I mean not high like Tymber Trees) bears as well as the lower,
and if you obÅ¿erve a due diÅ¿tance, which ought to be, the Å¿hade will not be injurious; and tho Fruit on a low Tree is eaÅ¿ily gathered, yet the other may be with Å¿ome little pains gathered well enough.

But if you deÅ¿ign to uÅ¿e the Land under, or about the Trees you plant, either in Orchard, Field, or Hedg, for the Syth, Spade, or GraÅ¿ing of Cattle eÅ¿pecially, let your Trees be Å¿even foot high at leaÅ¿t before they begin to Å¿pread, becauÅ¿e you can Å¿carce Å¿o cautiouÅ¿ly preÅ¿erve them, but Cattle will Å¿omtime or other get into your Orchard, and then they will not a little endamage your Fruit-trees, if low, by nipping off the Buds of all boughs within their reach; and if you chance to farm the Orchard, your Tenants in deÅ¿pight of all Covenants to the contrary, will either be negligent, malitious, or Å¿o covetous as to permit Cattel to Graze in the Orchard, to your no little damage, which by letting them be Å¿even foot high before they begin to Å¿pread, will be infallibly prevented. But where you intend Trees for Table-fruit to he Å¿et in the Borders of Gardens or Walks, there you may let them Å¿pread within an ell and leÅ¿s of the Earth, as you Å¿hall hereafter be more fully inÅ¿tructed.

Â§. 10. In Pruning Trees be cautious of cutting off the Å¿mall Sprigs, which are the more apt to bear Fruit, it being too uÅ¿ual for ignorant Planters, to beautify their Trees, by taking off theÅ¿e Å¿uperfluous branches (as they term them) whereby they deprive themÅ¿elves of the Furit.
Â§. 11. Cherry-trees muÅ¿t be Grafted at the hight you would have them Å¿pread, about Å¿ix or Å¿even Foot high, unleÅ¿s for the Wall, and then within a Foot of the ground.

Â§. 12. Prune the Heads of Å¿ome Å¿ort of Trees that have but Å¿mall Pith as Apple-trees, Pear-trees, &c. when you remove them, to proportion the Branch and Root as near as you can; but Cherry-trees, Plum-trees, Walnut-trees, &c. that have a large Pith are not to be top't, only Å¿ome of the Å¿ide Branches may be taken away.
If you cut part of any Shoot, or a Cyen for Grafting, cut it cloÅ¿e at a Bud or Sprig, and the wound will again grow up, and a Stub end not left behind.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Touching the DiÅ¿tance of Fruit-Trees.
div.p:
DiÅ¿tance of Orchard-trees.Â§. 1. THe diÅ¿tance of Trees in Orchards ought not to be leÅ¿s than eight Yards, neither need it be more than 13, or 14; the richer the Land is, the greater diÅ¿tance you ought to Å¿et the Trees at from one another, to which you ought to have reÅ¿pect, and alÅ¿o to the kinds of Fruit-trees you plant; for Å¿ome Trees take up more room than others, as moÅ¿t Apple-trees more than Pear-trees, and Å¿ome Apple-trees more than others, according to their aptneÅ¿s to grow more or leÅ¿s, too tedious and difficult to be here related; only the Red-Å¿treak being Generally a deÅ¿ired Fruit, you may take notice that it's one of the leaÅ¿t Apple-trees; where it yields the beÅ¿t Cyder, Å¿omtimes it's almoÅ¿t but a Shrub, the Winter Pear-main, Golden-renating, and John-apple, are Trees that Å¿pread not much, but the Gregory-pippin, a Fruit-Tree in LancaÅ¿hire, is a mighty Å¿preader, even on courÅ¿e Land, grows well and quickly, and
is an excellent Fruit for any uÅ¿e, and th â¢ Trees great bearers, and the Fruit will eaÅ¿ily keep untill the following May.

Â§. 2 As to the diÅ¿tance Wall-fruit-trees are to be Å¿et at,DiÅ¿tance of Wall-trees. where they are to grow, you may learn that beÅ¿t by conÅ¿idering their aptneÅ¿s to Å¿pread; Apricocks and Å¿ome other kinds of Plums Å¿pread moÅ¿t, the May Cherry â¢ , and Å¿ome others are of a very Å¿mall growth, it's impoÅ¿Å¿ible to give Rules for all, but the general diÅ¿tance is about four yards aÅ¿under.

Cherry and Codling Hedge diÅ¿tances.Â§. 3. Of late times it's uÅ¿ed to make Cherry-hedges in Gardens and Orchards, and Hedges of Codlings, NurÅ¿-gardens, Plums, and Å¿uch like Trees that may be kept by cutting and plaiÅ¿hing one Branch within another, and from growing very large; theÅ¿e are uÅ¿ually made along the Å¿ide of Walks, or round about a Garden-plot, and are Ornamental to a Garden being ordered and kept handÅ¿omly.

Trees for theÅ¿e purpoÅ¿es are to be Å¿et about a yard, or an ell aÅ¿under; for they Å¿hould near meet the firÅ¿t year, and Å¿hould be thus ordered, viz. Å¿tretch a line from one end to the other where the Hedg is to be made, and Å¿et the Trees Å¿traight at the diÅ¿tance aforeÅ¿aid: Afterwards knock down a Stake betwixt each Tree, then having Å¿traight long Rods, or Poles of AÅ¿h, or the
like; tye a row of them from one end to the other (about a foot from the ground) faÅ¿t to the Stakes with OÅ¿iers, or Å¿uch like, or elÅ¿e nail them, which is better, and another row of Rods a foot above them, and Å¿o a third if need be, according to the height of the young Plants; Having thus done Å¿pread and tye the Branches of the Twigs of the Trees in order to the Poles, but not too hard, and draw and faÅ¿ten Å¿ome of them down cloÅ¿e to the ground, that Å¿o there may be BloÅ¿Å¿oms and Fruit from the bottom to the top, which will be a beautiful Å¿ight in the Spring and Summer: Then after a few years the Stakes and Poles may be taken away, and the Branches platted and woven one within another from year to year, and the Å¿uperfluous ones cut off.

ReaÅ¿ons for a large diÅ¿tance in Å¿etting Trees.Â§. 4. For many reÅ¿pects Trees ought to be planted at a large diÅ¿tance, eÅ¿pecially for the following reaÅ¿ons.
1. The Plantation will be little Annoyance to the Land, if either you Å¿et GooÅ¿-berries, Currens, Ras-berries, Straw-berries, or Garden Å¿tuff in it; Å¿ow Corn on it while the Trees are young, or graze it when they are grown up.
2. Whereas Å¿ome Å¿ay the more Trees the more Fruit; that's abÅ¿olutely falÅ¿e; for when they are Å¿et Å¿o cloÅ¿e, that the Sun cannot have a good influence on them, by refreÅ¿hing the Roots, Body, Branches, BloÅ¿Å¿oms and Fruits, they bear poorly, and
ripen worÅ¿e; and cloÅ¿e-Å¿et Trees in a few years when they Å¿hould bear Fruits, croud, fret, and gall one another, and by rubbing often cauÅ¿e the Canker.
3. They cannot grow to be Trees of that Å¿ize as they would (if the Land be good) being Å¿et at a good diÅ¿tance, and Å¿ome kind of Trees being of Å¿tronger and Å¿wifter growth than others, will Å¿o domineer over their neighbors, that they will make them almoÅ¿t good for nothing; and one Tree that is Å¿et at a fair diÅ¿tance will bear oftner, and more Fruit than three, or four Trees Å¿et cloÅ¿e, as is dayly Å¿een by Å¿ome Apple-trees that grow Å¿ingle, or in a Hedge.
4. You may Plant betwixt every Tree, a Cherry-tree, Plum-tree, or Codling-tree, which may grow up and bear with the other Trees many years, and never reach or Prejudice them, but will decay before the others are at full growth; Or you may Å¿et a young Apple-tree, or Pear-tree betwixt every two of your Standards that you Å¿et in the Orchard, and nurÅ¿e it up with neceÅ¿Å¿ary dreÅ¿Å¿ing and Pruning Å¿even or eight years, or leÅ¿s time, to tranÅ¿plant into Fields or PaÅ¿ture-land, where Cattle feed; whereby with little help it will not be in Å¿uch danger of hurt from Cattel as Å¿mall ones would, and bear Fruit Å¿oon after it's Å¿et, and you cannot let them grow Å¿o long in your NurÅ¿ery without galling, fretting, or hurting one
another, unleÅ¿s when you remove Trees out of your NurÅ¿ery, you take care to leave every other Tree, whereby they may have liberty to grow big, and Å¿o more fit for your Fields.

As for Standard Cherry-trees, Plum-trees, and the like, Å¿ix yards diÅ¿tance is the moÅ¿t convenient, unleÅ¿s the ground be exceeding rich, and then a greater diÅ¿tance, as Å¿even or eight yards aÅ¿under.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Choice of Ground for an Orchard, and the ordering it.
div.p: SO far as it lyeth in ones power to chooÅ¿e a plot of Ground for an Orchard, let it be done with reÅ¿pect to the following advantages

Â§. 1. It Å¿hould lye conveniently near him, declining and lying open towards the South, South-eaÅ¿t, or South-weÅ¿t, and defended from the North, North-eaÅ¿t, and NorthweÅ¿t Winds by buildings, Woods, or higher Grounds; the Land Å¿hould rather incline to dryneÅ¿s than moiÅ¿ture, without Springs, the Soyl deep and a fat Earth, not a Å¿tiff, cold Clay, or binding Gravel, nor a light, Å¿andy, esky or hollow Earth; yet with good Husbandry, if it run not into the extreams of any of theÅ¿e, Fruit-trees may proÅ¿per reaÅ¿onably well in it.

Â§. 2. The natural Soil for an Orchard is more to be reÅ¿pected than a Garden; for the Garden Fruit-trees, and what els groweth there, rooteth little deeper than it may be eaÅ¿ily manured; but Pear-trees and Apple-trees in Orchards Å¿hould grow to be large Trees, and therefore Å¿end forth Roots broad and deep, Å¿o that it tranÅ¿cends all coÅ¿t and pains to enrich the Ground for them, as far as the Roots every way reach.

Â§. 3. But they that are Å¿eated or fixed in any place, and cannot conveniently change their habitation, muÅ¿t be content with their own, and if any defect or diÅ¿advantage be in it, it may be it hath Å¿ome advantage that another wants, if it lye to the North, the Trees Bud and BloÅ¿Å¿om the later, and many times the Fruit thereby Å¿ucceeds the better, and is free from the injurious South-winds in the Autumnal Å¿eaÅ¿on.

Â§. 4. If it lye to the EaÅ¿t, it hath not only the advantage of being later Budded, and blown, becauÅ¿e of the cold EaÅ¿terly Winds in the Spring, but the Fruit ripens the better, the morning Sun in the Summer being by much the beÅ¿t, and the Fruits freed from the WeÅ¿tern Winds, which with the South are the worÅ¿t.

Â§. 5. If your Land be on a dry, or riÅ¿ing Ground, you may Plant them the thicker, which will cover and Å¿hade the Ground the Å¿ooner, and make them bear the better; the Fruit will alÅ¿o yield a more vinous Liquor.

Â§. 6. If your Ground lye in a cold moiÅ¿t Vale, the Å¿ooner may you raiÅ¿e a natural Fence about it, to defend your Trees from cold Winds, and Å¿tiff GuÅ¿ts, which diverÅ¿ly anoy your Trees and Fruits; and I once knew a perÅ¿on that had a cold moiÅ¿t flat Å¿pringey plot of Ground, who cauÅ¿ed double Ditches to be made therein, at ten yards diÅ¿tance, each from other, and about an Ell high; upon theÅ¿e Ditches he planted Apple-trees each ten yards diÅ¿tant from another, which Trees did grow, proÅ¿per, and bear exceeding well.

Â§. 7. But if you have liberty to chooÅ¿e what Land you will for Planting of Fruit-trees, obÅ¿erve the directions given in the firÅ¿t Section of this Chap. and chooÅ¿e a warm, light Rye-land, or either a black or brown mold, if with a mixture of Sand, Å¿o much the better, but the heavy cold and moiÅ¿t Wheat-land is not Å¿o good.

Â§. 8. If the Ground be very light and rich of it felf, or Å¿o made by improvement, Å¿everal Å¿orts of Apple-trees, eÅ¿pecially the Pippin, will be Å¿o apt to canker, that they will Å¿carce ever be large Trees; therefore a firm and Å¿trong Land; is beÅ¿t for Winter or long laÅ¿ting Fruit; but for Summer-fruit, Land cannot be too light; the more it inclines to redneÅ¿s the better.

How to qualify the Ground.Â§. 9. If the Land you intend for it be a Turf or Green-Å¿ward, you ought to Plow it two years before you Å¿et your Trees in it, to make it mellow and looÅ¿e, that the Trees may be better take Root, and you may then lay on Manure, which by Plowing will be well mixt with the natural Soil, and uÅ¿e Å¿uch Manure as will beÅ¿t Å¿uit to amend it; and if you Å¿ow the Ground about ten days after the MidÅ¿ummur before you Plant, with Turneps, and when they are got off, which will be about November, if you pleaÅ¿e, then Å¿et your Trees, they will like well.

Â§. 10. Where the natural Soil is not good of it Å¿elf, whether it be in Garden, Orchard, or Field, there it ought to be by skill aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted and better'd, at leaÅ¿t wiÅ¿e for Å¿uch a compaÅ¿s as the Roots of every Tree take up for Å¿ome time, if not Å¿o far round as they are ever like to extend themÅ¿elves.

And this muÅ¿t be done by mixing Å¿uch Manures with the Soil as Å¿uit beÅ¿t with it's temper. If the Soil be Clay, or Clay mixed with Gravel or wet heavy Land, hot Dung, as that of HorÅ¿es, or Poultry, or for want of that, of Oxen or Cows is beÅ¿t to mix with it, to bring it to a due temperament.

And if the Soil be light, hollow, esky, or Å¿andy Land; Marl, Mud out of a Pond, Ditch, or River, or Å¿hovelings of Dirty yards or Highways, if they be not Sandy, and be well Mellowed, by lying on heaps, and eÅ¿pecially if thoÅ¿e heaps are mixed with Lime, are proper to mend it.
If this laÅ¿t Soil be barren likewiÅ¿e, you may properly add a mixture of Neats Dung.

It hath been Å¿een that an Apple-tree on a Hemp-but, which was conÅ¿tantly Plowed, and Manured to a great richneÅ¿s, bore more Apples than four Å¿uch Trees in an Orchard would do; and it's conÅ¿tantly Å¿een in Barren hungry Land, Trees thrive poorly, grow MoÅ¿Å¿ey, or Bark-bound, bearing Å¿eldom, and that a poor Fruit: Only Walnut-trees and Pear-trees do not neceÅ¿Å¿arily require a very rich Ground, and will proÅ¿per beÅ¿t on Stony, and light Land.
If your Land be too rich (which is Å¿eldom Å¿een) you may mix Coal-aÅ¿hes with it.

MoiÅ¿t Land to order.Â§. 11. If your Land is very flat, that wet is apt to Å¿tand upon it, or be a Å¿hallow Soil, you may Å¿omthing help it in Plowing, alÅ¿o by gathering the Land always up in and near the place where you intend the Rows of Trees Å¿hall afterwards Å¿tand, which in two years time will Å¿omthing raiÅ¿e it, and thicken the Soil, and the Furrows Å¿o made will help to carry off the Water, or which is better, raiÅ¿e the Land on broad Ridges, that the middle of them may be about 24, or 30 Foot diÅ¿tance, according as you intend to Plant your Trees: Let the Intervals between the Ridges be about eight Foot broad, and the Earth taken up between, about a Foot deep, and caÅ¿t on the Ridges which will make the Ground thicker of the beÅ¿t Soil than before it was, that the Roots of the Trees you Plant on the Ridges cannot run down, nor Å¿pread into the bad Soil, which otherwiÅ¿e it would do; by this means the Trees will thrive and proÅ¿per well, as may be perceived on the Banks of Å¿ome Land, and the Hedges, that Apple-trees will thrive better there than on the Level-land.

MoiÅ¿t Land to order.Â§. 12. If it be a Springey moiÅ¿t or Å¿pewy Land, you muÅ¿t Trench it at the head of the Spring, and that deeper than the chanel of the Spring runs in the Earth, which you may leave open, and yearly cleanÅ¿e, or fill it up with Alder or Oler-boughs, and
cover them with the Turf and Earth that came forth, much higher than the other Land; for the Wood and looÅ¿e Earth will Å¿ink very much by degrees; or you may dig Å¿everal narrow Trenches, one between each Row of Trees, deÅ¿cending to Å¿ome Ditch at the lower end of your Ground, and lay in the bottom of it Alder-frith, or Faggots of Beech, and fill the Trenches again on the Å¿aid Frith or Faggots with Earth, as aforeÅ¿aid, and the Water will inÅ¿inuatingly paÅ¿s through the Å¿aid Wood to the lower Å¿ide of the Ground, leaving the reÅ¿t dryer; but if you cannot eaÅ¿ily do this, order it as at the foregoing Section.

Â§. 13. If it be Springey, but only lye Å¿o low and flat that in the Winter Rain or Land-floods will lye upon it, and that it hath been lately Plowed, or that you'l not loÅ¿e two years time by Plowing it before you Å¿et your Trees, or if it be Å¿hallow or ebb Soil, you may Å¿et your Trees by Tumping.

Hot dry Land to order.Â§. 14. If your Ground be a hot dry Sandy Å¿hallow Land, Marl laid on the Å¿urface and there Å¿pread, will cool, Å¿adden, and make it rich; or if you can, cauÅ¿e the Current of Å¿ome Rill of Water, or rather Water that runs from Pools, Ponds, or Dunghills, to over flow it Å¿omtimes, which will
not only moiÅ¿ten, but make the Ground fertile alÅ¿o, and the Trees proÅ¿per well.
Fern or any other vegetables, nay Stones covering Å¿uch Land, will preÅ¿erve it cool and moiÅ¿t.

Gravelly-ground to order.Â§. 15. Gravel-grounds are as bad as any; becauÅ¿e a Tree in them cannot Root to any great bigneÅ¿s; and if Muck, or other Soils be laid to the Roots of Trees in Å¿uch Land, the Gravel will in a few years eat it up, and convert it unto it's own nature; but if a little Stony, a mixture of Mold among the Stones, and at the digging to pick our the largeÅ¿t Stones, then Trees will Root indifferent well in Å¿uch Grounds.

Over-flown Land.Â§. 16. If Land be Å¿ubject to be over-flown by the inundation of Rivers, or other falls of Water, Å¿o as the Water Å¿tand not too long upon it, nor the Land be of a Å¿tiff cold nature, it's very good for Fruit-trees.

Of uneven Ground.Â§. 17. If there be any unevenneÅ¿s in the Land, Å¿ome direct to level it, by carrying the Banks into the low places; but this will not only be very chargeable, but hurtful, by making the high places too barren, and the low Ground too rich.

But that your Trees may grow Å¿omewhat level in their tops, and not one overÅ¿hade another, and alÅ¿o appear comly, you may fore-caÅ¿t to Å¿et Å¿uch Trees as grow pendant,
or are not apt to grow tall Trees, on the higheÅ¿t Ground, and Å¿uch as are aÅ¿piring in the lower places.

The Fence and Order of Trees in an Orchard,Â§. 18. EncloÅ¿e your Orchard with a good double Ditch about four Foot high, and plant thereon two Rows of good Hawthorn, or Whitethorn, which will be an excellent Fence by the time that the Fruit-trees bear, to keep out Cattel from cropping the tender Twigs of the Fruit-trees, and rubing againÅ¿t their Stems, and unruly People from deÅ¿troying the Fruit. Good Whitethorn being the beÅ¿t Quick-fence for your Orchard, when it's grown up may be plaiÅ¿hed, the better to prevent Hogs or Sheep for creeping into it. Set no Å¿mooth Quick in it, that may grow to great Trees, becauÅ¿e they will be hurtful both to the Hedg and Fruit-trees, both by their tops and Roots when they are grown up: Having Å¿et two Rows of good Hawthorn, and made the dead Hedg on the out-Å¿ide the Ditch, the Quick-Å¿et will grow the faÅ¿ter, for the dead Hedg upon the Ditch is apt to choak the Quick-Å¿ets, and thus with Å¿omtimes Weeding it you may Å¿oon raiÅ¿e a good Fence.

If you have an old Hedg already about your Orchard, Å¿cour the Ditch and plaiÅ¿h the Hedg, and cut down all big Trees that grow in it, unleÅ¿s on the North, and WeÅ¿tÅ¿ide, the one requiring a defence to keep
the Orchard warm, the other to Å¿ecure it Å¿omwhat from the Å¿trong Winds, that blow down the Fruit before it's ripe, tho it's far better they grow on the outÅ¿ide the Hedg.

On the outÅ¿ide of your Orchard, not too near the Hedg, if it be not well defended by Hills, Buildings, or the like; Plant on the North-Å¿ide, two or three Rows of Walnut-trees, thicker than is uÅ¿ually done on other accounts, to preÅ¿erve the Orchard from the cold Nothern Air.
Some are alÅ¿o for Planting a Defence on the weÅ¿t-Å¿ide, to protect them from the brisk Autumnal Winds, which blow down the Fruit before ripe.

Within the Orchard on the North-Å¿ide, Å¿et the firÅ¿t Rows of Pear-trees, or Å¿uch other Trees as you know are apt to grow talleÅ¿t, and the reÅ¿t South-ward, as they decreaÅ¿e in hight, as near as you can judge; for Å¿o Å¿hall all your Trees Å¿hare in great meaÅ¿ure of the South-Å¿un, and will be leÅ¿s lyable to receive damage by the Northern old: The beÅ¿t way you can Å¿et Trees in an Orchard is according to the Figure call'd a Quincunx, by Planting them at an equal diÅ¿tance every way, only with this obÅ¿ervation, that every Tree of the Å¿econd Row may Å¿tand againÅ¿t the middle of the Å¿pace of the FirÅ¿t; in the Third againÅ¿t the Å¿pace of the Second; and Å¿o through out, which makes an
Orchard appear pleaÅ¿ant to the Eye in what part Å¿oever thereof you Å¿tand.

Â§. 19. If your Soil be not rich enough, once in three or four years in the Wintertime,Baring the Roots of Trees-in Winter. open the Earth for a good Å¿pace round about the body of each Tree, and about a Month after with Å¿ome proper Manure mixt with what came forth, fill up the hole again; but if you dig or Plow your Land, you will have no need to do this Å¿o long; and if your Trees were Å¿et by tumping, you need not do this, till the Roots are grown paÅ¿t the Ditch that was made about the Tump.

Muck-water good for the Roots of Fruit-trees.Â§. 20. The Water that Å¿oaks from a Dunghil, is an excellent thing to enrich the Earth about the Roots of Trees, and if your Orchard chance to lie Å¿o as that it may be floted Å¿omtimes, you may do it after this manner.

Make a little Trench along the upper part of the Orchard, and from it cut a Å¿mall Gutter down every row of Trees, take off the upper Turf for half a yards breadth round about every Tree, at about a Foots breadth diÅ¿tance from the body, when a rainy day comes, let this Å¿oke down one Row, Å¿o that (as near as you can) every Tree may enjoy it three or four days at Å¿everal times in one Winter

If your Orchard Å¿tand Å¿o that you cannot convey this Water to the Trees after this manner, you may carry two or three pale-full to every Tree twice or thrice a year, and pour it in where the Roots were opened, and againÅ¿t Spring put in the Earth again; when you do this firÅ¿t, Å¿tir up with Å¿omthing the bottom of this Water the more to thicken and enrich it.
This will follow the Roots and more enrich the Trees than can be done by Manure, or Dung, Å¿o that you Å¿uffer the Water not to be above a days time at once upon any one Tree.

Plant Fruit proper for the Soil and Clymate.Â§. 21. Some judgment is required from the Planter in Å¿etting each Tree or Plant in the proper Clymate and So I it moÅ¿t delights in, or in adapting Plants to the Nature of each Soil you have to Plant; for Trees will Å¿trangly proÅ¿per, grow and bear in Soil and Ground they like, comparatively to what they will do if they are Planted in Ground wherein they delight not.

The Apple it Å¿elf, which is but one kind of Fruit, yet are there Å¿everal Å¿orts of them, that delight in Å¿ome places, and will not thrive in another, which made the KentiÅ¿hmen Å¿o addict themÅ¿elves to the Planting of the Pippin and Codling; becauÅ¿e no other Apple would proÅ¿per Å¿o
well in that County, whence they are call'd KentiÅ¿h-pippin and Codlin; when in Å¿ome other places neither of thoÅ¿e Fruits will proÅ¿per without Art, but are deÅ¿troyed by that pernicious diÅ¿eaÅ¿e the Canker.
The Red-Å¿treak alÅ¿o is obÅ¿erved to proÅ¿per better and yield a better juice in Å¿ome places than in others, altho but in the next PariÅ¿h, Å¿o Summer-pears will thrive where the Winter will not.

Therefore conÅ¿ider what Species of Fruits are moÅ¿t natural to the Country or place where you intend to raiÅ¿e your Trees, which may be known partly by the growth and well bearing of Trees in the Neighborhood, or by experimenting variety of Å¿orts in your own Ground, then propagate and Plant thoÅ¿e that grow, proÅ¿per, and bear beÅ¿t.

Plant not Standards too near your HouÅ¿es or Walls.Â§. 22. When you Plant an Orchard, or any Ranges of Trees near your HouÅ¿e or Walls, Plant them at Å¿uch a diÅ¿tance from your HouÅ¿es or Walls, as that when they are grown up to any conÅ¿iderable magnitudes, they may not over-hang your Wall-trees, or hinder the Sun too much from coming to them, whereby your Fruit is much better in everp reÅ¿pect.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The time moÅ¿t proper for TranÅ¿planting of Fruit-Trees.
div.p: Â§. 1. STone-fruit will be firÅ¿t ready to remove;Time for removing for after two years growth in the Seed-plot or NurÅ¿ery after they are Inoculated or Grafted, you may well remove them, be they for Wall or Dwarfs, which you ought to do in October or November, early removing being advantagious for all Fruit-trees, both for the Å¿ecurity of their growing and their well-growing. The beÅ¿t time to tranÅ¿plant into Orchards is from the end of September to the end of November, tho you may do it untill the end of February, but that's not Å¿o good by far, for the Å¿ooner after Michaelmas the better; if the leaves are not all fallen when you remove the Trees, pick them off.

You may begin Å¿ooner to Plant well-grown Trees, than thoÅ¿e that are very young, and in a very thriving condition, eÅ¿pecially young Apple-trees, and Peaches, whoÅ¿e Stocks were raiÅ¿ed of the Stone or Kernel, which will be
in a growing poÅ¿ture untill extream weather put them to a Å¿tand; therefore for Å¿uch Å¿tay untill about the middle of November.

Young Trees having been taken up about November, and the end of the Roots cut off, like unto a Hind or Goats foot on the under-Å¿ide, and laid in the Earth till March to be Planted, being then taken forth again, it hath appeared that they have put out many Fibrous Roots at the ends of thoÅ¿e big Roots cut off, which had they done in the place they were to grow in the next Summer, this would have been a good preparation againÅ¿t Spring; and it's always Å¿een that Trees Å¿et in February, or March make generally a much leÅ¿s growth the next year, than thoÅ¿e that were Å¿et before winter. If a dry Summer happen to Å¿ucceed, it often kills Å¿ome of the late-Å¿et Trees, and puts Å¿uch a Sap to others that they recover not of many years.
In Å¿harp FroÅ¿ts, or in Snows, though you could dig, it's not good to remove Trees.

Â§. 2. If your Trees for Standards at Å¿eting are not very weak bodied,How to Prune and order Trees at removal. Prune them up, leaving three or four of the principal Branches on the top, that grow outward, which Å¿hould be lop't off almoÅ¿t a years growth but if they be weak (leÅ¿t the Winds Å¿hould injure them by toÅ¿Å¿ing them) you
may top them lower, doing it at a Bud or Å¿mall Twigg, and in big Trees cut the top almoÅ¿t all off; and whenÅ¿oever you tranÅ¿plant young Trees cut off the end of all big Roots on the under-Å¿ide, like unto a Hinds Foot, and they'l put forth new Roots the better.

BigneÅ¿s of Trees to be removed.Â§. 3. At three years end after Grafting in the NurÅ¿ery, Trees may be fit to be removed into an Orchard, eÅ¿pecially if you Plow (or which is Å¿afer, dig) the Orchard-Land, and Å¿et Beans or other Kitchin-Garden Å¿tuff in it for Å¿ome years; but if it be Å¿uch a piece of Land that you Graze, then you muÅ¿t be Å¿ure their heads are grown out of the reach of Cattle before you Å¿et them there, and you muÅ¿t Fence them one of the ways mentioned hereafter.

How to remove a large Tree.Â§. 4. It's the beÅ¿t way to remove Trees very young, as at three years growth, if they may be Å¿ecured from danger, which in Orchards or Fields where Cattle have liberty to feed, they cannot well be with ordinary Fencing, unleÅ¿s they be of five or Å¿ix years growth after Grafting. He that hath a NurÅ¿ery of his own, and removes them into places, Å¿o near that he can well do it, let him the very Å¿ame or the next day after they are taken up, Å¿et them in the place appointed for them, and not cut off too much of the Roots, but the
greateÅ¿t part of the Top; and he may do well to Plant Å¿trong and well grown Trees eÅ¿pecially, in his Fields, and out-grounds; for the charge of Fencing will be much eaÅ¿ed, and being carefully Å¿et, they may proÅ¿per as well or better than Å¿mall ones, eÅ¿pecially in uncultivated or Å¿tiff Land by nature, where young Trees cannot Å¿o well put forth Roots; and the following way is better to have old Trees grows and proÅ¿per well than is commonly practiÅ¿ed, viz.

If you chance to have any Trees betwixt Ten and Thirty years old that you have a mind to remove, you muÅ¿t about November, the year before you TranÅ¿plant them, dig a Trench as narrow as you pleaÅ¿e, but Å¿o deep as to meet with moÅ¿t of the Å¿preading Roots at Å¿uch a diÅ¿tance round about the body of the Tree as you would cut the Roots off at when you remove it, (about half a yard diÅ¿tant from the body may do well, if they be not very large Trees, but if you have not far to carry them, longer) as you make the Trench cut the Roots you meet with clear off, and Å¿mooth without Å¿plitting them, or bruiÅ¿ing the Bark; fill up the Trench again, and by October next after, when you take up the Tree to Å¿et it elÅ¿ewhere, you will find thoÅ¿e great Roots will have put forth many fibrous Roots, and made preparation for more, with freÅ¿h and
tender Roots, upon removal will enable the Tree to draw more nouriÅ¿hment than otherwiÅ¿e it would, and conÅ¿equently to proÅ¿per better in it's new manÅ¿ion.
Â§. 5. Many of thoÅ¿e Trees removed very timely, as in the end of September, or in October, may Å¿hrink and Å¿eem to wither much, yet they will recover and come to their former plumpneÅ¿s.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the manner of removing and Å¿etting Trees.
div.p: CoaÅ¿ting Trees.Â§. 1. IN removing any big Tree, men generally obÅ¿erve to CoaÅ¿t them, that is, to place the Å¿ame Å¿ide of the Tree to the South-EaÅ¿t, &c. as grew formerly that way where it Å¿tood before; to which end before you remove it, you had beÅ¿t make Å¿ome mark in the Bark of the Tree which way it Å¿tood, this you may obÅ¿erve in Å¿traight Trees, but it's more material if your Trees lean one way more than another, to Å¿et the leaning Å¿ide towards the South-weÅ¿t, from whence the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Winds blow; but notwithÅ¿tanding this obÅ¿ervation, you need not mind it in Å¿mall Trees, or Å¿uch that have grown in cloÅ¿e-NurÅ¿eries; they not being capable of any conÅ¿iderable alteration from any AÅ¿pect of the Heavens.

In caÅ¿e a Tree before removal hath the benefit of the EaÅ¿t, or WeÅ¿t Sun, more than of the South, then Plant that Tree that before had that advantage, on the like
again in it's new place, which altho it vary from the directions aforeÅ¿aid, yet not from the reaÅ¿on of it.

How to take up Trees to be TranÅ¿planted.Â§. 2. Be carefull in taking up the Plants; dig round about them, and take off the Mold from their Roots; if it be a Å¿mall Plant, it may be drawn up eaÅ¿ily, the Mold being taken away, if it be great, and the Roots Å¿pread much, then they may be cut about half a yard from the body of the Plant, and the greater it is, the further off cut the Roots, and Å¿o draw it up; but keep the Spade from coming too near the Tree, by Å¿urrounding the Tree at a good diÅ¿tance, and endeavour to raiÅ¿e as much Earth as you can with the Tree, but if it be to cary far, Å¿hake it off; then pick off all the Leaves, if they be not fallen off, becauÅ¿e the Sun and Air by their means extract the Sap out of the Branches.

Pear-trees have ordinarily more brittle Roots than Apple-trees, and the Roots of Apple-trees, or Stocks, raiÅ¿ed of the Kernels of good Fruit, are more brittel than thoÅ¿e raiÅ¿ed of Crab or wilding Kernels; therefore take more care and pains in opening Ground deeper and wider, when you take up the more tender and brittle Rooted Plants, and pull not over hard, leÅ¿t you leave moÅ¿t of the Roots behind.

Young Trees beÅ¿t to Å¿et.Â§. 3. Young Trees of three or four years old at moÅ¿t when removed, do not only grow Å¿urer, but make a larger growth at firÅ¿t Planting, than greater and elder Trees can do, and are therefore beÅ¿t to tranÅ¿plant.

Â§. 4. If your Trees have lain Å¿ome time out of the Ground, or been carried in the Wind or FroÅ¿ts, that their Roots Å¿eem to be dry, Å¿et them over night in Water, immerging only the Roots, and it will very much revive them; or when you Plant them, after you have added an indifferent quantity of Earth, caÅ¿t in a Pail or more of Water as the largneÅ¿s of the FoÅ¿s or hole requires, which not only quickens the Roots, but makes the Earth adhere thereunto, which otherwiÅ¿e would lye light and hollow about them. The Air does much incommode the Root of any Plant whatever, and Å¿o does FroÅ¿t.

Â§. 5. One may Carry young Trees many Miles to be tranÅ¿planted;How to order Trees for Carrying. being carefully taken up, lay the Roots all one way, the Å¿malleÅ¿t and tendereÅ¿t in the middle of the Bundle, and bind them cloÅ¿e from the Roots to their tops with a Å¿oft band, and then Å¿tuff the Roots round about with Straw, Hay, MoÅ¿s and the like; afterwards bind the bundle all over from the Roots to the very top with Hay, or Straw-bands, or
Å¿omething els, to preÅ¿erve them from bruiÅ¿ing, and wrap Å¿omething abouts the Roots, a piece of an old ackcloth, or any thing that will preÅ¿erve the Roots from the Wind, Sun, and from bruiÅ¿ing: And in Winter you may carry young Trees thus many Hundred Miles.
Â§. 6. See Chap. 8. Sect, 2.

Set upon every Removal in a better Soil.Â§. 7. It muÅ¿t always be obÅ¿erved that upon every removal of Fruit-trees, to Plant or Å¿et them again into as good or better Soil as that out of which they were taken.

But if that cannot be, then Plant, and Å¿et them for Å¿o far as the Roots may extend in three or four years growth in as good or better Mold than that out of which they were removed, by laying good Soils under, upon, and about the Roots at the Å¿etting; for after they have taken Root two or three years, they will then grow in ordinary Soils; the great danger is at firÅ¿t Planting, which is the reaÅ¿on Trees proÅ¿per abundantly better taken out of courÅ¿e and barren NurÅ¿eries, than out of thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Soils are very rich, either by nature, or improvement: therefore be Å¿ure to lay as good or better Soil upon, under, and about the Roots when they are Å¿et again, if you expect your Trees proÅ¿per.

Set not Trees deep but Å¿hallow.Â§. 8. Take heed of Å¿etting the Roots of your Plants too deep below the good Soil, for if Å¿et Å¿hallow they proÅ¿per far better, than Å¿uch as are Å¿et deep; becauÅ¿e in the top of the Earth is the beÅ¿t Mold, Å¿o made by the Suns influence thereon, and every Å¿hower of Rain reaches, and refreÅ¿hes, and feeds the Roots: for all may eaÅ¿ily obÅ¿erve Trees thrive beÅ¿t where the Roots run near the Surface, and not at all where Planted deep; becauÅ¿e by deep Planting they thruÅ¿t down their Roots below the good Soil into that which is barren and unfruitful; which cauÅ¿es your Trees to be injured by Canker, MoÅ¿s, and to be bad bearers, and ill thrivers.

Â§ 9. Cut away many of the Branches of all large Trees you Å¿et,Prune the Branches and Roots at removal. becauÅ¿e every removal is a check to nature, and their growth, and the Roots being cut, yield for Å¿ome years but a faint nutriment, Å¿carce Å¿ufficient to preÅ¿erve life, much leÅ¿s to make a large growth: But Plants of a leÅ¿Å¿er Å¿ize need not have their Branches cut, unleÅ¿s they croÅ¿s one another, grow too nigh together, or run up too high without Å¿preading, but cut off the ends of all the Roots; becauÅ¿e if cut, many Å¿mall Fibra's or Å¿trings Å¿hoot out of the cut place, which draw nouriÅ¿hment for the Plant, which without cutting would not.
See before Sect. the Å¿econd, in Chap. 8.

Â§. 10. Make a hole about one yard Å¿quare and two Foot deep; but if your Soil be wet, or binding Gravel, or Å¿uch like,How to Å¿et Trees. very bad in the bottom, go not Å¿o deep, it will be better to Å¿et them Å¿hallow, and raiÅ¿e the Earth about them; And if not manur'd Land you Å¿et them in, have in readineÅ¿s Å¿ome very fine rich Mold, or Å¿hovelings of a Yard where Cattle are frequently lodged or fed, or well temper'd Street-dirt, or the Mold of rotten Vegetables, or the Sediments of Currents that Å¿ettle in the bottoms of Pools, or Ditches, that have lain long on heaps, till the Å¿ame are become mellow and dry; eÅ¿pecially if Å¿ome Lime be at caÅ¿ting out mixt therewith, or rotten Neats-dung, which you may mix with the Earth that came forth of the hole; and Å¿o order it, that it may be as good or better than that out of which the Trees came; Fill the hole full half way up with this, and tread it down in Å¿uch form (having reÅ¿pect to the Roots of the Tree that is to be Å¿et in it) that the Roots may reÅ¿t cloÅ¿e upon it, then cut off the ends of all the Roots like unto a Deers foot on the underÅ¿ide, they'l put forth new Roots the better, (if the Tree have one long down-right Root (call'd the Tap, or Heart-root) cut it almoÅ¿t half off) then clay
your Tree in, and fill up the hole with the Mold, by caÅ¿ting in the Å¿malleÅ¿t and beÅ¿t next to the Roots, and be careful that all the Å¿mall Mold run between all the Roots; to that end, Å¿tir and Å¿hake the Plant, that there may not be any hollow place where the Mold Å¿alls not, and with your hand, draw up the uppermoÅ¿t Roots, and part them that they may Å¿pread in the Mold every way; Fill up the hole with the Mold, and uÅ¿e all diligence to Place the Roots of your Tree in the Å¿ame poÅ¿ture they were in before you removed it. If the Tree be young, and the Roots Å¿lender, this can be performed no way but by throwing in a little Soil at a time, and then raiÅ¿ing up with your hands Å¿uch Roots as are preÅ¿Å¿ed down by it below their proper Å¿ituation, Å¿preading them on the Soil you have caÅ¿t in, and then throwing in more, and ordering the Roots as before, Å¿o continuing to do till you have fill'd up the hole.
Old Trees with Å¿turdy Roots require not Å¿o much curioÅ¿ity, but be Å¿ure that the Mold lye cloÅ¿e under, betwixt, and among the Roots.

If the Soil be light, preÅ¿s it down gently with your foot; then cover them half a yard about with Straw, Weeds, Litter, Fern, or the like, which will keep the Roots warm all Winter, and moiÅ¿t and cool in the following Summer; but if your Ground
be not very rich, cover the top about the Tree with Dung.

Note that Dung is not good to lay next the Roots of your Trees, unleÅ¿s it be converted to Mold by it's long lying and rottenneÅ¿s, but Dung is better, being mixed with the Earth laid next the Roots of Trees than alone.
Â§. 11. Forget not to water all Trees you Plant, either very early or late.

To Stake Trees.Â§. 12. Standard-trees Planted in an open place Å¿hould for a year or two be Å¿taked, if they be large Trees in danger to be Å¿haken by the Winds; for a Tree at firÅ¿t Å¿etting Å¿hould not be Å¿haken, but after two or three years Rooting, Å¿haking is good: If they Å¿tand in a Å¿ad Earth, not Plowed or digged, knock down a Å¿traight Stake cloÅ¿e to every Tree, and tye the Plant faÅ¿t to it with a Hay-band or other Å¿oft Band, and be careful to prevent galling or fretting by interpoÅ¿ing and wrapping the Hay-band once or twice about the Tree before you tye it to the Stake; Å¿et the Stake leaning towards the CoaÅ¿ts you expect the greateÅ¿t Winds, and let not your Stakes continue above a year and half.

Watering Trees.Â§. 13. Trees being Planted, it's very good to keep yearly the Ground Digged or Plowed about them for the firÅ¿t Å¿even
years, which will conduce much to their growth, and preÅ¿erve them from MoÅ¿s, and other diÅ¿eaÅ¿es.

If you are enforced to remove a Tree in Summer, take the Earth you digged out of the FoÅ¿s or hole you intend to Plant your Tree in, and mix and temper it well with an equal quantity of Cow-dung, and as much water as will make it into a Liquid pap; fill the hole almoÅ¿t with this, and let the Root of the Tree gently Å¿ink into it; cover it over with the Mold, and lay Å¿ome Fern or Litter over all, and once a Month water it, and it will grow well.

To help Trees on barren Soil.Â§. 14. If your Land be not rich on which your Trees grow, it's exceeding good in October, November, or December to lay on the top of the Earth about them, Lees of Wine, the waÅ¿hing of Å¿trong-bear Barrels, Blood of Cattle, dead Dogs, or any Carrion, Swines-dung mixed with Earth, once in three or four years, but have a care that you lay not too much, and too often about them, alÅ¿o Soap-Å¿uds, when cold, and Soap-aÅ¿hes are alÅ¿o good. And if your Trees be grown out of the reach of Cattle, you may Å¿uffer them to ly amongÅ¿t them in the Winter from Michaelmas till Mayday.

About bad bearing Trees.Â§. 15. Trees of good bearing kinds will uÅ¿ually bear after they are four or five years old, untill extream old age, unleÅ¿s they grow on barren Soil, or Å¿omtimes they'l not bear whil'Å¿t they grow very Å¿trong, luÅ¿tily and vigorouÅ¿ly, and have too great a Å¿upply of Sap; but after Å¿ome years they'l then bear well, if they were Grafted of good bearing kinds; but in caÅ¿e Trees are Wall-trees and Å¿hoot exceÅ¿Å¿ively, and bear not, then abate their overful and rank fertile nouriÅ¿hment, by putting in Sand, or any thing that is barren inÅ¿tead of the fat Soil, and cut off one or two of the biggeÅ¿t Roots from the body, that Å¿o it may have leÅ¿s nouriÅ¿hment, and that left will turn to Fruits; and bend downwards alÅ¿o the Branches, and faÅ¿ten them to the Wall with their tops as low as may be, which reÅ¿trains and obÅ¿tructs the exceÅ¿Å¿ive riÅ¿ing of Sap, which riÅ¿ing moderately turns to Fruits. But if Trees are naturally bad bearers, there is no other remedy, but Grafting them again with Grafts taken from Å¿ome good bearing kinds, which are known by yearly experience to bear Fruits well and abundantly.

To Graft old Trees.Â§. 16. When Fruit-trees are grown to extream old Age, and therefore bear little, cut off their heads or big Boughs, not Å¿traight over, but aÅ¿lope, that Rain and moiÅ¿ture may not reÅ¿t on the top to Rot it. TheÅ¿e will put forth many young Shoots
next Summer, which may be Grafted the Spring after with good bearing kinds; and theÅ¿e old Bodies having young heads which draw up Sap vigorouÅ¿ly, will bear Å¿tore of Fruits many years after; or you may cut off their heads even and Å¿mooth, and put two Grafts in the Cleft, and two in the Rind, and they will Å¿oon cover their heads, if you keep well temper'd Clay continually on and about their heads. See Chap. 2. Sect. 10.

To know the kinds of your Trees.Â§. 17. When you Plant Fruit-trees in your Garden, or Walls, or in Orchards, draw the Platform of them in paper, and Å¿o Å¿et down the name of every Tree according to the place it Å¿tands in, which will be both Å¿atisfactory and uÅ¿eful at any Å¿eaÅ¿on of the year, readily to know what kind of Fruit every Tree beareth.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Planting Wall-fruit.
div.p: AS for the Soil, diÅ¿tance, and Stocks for Wall-Trees you are before inÅ¿tructed; It remains only to Å¿ay Å¿omething that before has not been touched on concerning them.

Setting Wall-trees.Â§. 1. Make a Trench by the Wall-Å¿ide you are to Å¿et them up to, about two Foot broad, and as deep, and in every place where a Tree is to be Å¿et, about a yard Å¿quare, mingle good old rotten Neats-dung with the Earth, and fill it up near as high as you intend the Borders to be, and when you have filled it up about half full, tread it down; but if you deÅ¿ign no Borders, make then only a hole about a yard Å¿quare; but if your Soil be wet, or binding Gravel, or Å¿uch like, very bad in the bottom, go not Å¿o deep, it will be better to Å¿et them Å¿hallow, and raiÅ¿e the Earth about them. Try by Å¿etting the Tree in the hole which Å¿ide will Å¿tand beÅ¿t to the Wall, and then cut off Å¿uch Branches as grow directly toward, and fromward the Wall, leaving
only the Å¿ide-Branches to be nail'd unto it; then clap your Tree in, placing it as far from the Wall as the top will allow, that muÅ¿t be Å¿pread upon it, that the Roots may have the more liberty to Å¿pread towards the Wall, fill up the hole with the Mold, and obÅ¿erve the Directions given at Chap. 9. Sect. 10. and 11. about Å¿etting Trees in all other things.

Summer pruning of Wall-trees.Â§. 2. Every year it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Prune and nail them to the Wall, twice or thrice according as they grow more or leÅ¿s; FirÅ¿t in Summer about the end of June or middle of July. Cut off Å¿uch as grow directly out-ward cloÅ¿e to the body; if you cut a part of any Branch off, do it at a Bud, that the Cut may be cover'd with a freÅ¿h Sprig; Å¿ome muÅ¿t be Cut off, and others Å¿pread to the Wall; Cut off thoÅ¿e that will not Å¿pread to the Wall, and pluck not off the Leaves of the others.

Cutting off the Å¿mall Branches in Summer, is Å¿ome check to the Sap, and hinders its exceÅ¿Å¿ive riÅ¿ing at that time, which elÅ¿e would Å¿pend it Å¿elf in larg and Å¿uperfluous Branches, and Å¿o rob the fruit.
Lay none a croÅ¿s or under one another, but let them Å¿pread as the fingers of your hand when expanded.

The Winter Pruning.Â§. 3. The Winter Pruning may be done as Å¿oon as the Leaves and Fruit are fallen,
or any time before February, except Nectarin's and Peaches, which are apt to dye if Prun'd before the Sap riÅ¿e; the beÅ¿t time to Prune them is after they Flower.

The Winter Pruning is chiefly for the well ordering of the Branches, that could not be well placed in Summer time, and for the Cutting off great Branches when need is. PreÅ¿erve Branches as low, and as near the Ground as may be, and cauÅ¿e them to bend and grow Å¿traight along the Å¿ides of the Wall both ways, and Å¿uffer not the biggeÅ¿t Branches to riÅ¿e Å¿traight upward, but nail them down-wards, to furniÅ¿h the bottom of the Wall. Be Å¿ure to take off thoÅ¿e that grow the Å¿traighteÅ¿t out, and will not be bowed cloÅ¿e to the Wall. And ObÅ¿erve to bend down the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Shoots (that would grow upwards) towards the Å¿ides, otherwiÅ¿e they will be apt to run Å¿traight upward and not cover the Å¿pace you deÅ¿ign for them, and by their Luxurious growth will extreamly rob the Å¿ide-Branches of their nouriÅ¿hment; there will Branches enough Å¿pring out freÅ¿h to run upwards out of them, when they are Å¿o bowed.

ThoÅ¿e that Å¿uffer all the young and larg Shoots, to grow as much as they will all Summer, without Cutting, and then in Winter Cut all or moÅ¿t of them quite off from the Trees, and preÅ¿erve only the old Å¿tumps, or biggeÅ¿t Branches of the Tree,
do commit a great errour; becauÅ¿e thereby in the middle part of the Tree, and near the Root, few or no young Branches will be Å¿een, whereas they Å¿hould preÅ¿erve all the young Branches to Å¿pread up againÅ¿t the Wall untill it be full of Å¿mall Boughs, and then Å¿ome young Shoots every year may be Cut off.
Shreads of Woollen Cloath are the beÅ¿t things to nail them up with; Å¿ome uÅ¿e gentle Leather, or the Cuttings of any old Hat, any of theÅ¿e may Å¿erve the turn.

To renew Old TreesÂ§. 4. When your Wall-Trees are grown old and full of big Wood, you may in three or four years time renew them, by Cutting out Å¿ome of the biggeÅ¿t Stems or Boughs yearly, cutting each Branch off at Å¿ome Å¿mall twig (if it may be) that either it, or a freÅ¿h Branch may grow over the cut place, which muÅ¿t be kept cover'd with Clay, and Å¿o go on yearly till all the big Wood is cut out. Or if you diÅ¿like the kind of Fruit, you may Inoculate or Graft the Boughs with a better Å¿ort of Fruit, but not all in one year, but Å¿ome in one year, and Å¿ome in another.

By either of theÅ¿e ways you may renew a decaying Tree, and keep your Wall almoÅ¿t Å¿till furniÅ¿hed, with leÅ¿s trouble and charge, or loÅ¿s of Time, than by taking up the old one, and Planting a young one in its Å¿tead.

Setting Fruit proper for each Wall.Â§. 5. In furniÅ¿hing your Walls with Fruit-Trees, ObÅ¿erve always to Plant Peaches and Nectarines up to the Wall that is moÅ¿t Southward; the EaÅ¿t-Wall is to be allotted to Apricocks, early Cherries, and the choiceÅ¿t Plums; the WeÅ¿t may be Å¿et with Pears, Cherries, and Plums. Some of the courÅ¿eÅ¿t Pears and Plums, you may Å¿et to the North-Wall, both to cover the Wall handÅ¿omely, and many years they will bear as well on it, as on Standards; eÅ¿pecially if your Wall Å¿tand not directly North, but Å¿o as to have Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable benefit of the Sun, Nut-Trees likewiÅ¿e are proper for this Wall, and will proÅ¿per well up to it.

If your conveniencies will allow it, and you are to build a new Wall, it is much better to have your Garden Walls not Å¿tand directly towards the four points, than otherwiÅ¿e, and then the worÅ¿t Wall will be much better, and the beÅ¿t good enough for your purpoÅ¿e.

As thus, the EaÅ¿t-Wall to incline to the South; the South-Wall to the WeÅ¿t, the WeÅ¿t-Wall to the North; the North to the EaÅ¿t; or contrary, but not Å¿o well: In the firÅ¿t way the two firÅ¿t Walls will be extraordinary good, and the two later good enough for Ordinary Fruit.

How to build a new Wall for Fruit-trees.Â§. 6. In building a new Wall it would be very advantagious to make it with half-Rounds, each Å¿emicricle being eight yards round in the inÅ¿ide, and about Å¿ix yards in
the face, or diameter, each taking two Trees; and betwixt every half-Round let there be two Foot breadth of plain and direct Walling, where you may place a Flower-pot on a Pillar two Foot high, or Plant a Vine to run up it, which every Summer, you may let Å¿pread it Å¿elf a little into the half-Rounds on each Å¿ide it.
One in a cold Countrey having his Garden-Walls thus made, had his Trees bear Fruit plentifully in Å¿uch years as his Neighbours generally fail.
In Å¿ome places Walls are thus made for raiÅ¿ing Melons under, by a pattern and directions from Italy.

Grapes ripen delicately on every Å¿ide the CluÅ¿ter that grow in a half-Round. By means of theÅ¿e Rounds, every Wall will one time of the day or other, have a Å¿hare of the Sun, and the beÅ¿t Walls (by reaÅ¿on of Å¿uch a Reflection, and Collection of the Sun-beams as will be in every Round) will be exceeding hot, and the Trees be more Å¿ecure from Winds.

A Pale is as good for this purpoÅ¿e, and in reÅ¿pect of Ripening Fruit better than any thing elÅ¿e; it can be raiÅ¿ed up too, if the Pale be made of Å¿awed Boards, nine or ten Foot high, and exactly joined, that no wind may come through; next to this in goodneÅ¿s is a Brick-Wall, and then a Stone-Wall; and the worÅ¿t of all that which is made of Tymber and Morter; but in this
every one cannot be his own chooÅ¿er, but muÅ¿t comply with what the Countrey he lives in will permit him to do for his beÅ¿t Convenience.

Baring the Roots of Wall-trees.Â§. 7. Sometime in the Winter after two or three years growth, if the Soil the Roots are to Å¿pread into be not rich enough, open the Ground at the outÅ¿ide of the holes you made at Å¿etting, as near round about as the Wall will permit; if you find no Roots bare, let it lye open a Month, and then fill it up with the Earth that came forth well mixt with Å¿uch a Manure as Å¿uits with it.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of Trees of low Stature and Growth, commonly call'd Dwarf-Trees.
div.p: Â§. 1. DWarf-Trees have been of late more than ordinarily valued and coveted; becauÅ¿e they are of great advantage for Table-Fruit (whether Pears, Apples, Plums, or Cherries) and being but of low Statute may be conveniently Planted for Walks, and in the border of Garden-Walks, without prejudicing any thing elÅ¿e about them, and their Fruit will be as well Å¿ecured, and commodious for gathering as the Wall-fruit.
Stocks for Dwarf Pear-trees.Â§. 2. Plants for this purpoÅ¿e muÅ¿t be provided, and prepared Å¿omewhat differently from thoÅ¿e for Orchards, or Fields.

The Quince-tree is generally uÅ¿ed, and beÅ¿t for Stocks for Pears both for Dwarfs and Wall, as well becauÅ¿e it may poÅ¿Å¿ibly Å¿omewhat meliorate the Pear as (and that chiefly) becauÅ¿e it groweth not to that bigneÅ¿s as on a Pear-Å¿tock it would be apt to do.

Stocks for Dwarf Apple-trees.Â§. 3. For Dwarf Apple-Trees the beÅ¿t Stocks are Å¿uch as are raiÅ¿ed of the Cuttings of other Apple-Trees that will grow by Cuttings, as of the Gennet-Moil, KentiÅ¿h-Codling and others.

That theÅ¿e are more proper for Dwarf-trees than CrabÅ¿tocks appears.
1. BecauÅ¿e the Fruit will be rather better'd and not tainted with any aÅ¿perity or RoughneÅ¿s, as poÅ¿Å¿ibly it might be, if CrabÅ¿tocks were made uÅ¿e of; and one chief deÅ¿ign in theÅ¿e Trees is to have choice and delicious Fruit for eating.
2. Apple-Trees that are raiÅ¿ed on Å¿uch Stocks will not grow Å¿o big as thoÅ¿e on CrabÅ¿tocks, but are with eaÅ¿e and certainty kept Dwarfs. Mr. Rea judging the ParadiÅ¿e-Apple of Å¿omewhat Å¿low growth in bringing forward a Cyen, adviÅ¿es to Graff a ParadiÅ¿e on a CrabÅ¿tock, and the Fruit you would have, on that ParadiÅ¿e, that the Crab might yield plenty of Juice or Sap to the ParadiÅ¿e, and the ParadiÅ¿e retard the growth of the Apple Planted on it, Å¿o as to keep it a Dwarf; but beÅ¿ides loÅ¿s of time the Å¿ucceÅ¿s of this is doubted, becauÅ¿e the Crab will put forth Å¿trong Roots, and yield plenty of nouriÅ¿hment; for why Apple-Trees raiÅ¿ed of Cuttings grow not to be very large Trees, is their putting forth Å¿uch Å¿mall Roots, by which means the Tree hath Sap conveyed to it accordingly.
3. By uÅ¿ing theÅ¿e Cuttings for Stocks you Å¿hall get at leaÅ¿t four years time, reckoning from
Sowing the Crab-Kernel, and the Å¿etting the Stem or Cutting be duly conÅ¿ider'd, as by Å¿etting the Stem in the place you intend the Dwarf-Tree Å¿hall grow, and Å¿etting it in good Earth, for then after one years growth, you may Graft it, and you will eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cern the advantage in point of time.

If it be Å¿aid Crab-Å¿tocks ready grown may be made uÅ¿e of inÅ¿tead of Cuttings, There's readily anÅ¿wer'd, they muÅ¿t grow two, if not three years after they are Å¿et before they are fit to Graft, and in reÅ¿pect of their large growth will not be fit for Dwarfs.

Some NurÅ¿ery-men have made advantage to themÅ¿elves by this Å¿peedy way of raiÅ¿ing Trees by Cuttings, but to the diÅ¿advantage of them they put them off to, for Planting in Orchards; becauÅ¿e they are never like to make large or long-laÅ¿ting-Trees.
Â§. 4. The way then to provide Stocks for Apple-Dwarfs is thus;

How to provide Stocks for Apple-Dwarfs.In October from Å¿uch Trees whoÅ¿e Cuttings will grow, take Å¿uch Stems, or Branches that grow Å¿traighteÅ¿t, and which (in the place where they Å¿hall be Grafted) are an Inch or more thick, if they be near two Inches Å¿o much the better; Cut them off if you can, an hands breadth below Å¿uch Knots or Burs as are on them (for at thoÅ¿e Burs
they principally put forth their Roots) and cut off the top that they be not above a yard long, (if you cannot get them Å¿o long) of Quinces, you muÅ¿t be content with Å¿horter, if they be two foot it may do reaÅ¿onable well; Cut off alÅ¿o all the Å¿ide-Branches cloÅ¿e to the body, except one Å¿mall Twig near to the top, for the Sap to vent it Å¿elf at; Å¿et theÅ¿e preÅ¿ently in Beds as your Seed-plants were, or rather if your Garden be laid out, (that you can know the places they Å¿hall Å¿tand in) Å¿et them there.

You need not fear Å¿etting theÅ¿e as deep as the length will bear, Å¿o that there be of them about a Foot above Ground, becauÅ¿e they will Å¿hoot out Roots all along, almoÅ¿t to the top of the Ground, and Å¿o Å¿pread their Roots in the good Soil, and by Å¿etting them Å¿omething deep, they are in leÅ¿s danger of Dying, and this prevents the trouble of covering the Ground about them with Fern or Straw; and by this means likewiÅ¿e they will Å¿tand the firmer in the looÅ¿e Garden-land for Grafting at a years end, and better Å¿upport a Å¿preading top afterwards.

Stocks by CircumpoÅ¿ition.Â§. 5. But becauÅ¿e its hard to meet with great plenty of Å¿uch Branches, thus to be cut and Å¿et for Stocks, that have Burs or knots on them; Planters have therefore found out a way (which is called CircumpoÅ¿ition) to bring theÅ¿e knots or Burs upon
Branches, that had them not before, and to mend and improve thoÅ¿e that before had them, and the way of it is as followeth.

About the beginning of February next before you deÅ¿ign to cut theÅ¿e Stems, directly above the place you intend to cut them off at, for above a Foot in length, faÅ¿ten about them Å¿ome Earth in an Old Hat, or Boot, or Bag made of Å¿ome Å¿trong Cloth: and in that Earth they will have put forth Roots againÅ¿t the Octob. following, when you are to cut them off to Å¿et them.

Or (which is a quicker and readier way) you may dawb Å¿ome wet Earth or Clay about the place, and wrap a Hay-band about it, putting Å¿ome moiÅ¿t Earth likewiÅ¿e betwixt the rounds of the Band, and then running it about again over the Å¿paces betwixt thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t rounds of the Hay-band, and making faÅ¿t the ends of it.

If the Stem have no Bur, before you go either of theÅ¿e ways to work, then take off here and there a little Å¿lice of Bark, about an Inch long round about it, near the middle of the place to be cover'd, as hath been directed.

But to proceed to the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s in hand, you have Å¿een the way of preparing Cuttings by CircumpoÅ¿ition; and though Å¿ome will pretend to raiÅ¿e Trees of any kind by the uÅ¿e of it, yet it's certain it avails not, but only in Å¿uch as by a peculiar property are apt to put forth Roots, being cut off and Å¿et into the Ground, and thoÅ¿e generally known and made uÅ¿e of this way, are the KentiÅ¿h Codling, the Gennet-Moil, Å¿ome Å¿orts of Å¿weet Apples, and BitterÅ¿weets, the Quince-tree, the Mulberry-tree, Goodsberry-trees, Curran-trees, and the ParadiÅ¿e Apple-tree, which laÅ¿t is much commended by Mr. Rea, for to raiÅ¿e Stcocks for Dwarf Apple-trees.

To raiÅ¿e Stocks by cutting down an old Tree.Â§. 6. Another way to raiÅ¿e Stocks for Dwarf-trees is, to cut down Å¿ome one Tree of little worth, of Å¿uch a kind as you want Stocks of, about a Foot or more from the ground: This will make Å¿ome kind of Trees very apt to caÅ¿t forth very good Suckers from the old Roots; Å¿uch as are of two years growth may be tranÅ¿planted; and the Å¿tump above ground, will alÅ¿o put forth abundance of young Shoots: after
theÅ¿e young Shoots have grown out of the Stump one year, caÅ¿t Mold or Earth about them a good height, Å¿o that you cover not the Tops of any of them, where let them grow two years more, and they will be well rooted, then cut them off from the old Stock (which after that may yield freÅ¿h ones again) and Å¿et the Shoots you take off as before hath been directed about Cuttings.

TheÅ¿e will be about three years longer before they be ready to Graft than Cuttings, but will be very good young freÅ¿h Stocks, and is a good way to raiÅ¿e Stocks of the Quince-tree for Pears, becauÅ¿e Quince-trees generally grow Å¿o crooked and irregular, that its difficult to procure any conÅ¿iderable quantity of them by Cuttings.

If they Å¿hoot up tall after they are molded, you had beÅ¿t top them at a convenient height; it will make them grow the more in bigneÅ¿s and Å¿o be Å¿ooner fit to Graft. But if you have a deÅ¿ire to have any of the Å¿ame kind as the old Tree was, you need not top them.
And by this means if you want Quince-trees, Codlings, &c. you may be furniÅ¿hed with plenty, that will make better and handÅ¿omer Trees than if you raiÅ¿e them by Cuttings.

Stocks for Dwarf Pear-trees.Â§. 7. You may raiÅ¿e Stocks for Dwarf Pear-trees from Suckers of Old Pear-trees (if you cannot conveniently get enough of
the Quince-tree) for many Pear-trees caÅ¿t them naturally, which being preÅ¿erved from Cattle, may be taken up and Å¿et in Beds of Earth as you did the Seedlings.

If your Pear-trees yield not Suckers of themÅ¿elves, you need only cut off the top of Å¿ome old ill Pear-tree (and Graff it with a better Fruit if you pleaÅ¿e) and the Roots will caÅ¿t forth Suckers plentifully, and you may help them by making a Å¿mall Ditch or Gutter Å¿o as to bear Å¿ome of the Roots about two yards diÅ¿tant from the Tree, or pare off the GraÅ¿s (if any grow about the Tree) that they may have the more liberty to Å¿pring up.

Or in this caÅ¿e you may bare the Roots, and then give a Cut croÅ¿s Å¿ome Roots almoÅ¿t to the Heart, and from the croÅ¿s Cut cleave the Root, raiÅ¿ing up the looÅ¿e part, and put in a little Stone to keep it open; cover it three Inches over with Mold; let this be done if you can, where you find a Bud or Eye on the Root for the Sucker to Shoot out at, and either inoculate the young Shoot in the place where it Å¿tands, or remove it to Å¿ome other place after a years growth, and when you do, cut off with it about a Foot of the old Root; and by this means you may have Suckers from Å¿ome other Trees, that do not naturally yield them.

Stock for Dwarf-Cherry and Plum-trees.Â§. 8. To have Stocks for Dwarf Cherries, and Plums, or for Å¿uch Trees for a Wall, the Å¿peedieÅ¿t way, and Å¿uch as will Å¿ucceed for that purpoÅ¿e, is by Suckers of the common red Cherry, and any ordinary, or rather white Plum-tree, both which caÅ¿t up Suckers plentifully.

If the Suckers grow in a place Å¿ecure from harm, you may inoculate, or Graft them before removal, under their mother Plant, and let them grow there one year after: and thereby you'l gain a years time and more; and chooÅ¿e Å¿uch Suckers as grow at greateÅ¿t diÅ¿tance from the old Tree.

How to order the heads of Dwarf-trees.Â§. 9. In Grafting or inoculating Stocks for Dwarf-trees, obÅ¿erve to do it as low as you well can, with two Cyens placed on each Stock, and thoÅ¿e longer than in Grafting for large Standards that they may Å¿pread from the Ground.

And after they are grown two or three years in the places they are to Å¿tand in, to make them Å¿pread, and to keep the Boughs outward, you may tye an old Hoop of a Barrel, or Å¿ome Å¿uch thing in the midd'Å¿t of the Branches, to bear them a good diÅ¿tance one from another; but if one Branch be much Å¿tronger, or more inclined to grow upright than the reÅ¿t, then you
may drive a Stake into the Ground, and tye the Å¿turdy one down to it.

If you Cut the Bark croÅ¿Å¿wiÅ¿e in Å¿everal places on the inÅ¿ide of the Branches, when they are placed as you would have them, it will be a means to make them more willing to continue in that order of their own accord, after Å¿ome years growth: If any one Branch Å¿hoot out much further than the other, cut off its top to keep it even with the reÅ¿t, and yearly cut much off, eÅ¿pecially new Shoots, that grow directly upwards, after they are grown to that height you deÅ¿ign them to be of,Trees raiÅ¿ed of Cuttings. which may be about a yard and an half.

Â§. 10. Having directed how to raiÅ¿e KentiÅ¿h-Codlings, Gennet-Moils, Quinces, or any that grow of Cuttings for Stocks; there needs no other Rules for raiÅ¿ing Trees, or Hedges of the Å¿ame kind of Fruit, only you need not cut them Å¿o Å¿hort as you do for Stocks.

Codlings Grafted on Crab-Å¿tocks, and Å¿et in a Garden or elÅ¿ewhere will, encreaÅ¿e their growth; becauÅ¿e Crab-Å¿tocks have great Roots, and will yield them more plenty of nouriÅ¿hment than Roots of their own putting forth, when they are raiÅ¿ed only of Cuttings. Others
Graft Gennet-Moils on Crab-Å¿tocks, and they thrive well, and bear a larger and (Å¿ome think) a better Fruit than thoÅ¿e Trees of that kind raiÅ¿ed by Cuttings: Å¿ome have Grafted Å¿everal of them in rough and Woody Grounds, which have grown with very Å¿trong Shoots, and cover'd the Stocks very Å¿oon.

div.head: CHAP. XII. How to Plant in the Fields, with the various advantages thereof.
div.p:
Â§. 1. MUltitudes of Fruit-trees may be Planted abroad in the Fields and Hedges of incloÅ¿ed Grounds, whereof very great profit may be made without any conÅ¿iderable damage either to Corn, Hay, or PaÅ¿ture, and its beÅ¿t in this way to Plant the courÅ¿er, harder, and long-keeping kinds of Fruits, which will not be meanly Å¿erviceable to a Family by uÅ¿ing them either for Baking or Cyder. TheÅ¿e Trees being about Å¿even Foot high before they begin to Å¿pread, will be out of the reach of Cattle, and not troubleÅ¿ome to Workmen about Hay and Corn in Summer-time, if Planted twenty or thirty Yards diÅ¿tant one from another, and in Ranks throughout the Field, that the Plow may continue a Å¿traight Furrow all along from one end to the other, whereby Corn will grow near the Roots of Å¿uch Trees almoÅ¿t as good as any where in the Field, and GraÅ¿s as much or more under Trees as where none are,
tho not altogether Å¿o Å¿weet, by reaÅ¿on of the droppings, yet the multitude of Fruit abundantly compenÅ¿ates the damage almoÅ¿t Ten-fold.

Many Countries in England have experienced the benefit of Planting in the Fields, where it hath been of long and general uÅ¿age, and in many other Countries Gentlemen have begun already to imitate them, which Å¿hould much encourage others to follow; for the more there are that Plant, the leÅ¿s particular perÅ¿ons will loÅ¿e by Thieves, and where Fruit is in great pleanty, it is found to be more Å¿lighted by Idle people; and beÅ¿ides if a man hath Å¿tore, hee'l not feel the loÅ¿s of a little, or it may quit his coÅ¿t, to have one to caÅ¿t an Eye to them, for a months time near ripening; and further yet Cyder-Apples, Baking-Pears, and Pears for Perry are Å¿o little grateful to the TaÅ¿t (which Pilferers chiefly aim at pleaÅ¿ing) that he that taÅ¿ts them once, Å¿hall Å¿carcely find his Teeth water after them a Å¿econd time. However the benefit of Planting in Fields much out-weighs theÅ¿e and all other incoveniences; for by this means you may have a double Crop on your Lands, viz. GraÅ¿s or Corn, and your Fruit, and the Land rather beneÅ¿itted (as the matter may be ordered) than damaged; One of theÅ¿e Trees alÅ¿o bears as much Fruit as three of the beÅ¿t in a thick-planted Orchard, the benefit
whereof for Sale or uÅ¿e in a Family for Baking, or Liquors, or other uÅ¿es, is known to be Å¿o very conÅ¿iderable, that it's needleÅ¿s to Å¿ay more of it.

Encouragements to Plant Peartrees in Fields.Â§. 2. BecauÅ¿e the Planting Pear-trees abroad in Fields is of leÅ¿s reputation generally than the Planting other Fruit-trees, to take off the aÅ¿perÅ¿ion, conÅ¿ider the following Å¿uggeÅ¿tions.

list.item: FirÅ¿t Å¿ome Pears do not make Å¿o contemptible a Liquor as Perry is commonly reckon'd, but very Å¿trong, and kept two or three years, drinks to admiration, Å¿o that Å¿everal good Palates that have drank of it, have not been able to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h it well from Liquors of more eÅ¿teem.
Secondly, Their Fruit is not eatable and Å¿o in leÅ¿s danger of Thieves in your out-grounds than Apples are.
Thirdly, They will grow on barren Land where Apples will not proÅ¿per Å¿o well.

Fourthly, They are Trees of long continuance, and often grow to that bigneÅ¿s, and bear Å¿o plentifully, that one Å¿ingle Tree will bear Fruit enough to make a HogÅ¿head of Perry, Å¿ometimes two, or three in one year, which would Å¿ave the expence of much Malt, tho the Liquor were but mean.

div.p:
There are Å¿everal ways of Planting in the Fields, all which are here Å¿et down,
that every man may uÅ¿e that which Å¿uits beÅ¿t with his conveniency and good likeing.

Â§. 3. If your Land be in tillage, you may Å¿et Fruit-trees at thirty Yards diÅ¿tance from one another,How to Plantwhole Fields. throughout the whole Fields, in Å¿traight and direct Rows, after the manner of an Orchard, and you may go on with your Plowing with the loÅ¿s only of about a yard, or four Foot Square of Land about every Tree for twenty years at leaÅ¿t, and when they are grown Å¿o big, that you think your Corn receives hurt by the Å¿hade or droppings of the Trees, if you can turn it to paÅ¿ture, the Trees will improve moÅ¿t kind of Land, by keeping it warm in the Spring, they will make the GraÅ¿s come and grow more early, and by Shades in the Summer preÅ¿erve it from burning; but the Trees being Å¿et at Å¿uch a diÅ¿tance, the Land may continue for any purpoÅ¿e for ever, if you dreÅ¿s or Prune theÅ¿e Trees higher up than any other, that no Boughs may hang in the reach of Cattle, and for convenience of going about them with your Team to any work, and thereby the Air and Rain will have free acceÅ¿s to the GraÅ¿s, or Grain near about them, and the Fruit will be Å¿afer from common Pilferers. TheÅ¿e need no other fencing than Thorns bound about them, and a Stake driven in the midÅ¿t to keep them from Å¿haking; becauÅ¿e you may receive the proÅ¿it of the
Stubble or Fallow without Å¿uffering any large Cattle to come into the Ground, that will browÅ¿e upon them.

Â§. 4. Another way of Planting Fruit-trees in Fields is by Å¿etting Walks of them,How to Plant Walks of Fruit-trees in Fields. running through the midÅ¿t, or along the Å¿ides of your PaÅ¿ture-grounds, where you have a mind to have Walks for ornament, or Å¿hady: for why Walks of Fruit-trees Å¿hould not be rather Planted than of Elm, Sycamores, AÅ¿h-trees, &c. none can pretend a reaÅ¿on, there being Å¿ome Å¿orts of Fruit-trees that will (and almoÅ¿t any kind may be ordered Å¿o as to) grow very handÅ¿ome in Å¿hape, beÅ¿ides the beauty and Å¿weet Å¿mell of the BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and worth of the Fruit.

To prevent damage by Cattle, if you go this way to work in Field Planting, they muÅ¿t be well grown before you Å¿et them, that is, they muÅ¿t be of about Å¿ix years growth, and then well fenced, and there are two ways uÅ¿ed to Å¿ave them harmleÅ¿s. 1. One much commended is by Tumping them,To Å¿et Trees by Tumping. and it's performed thus, viz. Å¿et your Trees in the place deÅ¿igned on the top, or almoÅ¿t on the top of the Ground, no deeper than to make it Å¿tand, tho all the Roots be not cover'd, till the Tump or Mound be raiÅ¿ed about it; and then take a line about a yard and quarter long, tye the one end of it about the Tree, but Å¿o
that in going round the Tree with the Line Å¿train'd, it may Å¿lip about the Tree as you go; faÅ¿ten the other end to an Iron Å¿etter or Å¿tick with a Å¿harp point, and as you go round the Tree, mark the Ground; Make then a Ditch on the out-Å¿ide of the round Score, and lay the Turf handÅ¿omly two or three heights, with the GraÅ¿s-Å¿ide outward Å¿o as to make the work full half a yard, or two Foot high; then caÅ¿t the Mold out of the Ditch, obÅ¿erving to throw the beÅ¿t of it next the Roots of the Tree, till you have raiÅ¿ed it within as high as the Turf; then prick Å¿trong Thorns into the Mold, that they may lye upon the Turf, and point outwards a yard over the Turf; as you place the Thorns, put more Turf or faÅ¿t heavy Earth out of the Ditch upon the ends of them, treading it down the better to fix them, and lay the Earth Å¿helving down from the Turf towards the Tree, that if Rain fall it may Å¿oke towards the Roots; if you have any Å¿mall Thorns, Bryars, Furs, or GorÅ¿e, lay it one the top of the work finiÅ¿hed, round the Tree and repair all yearly as you Å¿ee cauÅ¿e, which may be done with Å¿mall trouble. The following obÅ¿ervations will demonÅ¿trate the great convenience of Å¿etting Fruit-trees this way.

FirÅ¿t if your Land be over moiÅ¿t this Ditch will drain all wet from the Roots of the Tree; but if the Land be Clay or
Å¿uch that the Water will Å¿tand in, then when you perceive it (which is very rarely) cut Å¿ome little Notch or Trench to let it out.

Secondly, This way of Å¿etting is commended in dry Land; becauÅ¿e the Earth of the Mound will Å¿ecure the Roots from the heat of the Sun, and every Å¿hower of Rain will much refreÅ¿h it, by Å¿oaking towards the Tree.
Thirdly, You need not bind your Tree to a Å¿take which doth often gall and Hurt the Tree, for Å¿o much Earth about it will keep it Å¿teady,

Fourthly, If your Land be Å¿tiff, or Å¿trong old Land, the Mound made of it will mellow and improve about the Roots, and alÅ¿o by that time the Roots Å¿pread as far as the Ditch, it will be fill'd up with Mold fallen from the Tump, and with Å¿ticks, Leaves, &c. which will be rotten, looÅ¿e, and good for Trees to Root in, and by that time they will need little or no defence, if any at all; A few Thorns tyed about the bodies of the Trees, to keep Cattle from rubbing againÅ¿t them will be enough.

Fifthly, The Chief benefit of Å¿etting Trees thus, is, that where the Soil is Å¿omewhat too moiÅ¿t or Å¿hallow, the Tree being Å¿et on the top of the Land, will put forth it's Roots plentifully into the Earth caÅ¿t
up, and thence Å¿hoot into the upper Turf and beÅ¿t Land that hath been Plowed and manured before.

Another way of Fencing is, by erecting at a Foot and a half diÅ¿tance one from another, about every Tree three Å¿mall PoÅ¿ts, (if they be Å¿awed they need be but three Inches Å¿quare) or you may uÅ¿e Poles, or Å¿traight Boughs, either whole, or if big enough, cloven in two, three or four parts, about five Foot above the Ground in height, being driven into the Ground, nail a croÅ¿s Bar of Wood from each to other, within a Hand's breadth of the tops of the PoÅ¿ts, to which Bar, nail a Pale or two betwixt each two PoÅ¿ts, Å¿tuck into the Ground or nail'd to the like CroÅ¿s Bat within a Foot of the bottom of the PoÅ¿ts; the way of it may be Å¿een now in diverÅ¿e places, and learn't in a Minute; though what's Å¿aid here makes it plain enough.

This way is more chargable than Tumping, where Timber is Å¿carce, but much more dureable than it, and abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary where Deer, or Rabbets, or any thing that peels the Bark off, come into the Land Planted.

Planting near Hedges in the Fields.Â§. 5. Another way of Planting in Fields which hath been Å¿ucceÅ¿sfully PractiÅ¿ed, is thus; When you Å¿cour a Ditch, and cut down or plaiÅ¿h an old QuickÅ¿et-Hedg, then Å¿et a row of Trees within a yard of the Hedg
on that Å¿ide that is not Ditch't, and Fence them with half-Round Tumps only on the one Å¿ide, for the Hedg will Å¿ecure them on the other, and from the cut or plaiÅ¿h't Hedg, you will commonly have Thorns and Bryars enough for the Mounds, to Fence it as hath been before directed; and at the Å¿ame time, or in Summer, draw Å¿ome of the Quickthorns, Hips, or Bryars, from the Hedg in o the Fence, about the Tump which will contribute to the Å¿trengthening and preÅ¿erving the dead fence you had made about it before; Å¿o that you may be free from trouble about it for ever after.
There are theÅ¿e advantages in this way of Planting, viz.

list.item: 1. The Ditch on the out-Å¿ide the Hedg drains the Ground and makes it healthful and Å¿ound.

2. The Ground near the Hedg is commonly very Rich, as not having been impoveriÅ¿hed by Tillage, but improved Å¿ometimes by the often Å¿couring of the Ditch, and commonly with the Dung of Cattle, that for Å¿helter, Shade or Fodder repair thither.
3. Its not the leaÅ¿t hindrance to Plowing or GraÅ¿s; for the Hedg when its grown up, uÅ¿ually beareth out as far as the Tree is Å¿et in the Field.
