4. And this is much better than Planting in the Hedg Row, as many do; for in
a large top its apter to weaken the Hedg under it, but theÅ¿e being Å¿et a little diÅ¿tance from the Hedg, and growing (as they will) with the greateÅ¿t part of their Heads from it, will not damage it.
5. The Fruit may be gathered with much more eaÅ¿e, than of thoÅ¿e that are Planted in the Hedges.
6. They will not be choak't or hurt by the Hedg when its grown up, but be good handÅ¿ome fair Trees.

div.p: You may Å¿et theÅ¿e at eight yards diÅ¿tance, or nearer, being but one Å¿ingle Row, and Å¿o if but half a Field (as uÅ¿ually it falls out) have the Ditch on the out-Å¿ide, you may Å¿et a conÅ¿iderable number, and find advantage without damage, and with inconÅ¿iderable charge, eÅ¿pecially if the Ditch Å¿tand on the North-Å¿ide, if you can, therefore chooÅ¿e Å¿uch Hedges.

This is not to be practiÅ¿ed near Hedges that are full of great Wood, or Trees; but if there be but few Trees, its but leaving a vacancy near Å¿uch Trees, and Å¿etting your Fruit-trees againÅ¿t Å¿uch places, where there grow none in the Hedg.

How to Plant in Hedges is the Fields.Â§. 6. Another way of Planting in Fields is this, if you would Plant without any charge of Fencing, you may do it in your Hedges; theÅ¿e Trees muÅ¿t be well grown and Å¿trong, that the Hedg choak them not while they are young: and when you
plaiÅ¿h or cut down a Quick Hedg, obÅ¿erve no certain diÅ¿tance, but as it happens where you find it moÅ¿t free from Quick, Å¿et a Tree and incloÅ¿e the Body in the Hedg, but bind not the Etherings too cloÅ¿e about it, leÅ¿t they gall and fret it, and as it groweth obÅ¿erve what Thorns annoy it, and cut them off.

Planting by the Cuttings of Gennet-Moils, &c.Â§. 7. If you have a mind to Å¿et any Cuttings of Codlings, Gennet-Moils, or other Apple-trees that grow of Cuttings, they will proÅ¿per very well in, or rather near a Hedg, becauÅ¿e generally there the Mold is looÅ¿e and mellow for them to put forth Roots in, and Å¿omewhat enrich't by the frequent cleanÅ¿ing of the Ditch; if you Plant them near the Hedg, you muÅ¿t a little Fence them on the one Å¿ide, as by the third foregoing direction; but the Tumps you raiÅ¿e to Å¿et the Thorns in, muÅ¿t not be above a Foot high, for the Cuttings will Å¿hoot out their Roots, almoÅ¿t to the top of the Earth about them, and a high Mound falling down by degrees, Å¿ome of the beÅ¿t Roots may be left bare, or very little Earth upon them.
The way of preparing Plants for this purpoÅ¿e, is by CircumpoÅ¿ition, &c. as is directed in the 11 Chap. of Dwarf-trees.

Make choice of Cuttings or Stems as big as a Mans wriÅ¿t (if you can) towards the lower end; before you Å¿et them, prune
them out of the reach of Cattle, and leave but little top on them when you Å¿et them, neither let them be very long; if the tops be out of the reach of the Cattle its enough.

Planting in Fields by long Crab-tree Stocks.Â§. 8. There be Å¿ome that get long Crab-tree-Å¿tocks out of Woods, or elÅ¿e dreÅ¿s Å¿ome up in their NurÅ¿eries to grow tall, and Å¿et them in their Fields or Hedges, and at three years Å¿tanding Graft them, which may do well and is better approved of, becauÅ¿e there needs no removal after they are Grafted (which is of great advantage as to make both good-bearing and Å¿ound Trees) but Å¿ome inconvenience there is in this way: the long Stocks out of Woods being commonly very old, their Bark thick, their Roots big, they thrive but indifferently; and thoÅ¿e raiÅ¿ed in NurÅ¿eries will Å¿eldom be taper grown, or Å¿trong enough to bear a large top well, after they are Grafted Å¿o high as they ought, being Å¿et in Fields: You will alÅ¿o be longer in raiÅ¿ing Stocks to that height, and any conÅ¿iderable Å¿trength (as is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for this purpoÅ¿e) than in raiÅ¿ing Trees, if your Stocks be Grafted young in your NurÅ¿ery, becauÅ¿e they thrive more after Grafting than before; and in both CaÅ¿es if you Graft them high, the Stocks will be continually putting out Å¿prouts of their own kind below the place they are Grafted at, which will
require frequent cutting off; if you Graft them not very high you will find it difficult to defend them from the nipping of Cattle, and from the Cyens being broke out of the Stocks by Å¿ome caÅ¿ualties or other, to which they are more expoÅ¿ed in Fields that lye common to Cattle, than NurÅ¿eries that are incloÅ¿ed.

Planting in Fields by Gra â¢ ting old Crab-treeÅ¿tocks.Â§. 9. The way moÅ¿t uÅ¿ed in Planting-Countries is by Grafting Å¿uch Crab-trees as grow in the Hedges or Grounds, and this is the Å¿peedieÅ¿t way to have Fruit; becauÅ¿e the big Trees have Bodies already, and in four or five years time (well ordered) will have good tops to bear; and if you Graft Å¿mall Stocks in your Ground that have grown of their own accord there, and Fence them, they will Å¿peedily bring on Grafts, being Å¿o well Rooted.

The miÅ¿chi â¢ f of Grafting the bodies of old Trees.Â§. 10. Many cut off the tops of old Crab-trees, or Apple-trees, and Graft the body or Trunk, but the Cyens could never cover the Heads of thoÅ¿e Stocks, and by that time the top was a little grown up, the body was ready to periÅ¿h with rottenneÅ¿s. The beÅ¿t way for big Crabtrees (or if you would change the kind of any Fruit-trees) is to Graft them in the Boughs, where they are not bigger than a Mans Arm, making uÅ¿e of none but thoÅ¿e that grow handÅ¿ome at convenient diÅ¿tance one from
another, cutting off the others Å¿mooth and even, cloÅ¿e to the Body of the Tree.

To do this, that Winter that you cut or plaiÅ¿h a Hedg, order the Workmen to trim up, but not to lop or top the Crab-trees, unleÅ¿s it be the tops of the Boughs two Foot above the place you intend to Graft them at, and then in March following Å¿aw off the Heads at proper places and Graft them.

Of Grafting old Trees in the Cleft.Â§. 11. Many are for Grafting theÅ¿e in the Cleft; becauÅ¿e they think the Cyen hath beÅ¿t hold, and will not be Å¿o Å¿ubject to be broke off, or out, by the Wind, as thoÅ¿e Grafted in the Bark; but many times thoÅ¿e in the Cleft are broke out by the Wind, neither can you perceive that the Wood of the Cyen in the Cleft did ever cement with the Wood of the Stock, but only on the outÅ¿ide as the others do: And thoÅ¿e in the Cleft are not Å¿o apt to grow all of them, nor to make Å¿o great a growth as thoÅ¿e in the Bark, which with a little warineÅ¿s may be preÅ¿erved from danger of the Wind, and full as much care muÅ¿t be had about thoÅ¿e Grafted in the Cleft, if you will preÅ¿erve them all from the Å¿ame prejudice.

How to Graft old Trees.Â§. 12. You may obÅ¿erve the following difference in Grafting theÅ¿e great Foughs from all the forementioned varieties of
Grafting, and look upon it as a thing well worthy to be taken notice of and obÅ¿erved.

When you have prepared the Cyen as you are directed to do when you Graft in the Bark, apply it to the place you deÅ¿ign to put it in, and Å¿lit the Bark of the Bough through on both Å¿ides the Cyen cloÅ¿e to it, beginning at the top of the Bough, and not carrying the Å¿lits much above half length of the Å¿lope of the Cyen, Å¿eparate that little portion of the Bark between the two Å¿lits, from the Wood with your InÅ¿trument, thruÅ¿ting it a little lower than the Å¿lits, to let in the Cyen as far as it is Å¿loped, and then Å¿tick the Cyen in, having firÅ¿t taken off from the edges of the Cyen any unevenneÅ¿s (not cutting through the Bark) that all may the better fit together, and you may put in two, three, or four Cyens in every head, having reÅ¿pect to the bigneÅ¿s of it; or you may in the biggeÅ¿t put in two Cyens in the Cleft, and two others in the Bark, doing one of the later on the WeÅ¿t-Å¿ide of it, for then the Wind blowing it towards the Head, is not Å¿o apt to break it out, as if it drove it from the head; bind the heads and Clay them as you heard before, and continue to do Å¿o yearly till the heads are almoÅ¿t covered.
At firÅ¿t Claying, Å¿tick in Feathers or long EÅ¿cures, to prevent Birds lighting on the Cyens.

In July following (whether you Graft
theÅ¿e big Stocks in the Cleft or Bark) pick off moÅ¿t of the Leaves of the Cyens, and cut off Å¿uch Å¿prigs as growing inward will make the head thick, and all Å¿tragling out Boughs, that the Wind may not have Å¿o much force upon them to break the Branches out of the Stocks.

Cut off alÅ¿o Å¿ome of the biggeÅ¿t Shoots the Crab-tree puts forth of its own kind; but for the firÅ¿t three years, you muÅ¿t not cut off all, left the Tree not having liberty to vent all the Sap that cometh up, Å¿urfeit and dye, the Å¿mall Grafts not being able to receive near Å¿o much Sap as the old top did the year before.

Thus many Country-men when they take off the head of an old Oak, have Å¿ometimes found it dye, and therefore in Å¿ome Countries, they leave one big Bough to grow for one year to draw up the Sap, (as they term it) whereas it is indeed that the Sap may have liberty to vent it Å¿elf; for Trees that have a thick Bark, as old Oaks have, when all the Å¿mall Boughs are cut off, are long in putting forth Branches; and difficulty at laÅ¿t put forth Å¿o many as will Å¿pend the Sap which comes up the Tree, in Å¿ome proportion to what it did the year before, when the whole top was on, which Sap being chiefly in the greateÅ¿t Channel betwixt or near the Bark and out-Å¿ide of the Body of the Tree, and not being vented, is either dryed or conÅ¿umed by the
heat of the Sun, or putrifies for want of that continual motion that is in it, when it hath vent, that Å¿everal Trees dye of this DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e; and when Trees dye this way the Bark will drop off from the Body of them Å¿ooner by Å¿ome years than otherwiÅ¿e.

Hence it is that you may kill a Tree, by lopping off the whole top in the Summer time, or Å¿o much of it that the remaining Boughs cannot receive all the Sap, but it lyeth choakt up for want of IÅ¿Å¿ue.

The Å¿econd Summer you ought to bind Å¿ome Hay-ropes, about the lower part of the Cyens; there will be no great need of repeating this the third Summer, but if done, it will the more certainly Å¿ecure them from breaking by the Wind.

Thus you may Å¿ecurely and Å¿peedily Graft old Trees, that are either bad Bearers, or bear Fruit of bad kinds, and they will in three or four years hear plentifully, if you take care (which you always ought to do upon any Grafting or inoculating) to Graft them with kinds that experience of your Å¿elf, or others, can faithfully aÅ¿Å¿ure you to be of very good bearing kinds.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of propagating and ordering Vines.
div.p: Soil proper for Vines.Â§. 1. THe beÅ¿t Ground for them is a rich dry, light, Sandy Land, inclinable to Stony or Gravel, Å¿o it bind not; if it incline much to Brambles it's a Å¿ign of apt Ground for this Plant; the richneÅ¿s of the Soil is not altogether Å¿o requiÅ¿ite as the heat and dryneÅ¿s thereof; a Å¿hort Vine full of Knots or Joints is moÅ¿t fruitful, and fitteÅ¿t for our Clymate. Kinds of Vines to be propagated in England Â§ 2. Next be Å¿ure to make choice of Å¿uch Grapes as are moÅ¿t Å¿uitable to the EngliÅ¿h Soil and Clymate, which is more Å¿ubject to nipping FroÅ¿ts and cold blaÅ¿ts than France &c. and our Northern Country much worÅ¿e than the Southern for theÅ¿e Fruits (as well as all other) eÅ¿pecially, are better or worÅ¿e, and bear according to the place they grow in, if they have a proper Soil, be well ordered,
have much Sun, as upon a South-Wall or upon the EaÅ¿t-Wall which is beÅ¿t next, the Fruit will be better and Å¿ooner ripe. And I have read that the Vine that yields Grapes in the Canaries, of which the Sack is made, was tranÅ¿planted from the Rhine in Germany thither, and that it was no other than the RheniÅ¿h-Wine Grape, which agreeing and improving in that Clymate, affords the moÅ¿t delicate Wine, far different from it's parents on the Rhine.

The Å¿mall black Grape, by Å¿ome call'd the CluÅ¿ter-Grape, or Currant-Grape, is the firÅ¿t ripe, beares well, the Bunches are Å¿mall, but the Grapes Å¿o thick that you cannot put a pin between them, and is a very pleaÅ¿ant Å¿weet Grape, and as fit for propagation as any. There is another Å¿ort Å¿o them without Stones.
The next is the Red and White Muskadine, bearing well, large Bunches, and fair Fruit, and ripens in moÅ¿t years againÅ¿t a South-Wall; but the Red is not Å¿o good as the White.

The Red and White Frontin â¢ ac, is a Fruit, of a very pleaÅ¿ant haut-guÅ¿t, where it comes to perfect ripeneÅ¿s, which it Å¿carce does, unleÅ¿s in a hot Summer, and it be Planted againÅ¿t a good South-Wall.
The Black or Red Orleance is a very good Grape, and ripens very well with us.
The great Blue-Grape, is very good Fruit, and ripens well with us.
The Canada, or ParÅ¿ley-Grape, Å¿o call'd from the Country whence it came, and from the form of it's Leaf, being divided and Jagged like a ParÅ¿ley Leaf, it's ripe Å¿omewhat late, but a good Fruit.
The RaiÅ¿in-Grape is a large and long Grape, but ripens not well in this Clymate.
The Burlet, is a very large Grape, but Å¿eldom ripening here.
Grape de Arbois, is a very good Grape.
The BurÅ¿arobe is an excellent large Å¿weet White Crape, and in Å¿ome years ripens well, as alÅ¿o will the MuÅ¿cat.

The way of propagating Vines by Layers.Â§. 3. The beÅ¿t way of propagating Vines, is in November, to Lay a Branch of that years growth into the Earth, under the old Tree, without cutting it off; lay as many Joints, or Buds in the Earth as you can, leaving but one or two out; for it puts forth it's Roots chiefly at the Joints; at a years end, or in the February come twelve-month cut it off from the old one, and Plant it where you deÅ¿ign it Å¿hould grow; lay it in the Earth in the Å¿ame poÅ¿ture it lay in before, and alÅ¿o lay Å¿ome of the Buds of the new Wood that grow out Å¿ince it was firÅ¿t laid down; that it may gain the more Roots, leaving out of the Ground again not above one or two Buds.

Propagating Vines by Suckers and Cuttings.You may chance to have Suckers of an old Vine which will be Å¿ure to grow. Or you may take Cuttings of Vine-Branches of that years growth, and cut the bottom in Å¿hape of a Deer's foot on the under Å¿ide, and Å¿et them in good warm looÅ¿e Land, and many will grow; if it be in the place you intend they Å¿hall always Å¿tand in, next year lay down a part of that which hath grown out, to Root alÅ¿o, or els upon removal lay in the new growth all but a Bud or two, with that part which is already Rooted; if it have made but Å¿mall growth the firÅ¿t year, lay part of the Å¿econd years growth in the Ground; it will more advantage them by helping them to good Roots, than the loÅ¿s of a year or two's growth in the top will amount to.

Â§. 4. If you have an old Vine that beareth not well,To help an old Vine. lay down in February or March Å¿ome of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Branches of the foregoing year, (that grow low) in the Mold under the old Tree, without cutting them off, leaving out of the Ground a Bud or two to grow, and your Wall will quickly be furniÅ¿hed with new and FreÅ¿h Branches; Å¿o that by degrees you may cut off many of the old Branches of the Vine; for tho one Vine may cover abundance of Walling, yet three or four Roots in that compaÅ¿s will Å¿trengthen it the more to bear.

Of Pruning Vines.Â§. 5. As Vines Å¿tand in more need of Pruning than other Fruit-trees, Å¿o great care is to be taken in the performing of it; when you have Å¿et your Vine as you have been before directed, Å¿o that not above two Buds of it remain above Ground, you are to nail up Å¿uch Branches as grow forth up to the Wall, till it have over-Å¿pread as much Wall as you deÅ¿ign for it, Å¿uffering not above two Branches to grow from the Ground, and Å¿nipping yearly the tops of the Branches a conÅ¿iderable length, as far as they are weak and tender, and alÅ¿o all Å¿mall poor ones, cloÅ¿e to the body, unleÅ¿s the well-liking Branches be but few, and then you may leave the loweÅ¿t Bud of Å¿ome of them, to grow forth next year, and this you are to do yearly towards February, or the beginning of January.
When your Vine comes to bear, you are to uÅ¿e your Knife about it three times in the year.

FirÅ¿t at fartheÅ¿t in February, and the begining thereof you are to prune off part of the foregoing years Shoots where they are too thick, cloÅ¿e to the old Wood. As it enriches your Vine to keep it thin of Branches, Å¿o you muÅ¿t take care it be well Å¿tored with Buds againÅ¿t the Spring following, for it bears Grapes only on the new Shoots of every year; and in cutting off theÅ¿e Branches, you muÅ¿t take care your Wall continue furniÅ¿hed with Å¿uch Branches
as may be Å¿pread upon the Wall regularly and decently, not thick in one place and thin in another, nor croÅ¿Å¿ing out another. On every Sprig you cut off in this Pruning, where you would have Fruit the Å¿ucceeding year, leave two or three Buds, for out of thoÅ¿e Buds, eÅ¿pecially the Å¿econd or third, proceeds the CluÅ¿ters; alÅ¿o cut off the Branch aÅ¿lope on one Å¿ide or under, that the Rain reÅ¿t not on the Pith of the remaining part.

Secondly, The next time to take off Å¿uperfluties from your Vine is about MidÅ¿ummer, when the Grapes are knit; clip off then the end of the Branches that have Grapes on them, a little above the Grapes, that they may have the more nouriÅ¿hment and keep them nail'd to the Wall, as alÅ¿o barren Branches where the Wall needs them.

Thirdly, The laÅ¿t time of cutting is in AuguÅ¿t, for then, becauÅ¿e Leaves and Branches may be Å¿o thick, as to keep the Heat of the Sun from the Grapes, which is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to ripen them, you may pluck off Å¿ome of the Leaves, and cut off Å¿ome of the Branches to open way for the Sun to come to them.

There's on thing to be obÅ¿erved in Pruning theÅ¿e, peculiar to it, that whereas others are cut at a Bud, the Branches of theÅ¿e muÅ¿t be cut off near the midÅ¿t betwixt two Buds, and that not later in the year than the beginning
of February, Note. that December and Jannary, are the beÅ¿t times for tee Winter Pruning of Vines. for afterwards the Sap or Juice will run out, and the Vine will be much weakened by bleeding. You will by that time alÅ¿o Å¿ee what the FroÅ¿t of the Winter foregoing hath kill'd, which muÅ¿t be taken all away.
If FroÅ¿ts come before any Grapes are ripe, defend them in the night time by Tilts or Mats.

Â§. 6. It's not worth your labour to Plant Vines by EÅ¿paliers,Vineyards proÅ¿per not in England. or in a Vineyard in England; becauÅ¿e of the early nipping FroÅ¿ts which our Clymate is very Å¿ubject to, which is the reaÅ¿on ti's Å¿eldom uÅ¿ed, and the uÅ¿age of people in Å¿uch caÅ¿es affords no weak Argument that it's of no advantage; And Grapes Å¿eldom or never ripen well in this IÅ¿le, without great help of Art and induÅ¿try, to which purpoÅ¿e take theÅ¿e directions.
FirÅ¿t, To Plant Å¿uch as ripen Å¿ooneÅ¿t in the year, that they may have as much of the Summer heat at ripening time as may be.

Secondly, Let the Wall you Plant them againÅ¿t, be a full South, or but a little inclining to the EaÅ¿t; or if you have a half round, or corner in a Wall, or the back of a Brick Chimney, or a Kiln-wall, or Barnwall poÅ¿ited as aforeÅ¿aid, make uÅ¿e of Å¿uch places for them.

Vines will proÅ¿per and bear well againÅ¿t a high Wall, yet that is not altogether Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary but that low Walls may Å¿erve turn, and the higher may be reÅ¿erved for Å¿uch Fruit-trees as will not do well without them. That of a Tarras Walk may do well for Vines, and the Gravel Walk under the Wall mightily encreaÅ¿e the heat about them.

If you Plant any Trees againÅ¿t your dwelling-houÅ¿e Wall, there may be Å¿ome narrow places between two windows, or the like, where other Fruit-trees have not room to Å¿pread: a Vine may grow up there, and above thoÅ¿e narrow places enlarge it Å¿elf where ever it meets with room.

You may alÅ¿o Plant a Vine betwixt every Fruit-tree that groweth againÅ¿t your hotteÅ¿t Walls, and let it Å¿pread a little in the Summer time into the Fruit-trees on either Å¿ide, eÅ¿pecially if the Fruit of Å¿uch Trees uÅ¿e to be early ripe, or that they bear little Fruit, or have not been Å¿o long Å¿et as to have covered the Wall. And tho Å¿uch Vines cannot extend themÅ¿elves to that bigneÅ¿s, as thoÅ¿e Planted where they have more room; yet by this means you will make advantage of Å¿uch portions of your Wall, as otherwiÅ¿e you could have but little benefit from.

Some Vines Shoot Å¿orth exceeding large Branches yearly, but bear little; in Å¿uch caÅ¿es bare the Roots, and cut off a MaÅ¿ter
Root, or two from the Tree, then lay Å¿ome Sand, AÅ¿hes; or any hot barren Soil to the Roots, and it will abate the redundancy of Sap, and conduce to bearing Fruits.

Â§. 7. Do not pull or cut off your Vine-Leaves in AuguÅ¿t, or September, with deÅ¿ign of giving acceÅ¿s to the Suns heat, thereby to acclerate the maturity of the Fruit, as many frequently uÅ¿e to do, and as is before directed in Sect. 5. for on my own experince, Å¿uch depriving the Grape of it's Leafed Å¿helter from the cool Air, or morning FroÅ¿ts, hath always proved pernicious and deÅ¿tructtive to the Grape; and I have often obÅ¿erved the beÅ¿t Grapes and earlieÅ¿t ripe, to be under the Å¿hadow and Protection of Å¿ome Leaf.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of Figs, their kinds, and propagation.

div.p: Kinds of Walnuts.Â§. 1. THere are Å¿everal Å¿orts of Walnuts, Å¿ome being larger, others thinner Å¿held than the common, but differ Å¿o little one from another that Men have not much minded giving them Names; the largeÅ¿t Å¿ort is uÅ¿ually call'd the French Wallnut; the beÅ¿t are thoÅ¿e of a tender thin Å¿hell, of a full Kernel, and of a middle Å¿ize.

They are raiÅ¿ed by Nuts gathered from the Å¿ame Trees: if you can, let them have their Green Husks on them, for the bitterneÅ¿s thereof will defend the Kernels from being eaten by Worms before they Å¿pring up; but you muÅ¿t chiefly reÅ¿pect their full ripeneÅ¿s, at which time they are apt to Å¿hed their Husks; you may either Å¿et them as they come immediately from the Tree, or keep them in the Sand till March.

div.p: THere are two Å¿orts of Filbeards, diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿ht by the colour of the skin of their Kernells, the one being Red, and the other White: There is another Å¿ort, call'd the Filbeard of ConÅ¿tantinople; the Leaves and Fruit of which, are bigger than either of the former: And there is beÅ¿ides theÅ¿e an excellent large plump Nut, that hath a very good Kernel, the beÅ¿t of which have a very thin Å¿hell.

div.head: CHAP XVIII. Of Quinces their kinds and propagation.
div.p: THere is not a more delicate Fruit for the Kitchin and ConÅ¿ervatory than the Quince, whereof there are Å¿ome Å¿orts, though not many, Å¿omwhat different from each other.
The Portugal Apple Quince, is of beÅ¿t eÅ¿teem, it's a large yellow Fruit, tender, pleaÅ¿ant, and Å¿oon boiled.

The way of raiÅ¿ing Quince-trees is by Suckers, Cuttings, as you are taught in the Eleventh Chap. aforegoing; and it's only to be added that if you have a part of a
Tree that growth Å¿o low, that you can bring it to the Ground, either by PlaiÅ¿hing or otherwiÅ¿e, you may do it in the beginning of Winter, and cover it all with Earth but the ends of the Branches, and let it continue Å¿o one year, and then uncover it, and every Twig will have put forth Roots in the Earth, which being cut off, and tranÅ¿planted will make you a Tree.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of Mulberries.
div.p: MUlberries are diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed by their Colours, for there are Black, Red, and White.

TheÅ¿e following Trees and Shrubs are very apt to grow of Cuttings or Slips, as Codlings, Gennetings, Brets, Gennet-Moils, Quinces, Goosberries, Currans, Figs, Vines, Tamarisk, HoneyÅ¿uckles, and RoÅ¿es in Å¿ome Grounds. div.head: CAAP. XX. Of Medlars, and Service-trees.
div.p: THere are three or four Å¿orts of Medlars, the biggeÅ¿t Å¿ort, call'd the great Dutch Medlar without any Thorns upon the Branches, is the beÅ¿t, and a good bearer; the common hath Thorns upon the Branches; and there is another Å¿ort without any Stones in the Fruit.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of Goosberries, Currans, RaÅ¿pherries, and Barberries.
div.p: Â§. 1. GOosberries Å¿o call'd from the uÅ¿e that hath a long time been made of them,Goosberries. in the Kitchin when Green GeeÅ¿e are in Å¿eaÅ¿on.

There are Å¿ome varieties of Goosberries, the beÅ¿t Å¿orts are the Amber, and great Hedghog Goosberry, which is prickly, but the other Å¿mooth, both of a bright Yellow colour, and the great White Holland, or Dutch Goosberry, which is large, tranÅ¿parent, and a great bearer. Â§. 2. Currans or Corinths,Currans. taking their name from Corinthia where firÅ¿t had. The great White Dutch Curran, and the great Red Dutch Curran, are the faireÅ¿t, largeÅ¿t and beÅ¿t, and the great Yellow Dutch Curran differs only in Colour, all others are to be ejected out of your Gardens; the EngliÅ¿h and Black Currans not being worth Planting in compariÅ¿on with the White and Red Dutch Currans. Â§. 3. Of Barberries there is the ordinary,Barberries. or common Å¿ort, and Barberries without Stones, and the great Barberry, which is a Å¿ort bearing bigger Fruit than either of the other.
Of Rasberries there are three Å¿orts;Rasberries. The Common Wild; The large Red Garden Rasberry, a pleaÅ¿ant Fruit, and yields a delicate juice, And the White Rasberry little inferior to the Red.

Goosberries, Currans, Rasberries, and Barberries are beÅ¿t raiÅ¿ed by Suckers, of which you may have plenty about the Roots of old Trees. And Goosberries, and Currans may be propagated by Layers, or by Branches, or Shoots cut off and Å¿et; they are to be Å¿et four or five Foot diÅ¿tant from each other upon Borders, or
Beds of rich moiÅ¿t Land: The Å¿eaÅ¿on for Planting them is from Michaelmas to Candlemas.
Currans and Rasberries will proÅ¿per and like very well in Å¿hady places, and the colder the Soil, the better will Rasberries bear and thrive.

Rasberries uÅ¿ually bear the Å¿ame year they are Å¿et, if drought, or too late Planting hinder not; and that which bears this year, dyes after bearing, and what Springs new this year bears the next; Cut no more of them than what will make them a little handÅ¿ome, and in the Winter cut or break out all the dead Stalks from amongÅ¿t the living Rasberries.

When Currans, Goosberries, and Barberries have grown Å¿ome years, Å¿uffer not too many Suckers to grow about them, nor cut the tops to a round cloÅ¿e BuÅ¿h, as many Gardiners do, whereby they grow Å¿o thick that they neither bear, nor ripen their Fruit Å¿o well as if the grew taller and thinner.

All the Å¿aid Fruits (viz. Goosberries, Currans Barberries and Rasberries) like well in Å¿hades, tho the Fruits are not of Å¿o delicate a taÅ¿t, as thoÅ¿e that grow in the Sun: You ought to keep the Ground about
them free from Weeds, and other Vegetables, and to Dig, and well Manure it each two years at Michaelmas, and yearly with a pair of Sheers about fourteen days before MidÅ¿ummer dub the tops of Currans and Goosberries and they'll bear better; do the like at Michaelmas.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of the kinds of Peaches, and Nectarins.

The Trees are great bearers, and hardy againÅ¿t all Winds and BlaÅ¿ts; The Fruit is Å¿o hard, Å¿harp, and unpalatable from the Tree, that it's freed from the danger Å¿weeter Fruits are Å¿ubject to; they hang long on the Trees before they are ripe, and then being laid up until December, or after, and Ground, yield a very delicate Cyder, which will Å¿oon ferment, therefore muÅ¿t be drawn off the Lee in a few days.

This being a common, and in Å¿ome places but a Hedg-Fruit, and yielding but a thin Å¿owr juice, being Ground from the Tree, hath been of late Å¿lighted, when in truth there is Å¿carce a better Fruit to be Planted, than this John-Apple, or Two-year-old,
both for the beauty of the Tree, it's quick growth, it's liking all Grounds, great bearing, enduring all Weathers, long laÅ¿ting, it's excellency for Kitchin uÅ¿es, and preference at the Table, when moÅ¿t other Fruits are paÅ¿t.

ObÅ¿erve that Cyder Fruit may be divided into three ClaÅ¿Å¿es, FirÅ¿t, Å¿uch as are for making early Cyder, or for preÅ¿ent Drinking, as the Codling and Summer Fruits, &c. Secondly, Å¿uch that are for making the beÅ¿t, rich, oyly, Å¿picy, poignant, and high reliÅ¿hed Cyder, and alÅ¿o long keeping and laÅ¿ting, Å¿uch are the RedÅ¿treak, Bromsberry Crab, Golden-Pippin, WeÅ¿tbury-Apple, John-Apple, the Å¿everal Å¿orts of MuÅ¿ts, and Fillets, the Elliot and Stoken-Apple, &c. Thirdly, Å¿uch that are uÅ¿eful Fruit for the Table, yet making a very pleaÅ¿ant and acceptable Cyder, and Å¿uch are the Pippins and Pearmains, Gilliflower, Marigold-Apple, Golden-Renneting, Harvey-Apple, Queening, &c. Generally all hard Apples and Wildings, having a lively, pert, poignant, brisk juice (Å¿o that they come not too near the degree of Å¿tark Crabs) make excellent Cyder; but Cyder, made of hard, harÅ¿h Fruits, is not Å¿o Å¿oon ready for drinking, as that of Summer Fruits, and thoÅ¿e more pleaÅ¿ant: That made of Table Fruit being earlieÅ¿t ripe, is ready to drink Å¿o Å¿oon as it is well Å¿ettled and cleared; but that of hard Apples, not till Summer following,
and will continue good for two or three years, or longer, if kept in a cool Cellar, good VeÅ¿Å¿ells, well Å¿topt, and will improve in keeping.
Of Planting Å¿everal kinds of Apples,Some object that Å¿ince one or two kinds of Fruits may be had very good for Cyder, what occaÅ¿ion is there to Plant of Å¿o many Å¿orts?

For AnÅ¿wer; They will find it advantageous to have Å¿everal Å¿orts of Fruit for Cyder, for the following conÅ¿iderations,
1. One Å¿ort of Fruit-trees may and do bear one year when another fails.
2. Cyder made of Å¿ome kinds will be ready to drink Å¿ooner than others, and thereby you may have it Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively for your uÅ¿e. The MuÅ¿t-Cyder may be clear a Month after making; The Gennet-Moil a quarter of a year after; the RedÅ¿treak near Half a year after, though it's much improved by longer keeping.
3. You may make your Cyder with more eaÅ¿e, the Fruits you make it of ripening one after another.
4. Tho Å¿ome Fruits yield not Å¿o good Cyder as others, yet the Trees may be quicker of growth, bear more plentifully, and laÅ¿t longer than thoÅ¿e that yield better; and the Palates of men being various, Å¿ome like one Å¿ort and Å¿ome another, and Å¿o all may be pleaÅ¿ed.
5. Some Fruit-trees agree with the Soil and Clymate better than others, which you'l not be able to know, till you have made tryal of Å¿everal.

How to make a new kind of Apple or Pear.Graft one Fruit on another many times over, every year a different kind, (Å¿o that you keep to thoÅ¿e kinds that will grow together.) As firÅ¿t to Graft a Crabtree near the Ground with Å¿ome good kind of Apple Graft, and the next year to Graft that again a handful or two above where the firÅ¿t was Grafted, and the next year to Graft that Å¿econd Graft, and Å¿o proceed for five or Å¿ix years, by Å¿etting Graft upon Graft, and this may probably make Å¿ome alteration and commixture in the Fruit of the topmoÅ¿t Graft; tho it be true, every Graft keeps it's own nature, yet Å¿o as it receives Å¿ome Å¿mall alteration from the Stock, the Sap thus ariÅ¿ing and paÅ¿Å¿ing through Å¿o many kinds of Stocks into the topmoÅ¿t, may poÅ¿Å¿ibly raiÅ¿e a new Fruit.

The more Red any Apple hath in it's Rind, the better for Cyder, the paler the worÅ¿e; no Å¿weet Apple that hath a rough Rind is bad for Cyder, if Å¿uffered eÅ¿pecially to digeÅ¿t Å¿ome time on heaps, as is hereafter directed, Chap. 29. Sect. 3.

Mixture of Fruit is of great advantage to your Cyder, the meaneÅ¿t Apples mixt make as good Cyder as the beÅ¿t alone, except the RedÅ¿treak, and Å¿ome few celebrated Apples for that purpoÅ¿e; but always obÅ¿erve that the Apples Å¿o mixt be of equal ripeneÅ¿s.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of Annoyances to Fruit-Trees.
div.p: Concerning MoÅ¿s or Canker.Â§. 1. THe nature of Soil is the chief cauÅ¿e of the MoÅ¿s and Canker, and therefore without altering the one, you can Å¿carce prevent the other, however you may with a hair cloth rub the MoÅ¿s off, after rain, or (as Å¿ome Å¿ay) burn it with a bottle of Straw under the Tree: but if you only Å¿crape or rub off the MoÅ¿s, in few years they'l be as much annoyed therewith as ever; becauÅ¿e MoÅ¿Å¿ineÅ¿s is cauÅ¿ed by over coldneÅ¿s of the Ground; as in the WateriÅ¿h and Clay Grounds, and likewiÅ¿e by BarrenneÅ¿s of the Soil. If the coldneÅ¿s proceed from over much moiÅ¿ture, lay it dryer, by Trenching the Ground; if Clay Grounds, then mix warmer Soils therewith as you are before taught at Chap. 7. Sect. 10. yet be Å¿ure you take away the preÅ¿ent MoÅ¿s.
All Canker, filth, and Worms, muÅ¿t be picked clean off, and bind Å¿ome Clay well mixt with Hay about the Canker'd place.

If the Tree grow but poorly, which is for the moÅ¿t part cauÅ¿ed by the ill temper
of the Soil, open the Ground about the Roots and put in Å¿ome Manure proper to cure it.

The Canker aÅ¿Å¿aults generally the beÅ¿t Å¿orts of Fruit-trees, as the Pippin, Pearmain, Harvy-Apple, Golden Rennet, &c. of Pears the Wardens of all Å¿orts, Burgamots. &c. And it Å¿omtimes comes by galling and fretting of Boughs on each other, and Å¿omtimes by Å¿etting Trees not Å¿hallow but too deep, as well as by BarrenneÅ¿s of Soil, and Å¿omtimes it comes by breaking off Boughs (which Å¿hould be cut off cloÅ¿e to the Tree, tho in the Summer) and Cattles nipping off the Buds or pieces of the Tree, or unÅ¿eaÅ¿onable Pruning.
RaiÅ¿ing of Stocks from Crab kernels in the Å¿ame Land and Grafting on, after once removed, and placed where they are to grow and be Grafted, prevents the Canker.

To cure the Canker at preÅ¿ent, cut it out, if it be upon the body or great Boughs of Trees, and waÅ¿h the place with Cowdung and urine mixt, and then cover the place with Clay mixed with HorÅ¿e-dung, and cut off the Å¿mall Branches that are dead; however Å¿top the cauÅ¿e by amending the Soil at Roots with proper Manure, as the Dung of Hogs, Pidgeons, Poultry, HorÅ¿es, Cows, the Å¿ediments of Pools, Ponds, Currants, Shovelings of yards where Cattle frequent, &c. according to the nature of the Soil.

Â§. 2. Slitting the Bark is an excellent additional help to moÅ¿t of the aforÅ¿aid evils,Bark bound. and alÅ¿o for Bark binding; Å¿ome adviÅ¿e that the Bark be cut according to the grain of it, as in Apple-trees, Pear-trees, &c, Å¿traight down; in Cherries &c. round about the Trees; and where the Graft over-thrives the Stock, there Å¿lit the Stock, but not quite through the Bark, and this Å¿litting muÅ¿t be done in the Spring about the middle of February, or at Candlemas.

Some Trees proÅ¿per where others will not.Â§. 3. You'l often find in the Å¿ame Land Å¿ome kinds of Fruit-trees very Å¿ubject to Å¿ome of the beforementioned evils, and others proÅ¿per well; when once you diÅ¿cover this (becauÅ¿e it's utterly in vain to make Ground and Trees of different Genius agree together) you muÅ¿t make it your buÅ¿ineÅ¿s by degrees to change your Trees, till you have left none againÅ¿t which your Soil beareth Å¿uch an implacable hatred, and furniÅ¿h it with Å¿uch as will flouriÅ¿h and be fruitful.

Â§. 4. If any of your Trees are galled by rubbing on each other,Bark Gall'd or by being bound to Stakes, or by Thorns, or otherwiÅ¿e, lay Å¿ome Clay upon the gald places and wrap Hay-bands about them, but withall remove the cauÅ¿e by Pruning, or otherwiÅ¿e.

Â§. 5. Bigg Plants that upon there removal have had their Tops cut off,Dead Tops or bitten Twiggs to be cut off. are apt to dye from the place they were cut off at, to the next Sprig or Branch upon them; theÅ¿e dead parts, or any piece bit by Cattel, ought to be cut off cloÅ¿e to the next good Twig or Shoot, and cover'd with Clay as in Grafting, that the head may be well grown over by Å¿uch Twig or Shoot, and the wet prevented of getting into the Pith, to the dammage of the Tree.

Â§. 6. Hares and Rabbets are very miÅ¿chievous to NurÅ¿eries,Hares and Coneys. and young Orchards by peeling off the Bark of the Plants; if your Fence be a Wall, or cloÅ¿e Pale, or Water, there's little danger of them, but becauÅ¿e Å¿uch Fences about Orchards are rare, and no other can keep them out, Å¿ome expedient muÅ¿t be made uÅ¿e of.

Some have uÅ¿ed Hay Ropes bound about the Tree from the Ground a Å¿ufficient height; but this were endleÅ¿s in a NurÅ¿ery, it may be done in an Orchard, but there are other ways to be preferr'd before it.

Others therefore dawb the bodies of the Trees over with Tar, which being uÅ¿ed alone endangers the life of very young Plants, and extreamly hardens the Bark, and otherwiÅ¿e hurts them, which evil is prevented by mixing the Tar with any kind of GreaÅ¿e, and boiling them on a Fire, Å¿o as both may incorporate, then with a BruÅ¿h,
or little Broom, dawb over the body of the Tree, as high as an Hare or Rabbet can reach, and this is to be done about the tenth of November, it will preÅ¿erve the Trees for that whole year, with that once doing, it being the Winter time only that they will feed upon the Bark.
Some uÅ¿e GreaÅ¿e alone, and then it will require to be laid on twice in a Winter.
Some thin Å¿tuff out of a houÅ¿e of Office, or the thick tempered with Water, and bruÅ¿ht on, once or twice in a Winter hath been often uÅ¿ed with good Å¿ucceÅ¿s.

And if you deÅ¿ire to take them, Å¿et Grins of Wire, Snares, or runing NooÅ¿es of Wire (whoÅ¿e brittleneÅ¿s is allay'd by the heat of Fire) at and in their MuÅ¿ets, or the holes they come in at, and you may take many, but Å¿carce all before you have great miÅ¿chiefs done you.

PiÅ¿mires and Ants:Â§. 7. If you find PiÅ¿mires, or Ants, breed about or near the Roots of any of your Trees, caÅ¿t away the Earth they lodge in, and Å¿upply it's place with Å¿ome Å¿tiff Clay: If they breed diÅ¿tant in Å¿everal places, Å¿ome direct to dawb the Tree about with Tar, that their feet may be taken in it, but you heard already that's prejudicial to young Trees; but if they peÅ¿ter you extreamly, and your Tree be young, you may bind a Å¿ingle liÅ¿t, or Å¿hred of cloth about it, and once a week (when Buds and BloÅ¿Å¿oms are
putting forth, for that is the chief time they prejudice them) dawb the cloth over with Tar. And where you find their breeding places, pour Å¿calding Water thereon.

Â§. 8. Moles are to be killed, eÅ¿pecially in Seed plots and NurÅ¿eries:Moles and Water Rats Spring-traps, or Box-traps are beÅ¿t to deÅ¿troy them, not eaÅ¿ily deÅ¿cribed, but are now almoÅ¿t generally known. There are alÅ¿o Å¿ome kinds of Cats that will not leave a Mole either in your Garden or Orchards, and Å¿ome Å¿ay that Water Rats will Å¿poil a whole NurÅ¿ery getting through Mole holes, and Barking or eating the young Roots, and theÅ¿e are Å¿aid to be frequent where your NurÅ¿ery is near a FiÅ¿h-pond.

Suckers.Â§. 9. From the Stock uÅ¿ually Å¿pring many Suckers, which extract the nouriÅ¿hment from the Tree, they muÅ¿t be taken off dexterouÅ¿ly from the Root, and may be prevented by Grafting on good Stocks raiÅ¿ed from Kernels: for Trees Grafted on, or proceeding from Suckers, are always Å¿ubject to this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, which the Canker uÅ¿ualy attends.
EÅ¿ts.Â§. 10. EÅ¿ts or (or Å¿ome call them) Askers, are Å¿aid to be pernicious to Trees; therefore as you find either Moles, Water Rats, or them, deÅ¿troy them.

BlaÅ¿tings, FroÅ¿ts, and Caterpilars. Â§. 11. The greateÅ¿t prejudice to Fruit is by BlaÅ¿tings, FroÅ¿ts immediately Å¿ucceeding rain, Caterpillars, or black Flies, that eat up Buds, Leaves, and BloÅ¿Å¿oms; therefore when in the Spring you perceive theÅ¿e Caterpillars or Flies appear, make fires of Å¿omthing that will Å¿moak, Å¿o near the Orchard, and in Å¿uch places that the Wind may carry the Å¿moak as much through the Trees as may be. A thing frequently uÅ¿ed is Hemp Å¿heaves (as t'is called) being the Stalk of the Hemp, when the Tow is Å¿eparated from it, and 'its certainly very good, but bad Chaff, wet Straw, or Moldy Hay, or any thing of that nature may Å¿erve turn, and 'tis Å¿aid to be good for FroÅ¿ts alÅ¿o, but how, I know not; and you may alÅ¿o pluck off thoÅ¿e Leaves which have the Cobwebs made upon them, (in which they breed) and tread them under foot, for one of them contains multitudes.
Â§. 12. Snails are pernicious to Wall-fruit therefore deÅ¿troy as many of them as you can,Snails. when they are beÅ¿t to be diÅ¿cover'd which is early in the morning.

Cover Wall-Fruit.Â§. 13. To preÅ¿erve your Wall-fruit as, Apricocks, Peaches, Nectarins, &c. from blaÅ¿ting Winds, and FroÅ¿ts, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to cover them in the nights and cold days, by hanging before them Canvas or
thick Linnen cloths, which you may draw up and let down by Pullies.

Â§. 14. Birds, as the Bullfinch, TitmouÅ¿e, or Tomtit,Birds. &c. are affrighted beÅ¿t by a dry Hawk perching in the middle of the Tree, or by taking them with Birdlime: Crows will be frighted if you kill one or two of them, and pull it in peices, and Å¿catter the pieces about the Trees, they'l not come their again whilÅ¿t the Feathers are any thing freÅ¿h: but Magpies, Jackdaws, Jay's are not to be frighted from your Cherries, but kill'd as they come with a Gun, and that early in the morning.

Earwiggs.Â§. 15. Earwigs are deÅ¿troyed by Å¿etting Oxhoofs, Canes, or any hollow thing near the Roots of the Trees, and among the Boughs upon the ends of Å¿ticks, and they'l Creep in, and lye there, then take off theÅ¿e Hoofs quickly, and Å¿hake them and cruÅ¿h them on the Ground with your foot.

Cattle.Â§. 16. Cattle, whereÅ¿oever they come amongÅ¿t Trees, are a mighty and miÅ¿chievous enemy, if the Boughs be within their reach; for then they'l bite off the ends of all, and thereby with their Teeth, Å¿o bruiÅ¿e the ends of the Boughs and Shoots, that the Tree Å¿eldoms thrives of many years, if ever, afterwards. Where this misfortune happens to any Tree, the only remedy
is to cut off at Å¿ome Sprig or Bud, Å¿o much as they have had in their mouths, or is bruiÅ¿ed by their Teeth. And Fence your Orchards well from them, or els, which is the Å¿ureÅ¿t way, not to let your Trees begin to Å¿pread before they be Å¿ix or Å¿even foot high, of the Trunk or body, and Å¿o Prun'd up, that all the Boughs and every part of them be Å¿o far from the Ground as will be impoÅ¿Å¿ible for Cattle to reach.

Setting too deep.Â§. 17. Altho the Å¿etting Trees too deep and below the good Soil be no diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, yet it's the cauÅ¿e of many diÅ¿eaÅ¿es to your Fruittrees, as MoÅ¿s, Barkbound, Canker, &c. therefore carefully to be avoided; Å¿etting Å¿hallow being attended with no other inconveniences, but that the Trees are Å¿omtimes blown down, if not Staked the firÅ¿t two years.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. Of Gathering Fruit, and the beÅ¿t way of making Cyder.
div.p: Â§. 1. IN gathering of Fruit, be careful that the Branches of your Trees be not battered and broken.

Â§. 2. Such as you deÅ¿ign to keep any time, ought not to be Å¿haked off the Trees, becauÅ¿e of bruiÅ¿ing, but picked off with your hands: Be Å¿ure the Fruit you gather be throughly ripe, which you may know by it's beginning to drop, or by cutting an Apple, and Å¿eeing the Kernels turn black: Let the Weather be fair and dry when you gather, and no dew upon the Trees; lay up what you thus gather in a cloÅ¿e, but a Å¿weet room, upon a boarded (but not with Deal) Floor, and not on a Clay, or plaiÅ¿tred Floor, and lay them up without any green Leaves, or Sticks among them. As you find any in your heaps rot, pick them out, and in FroÅ¿ts cover them with Straw, or Straw Mats, and alÅ¿o hang in Å¿harp FroÅ¿ts Blankets before the Windows to keep out
the FroÅ¿ts. Lay every kind by themÅ¿elves.
If you have Å¿ome Pears that are choice and laÅ¿ting, wrap them up in paper, and lay them one by one upon Å¿helves, or hang them up by the Stalks, and keep out the Air from them as much as you can.

Â§. 3. In gathering Cyder Fruit, you muÅ¿t be Å¿ure to let them be well ripe on the Tree,Gathering of Cyder Fruit and preparing it for the Mill. for there is much Cyder Å¿poild becauÅ¿e the Apples are Ground before they are ripe, and all Fruits yield a different Liquor according to the different degrees of maturity of the Å¿ame Fruit; for when it's moÅ¿t ripe it yields a richer, pleaÅ¿anter and more laÅ¿ting drink; but if preÅ¿Å¿ed before ripe, tho it yields a greater quantity, yet it's but a thin, raw, crude, Å¿owr, phlegmatick, and unwholeÅ¿ome drink: Therefore if your Fruit be not ripe all at one time, Å¿elect Å¿uch Å¿orts as are of a like degree of maturity, or if the Wind beat down many, and you are unwilling to Å¿poil or loÅ¿e them, let them lye dry as long as you can before you grind them, to obtain as great a degree of ripeneÅ¿s as they can, and let that Cyder be thoroughly fermented before barrel'd, and the firÅ¿t that is Å¿pent; neither mix ripe with unripe Fruit, not ought you to permit Å¿ome Å¿orts of Fruit be too ripe; becauÅ¿e it then grows pulpy in Grinding, and will not yield it's Liquor
unleÅ¿s Å¿ome Water be mixed therewith; your choice Summer Fruits are Å¿ome of them, as alÅ¿o the Pippins, and Renatings Å¿ubject to pulpineÅ¿s, if full ripe.
Lay Å¿uch Fruit by themÅ¿elves (to be Ground and preÅ¿Å¿ed for Cyderkin) that are broken; but a Å¿mall bruiÅ¿e does not much injury.

Your Apples being well ripe, let them be gently Å¿haken down, and laid out of the Sun and Rain, not abroad but in a heap; upon a Å¿weet and dry Floor that is boarded (but not with Deals, nor on a plaiÅ¿terd Floor) and on dry, Rye, Wheat or Oaten Straw, till they have Å¿weat out and digeÅ¿ted their crude and phlegmatick humour, and there let them Å¿o lye a fortnight; the RedÅ¿treak and harder Apples you may let lye longer, that is, three weaks or a Month; the longer they lye, the leÅ¿s Cyder indeed they will yield, but much the better, it being neceÅ¿Å¿ary to have them as ripe as may be, Å¿o that too many of them begin not to rot, which rotten ones are to be picked out.

Grind not your Apples immediately from the Tree, Å¿o Å¿oon as they are throughly ripe, tho they will then yield the greater quantity of Liquor, but neither pleaÅ¿ant nor laÅ¿ting, therefore let them lye on heaps as aforeÅ¿aid.

By hoarding only of Windfalls for Å¿ome time, or untill the time it was expected they
Å¿hould have been ripe in, doth very much meliorate the Cyder made of them, which otherwiÅ¿e might have been very bad.
For from the due time, place, and manner of hoarding of the Fruit is oftentimes the Cyder very good, which otherwiÅ¿e might have been very bad.
Thus when your Fruit is duly ripe, gathered, preÅ¿erved or hoarded Å¿ome time, it's ready for the Mill.

When you bring your Apples to the Mill, or juÅ¿t befor you fill them up; pick out, or caÅ¿t by, all that are Green, unripe, rotten, or otherwiÅ¿e naught, and all Stalks Leaves, &c. that may injure your Cyder, for it's better to want a Å¿mall quantity of Liquor than to Å¿poil the whole.

Some are of opinion that rottenneÅ¿s in the Apple injureth not the Cyder, but that a convenient quantity of rotten. Apples mixt with the Å¿ound is a great help to the Fermentation and Clarification of the Cyder; but it's Å¿uppoÅ¿ed they mean Å¿uch Apples only as have been bruiÅ¿ed in gathering, Å¿haking down, or carrying, which will by lying become rotten, and (the skin being whole) be not much the worÅ¿e, only the Cyder will retain a Å¿mack of them; notwithÅ¿tanding which, by no means admit them amongÅ¿t your Cyder, that you intend for keeping, but rather make Cyder of them for a more early Å¿pending: for others
affirm, that one rotten Apple corrupts a whole VeÅ¿Å¿el, which I preÅ¿ume is intended only of putrid rottenneÅ¿s.
Â§. 4. Grind not your Apples too Å¿mall, for if they are not very Å¿mall Ground,Of grinding and PreÅ¿Å¿ing the Apples. you'l have but little leÅ¿s Cyder (altho the contrary is commonly believed.)

After your Fruit is Ground, let it Å¿tand 24 or 48 hours, according as your time and conveniency will admit, Å¿o that it be altogether in good quantities in large VeÅ¿Å¿els; by Å¿tanding thus it not only matures, but acquires colour, commendable in Cyder, and alÅ¿o cauÅ¿es the leÅ¿Å¿er part of the Apple eaÅ¿ily to part with it's juice in the PreÅ¿s; therefore obÅ¿erve not the general adviÅ¿e to preÅ¿s immediatly from the Mill.

You may leave a paÅ¿Å¿age open in the bottom of your Fat, wherein you keep your bruiÅ¿ed Apples, during the time of their being therein, from the grinding to the preÅ¿Å¿ing; and Å¿ome of the Cyder may Å¿pontaneouÅ¿ly deÅ¿till into a receiver placed under it, or you may have a falÅ¿e Bottom full of holes, that the greater quanty may be had which may run through Å¿ome Tap or other paÅ¿Å¿age into your receiver: Cyder thus obtained far excels that which is forced out by the PreÅ¿s; as Live Honey that deÅ¿tills of it Å¿elf from the Combs, is much better than that which remains and is preÅ¿Å¿ed out
afterwards; but this is only uÅ¿ed to get Å¿ome Å¿mall quantity of the richeÅ¿t Cyder.

In preÅ¿Å¿ing the Apples, in caÅ¿e you intend not to uÅ¿e (which is bad husbandry) your Pulp, MuÅ¿t, or Murc afterwards for the making of Water Cyder, uÅ¿ually call'd Purre, or Cyderkin, then it is beÅ¿t to preÅ¿s it as dry as you can, but incaÅ¿e you intend to add Water to your Murc, and to preÅ¿s it again, then you need not to preÅ¿s it very hard, for your Cyder will then be Å¿omthing the worÅ¿e, and Å¿o will your Purre, or Cyderkin: for the laÅ¿t Å¿queezing is the weakeÅ¿t, and makes your Cyder the rougher; and if any thing will, that gives it a Wooddy taÅ¿t, unleÅ¿s it be prevented in the eaÅ¿y Grinding; but this only is obÅ¿erved when you intend to have Å¿ome rich Cyder, and Cyderkin for your own uÅ¿e, otherwiÅ¿e CyderiÅ¿ts generally preÅ¿s their Apples as hard as they can, altho they intend to make Cyderkin of the Murc.

Barrelling of Cyder.Â§. 5. As your VeÅ¿Å¿el under the CyderpreÅ¿s fills, then take the Liquor, and pour it through Å¿ome Streyner or hair Sieve (which will detain the Pulp and groÅ¿Å¿er pieces of Apples from intermixing in the Vat) into a large Vat, from whence moÅ¿t preÅ¿cribe to tun it immediately into the Barrels wherein it's to be kept, leÅ¿t it's Å¿pirits Å¿hould evaporate; but others rather chooÅ¿e to caÅ¿t a cloth only over the Vat or Tun
to preÅ¿erve it, and rather waÅ¿t and conÅ¿ume the wild Spirit of the Cyder, in the Tun or Vat, and let it there in Å¿ome Å¿mall degree purify by Å¿tanding coverd five or Å¿ix hours in the Vat, before you put it into the Barrel it's to be kept in; then they Å¿eparate the pure from the impure by leaving as many Feces or Dregs to remain on the bottom of the Vat as poÅ¿Å¿ible; becauÅ¿e Dregs very much incommode your Cyder by making it quickly become acid.

Then Tun up the pureÅ¿t (leaving the Å¿ediment at bottom of the Vat) Liquor in a HogÅ¿head or Barrel, Å¿eaÅ¿oned and Å¿weet, fill it not up by two Gallons at leaÅ¿t, and Å¿top it up only with a looÅ¿e Å¿topper for four or five days, and then Å¿top it up cloÅ¿e with Clay on the top or Tunhole, and put a Cork or Å¿ome Å¿topper in â¢â¢ e Vent-hole, looÅ¿ly putting in the Peg; but for a weeks time or more, you may once a day draw it forth a little, leÅ¿t it break the VeÅ¿Å¿el, or force Å¿ome other vent; then Å¿top it cloÅ¿e up alÅ¿o, and Å¿o let it Å¿tand till you think it may be Å¿omthing clear, and then pierce it, to try how it fines; The Summer Fruit after a Month, the Moil after the firÅ¿t FroÅ¿ts, the Red Å¿treak not till after January, other Winter-Fruit Cyder about the Å¿ame time.

If the Cyder be Å¿o clear that it will not again ferment, and you intend to keep it long in the Barrel; put in clean unground
Wheat, after the proportion of a quart to a HogÅ¿head, which will preÅ¿erve it; and this artificial head is only to be uÅ¿ed, where an admiÅ¿Å¿ion of Air may probably be into the VeÅ¿Å¿el.

Stopping of Cyder with Clay, if you deÅ¿ign to keep it long, is not Å¿o good as a Woodden Plug, turn'd fit to the Bunghole, and covered about with a Å¿ingle brown paper wet, before you wring it into it's place, and then let the Plug be well luted on the top and Å¿ides with Clay temperr'd with Salt.

How to fine or clear Cyder.Â§. 6. is not advantagious but injurious to it, becauÅ¿e the Scum being of the nature of YeÅ¿t or Barm, helps to ferment and purify.

How to make Å¿mall Meath.Â§. 20. Take 24 Quarts of clear Spring Water, that hath been boyled with LiquoriÅ¿h, RoÅ¿emary, Bays, Fennel and PurÅ¿ly Roots, of each half a handful, till it taÅ¿t Å¿trong of them, which will be in half an hours boyling; put the Water through a Sieve, and add full eight Pints of Honey to it; When it is diÅ¿Å¿olved Å¿et it over the Fire in a BraÅ¿s, or rather Copper Pan; let it boyl a quarter of an hour after it would boyl all over, in which time continue to Scum it clean; put it then into Earthen Pans, and when it is cold as Wort is when it is put together, pour off the clear into a Pale, and put to it about one Pint and half of Ale Barm, or YeÅ¿t, which muÅ¿t be poured in by degrees as it works; when it hath Å¿tood all together a day and a night, Tun it up together in an Earthen Pot that hath a Spigot, and hang in it a bag with Nutmeg, Ginger, and Cinnamon, quartered or Å¿liced; if the weather be cold, cover it; it muÅ¿t Å¿tand till the Barm begins to Å¿hrink from the Å¿ides, which will be in eight or ten days; then Bottle it, and let it Å¿tand all night, with Corks put looÅ¿ly in; the next day give them Air, and knock them down; if the Weather be hot, put them in the Cellar,
otherwiÅ¿e in Å¿ome warmer place to ripen, it will be ready to drink in a Month.
You may this way make Metheglin by adding a grater quantity of Honey; and the Å¿ame is highly commended.

Of Birch Wine.Â§. 21. You may eaÅ¿ily extract great quantities of the juice of the Birch-tree by cutting off the ends of the Boughs of the Tree, and hanging Bottles thereon, leaving the ends of the Boughs fit to go into the Bottles mouths, and the Liquor will therein diÅ¿til. Or with more eaÅ¿e cut a Swan or GooÅ¿e quill at one end, in the Å¿hape of an Apple Å¿coop or Apple Scraper, and with a Gymblet make a hole in the body of the Birch-tree, and put in this Quill with the mouth upwards, and Å¿et a Pot under the other end of the Quill, and great quantities of the juice or Liquor will fall thorough the Quill into the Pot; but that Liquor which comes from the Branches, being better and longer digeÅ¿ted, is better than that which comes from the Trunk of the Tree. And this is only to be done from the end of February, to the end of March, of this Liquor or juice of the Birch is made a very wholÅ¿ome and medicinable Wine in this manner, viz.

To every Gallon of the Liquor add a pound of refined Sugar, and boil it about a quarter or half an hour, then Å¿et it to cool, and add a very little YeaÅ¿t to it, and
it will Ferment and thereby purge it Å¿elf from that little droÅ¿s, the Liquor and Sugar can yield; then put it in a Barrel, and add thereto a Å¿mall proportion of Cynnamon and Mace bruiÅ¿ed, about half an Ounce of both to ten Gallons; then Å¿top it very cloÅ¿e, and about a Month after Bottle it, and in a few days you'l have a moÅ¿t delicate Wine of a Flavour like unto RheniÅ¿h: It's Spirits are Å¿o Volatile that they are apt to break the Bottles, unleÅ¿s placed in a Refrigeratory, and when poured out, it gives a White head in the GlaÅ¿s. This Liquor is not of long duration unleÅ¿s preÅ¿erved very cool. InÅ¿tead of every pound of Sugar, if you add a quart of Live Honey and boil it as before, and adding Spice, and Fermenting it as you Å¿hould do Metheglin, it makes an admired Drink, both pleaÅ¿ant and medicinable.
Ale Brewed of the juice or Sap of the Birch-tree is eÅ¿teemed very wholeÅ¿ome.
Birch Wine, as alÅ¿o Birch Ale, are excellent remedies againÅ¿t the Stone; Van Helmont being the firÅ¿t that diÅ¿coved it's vertue, mightily commends it.

If when you make your Metheglin you uÅ¿e the juice of the Birch inÅ¿tead of Water, and when Barrell'd, you for every Gallon of the Liquor hang four Ounces of Daucus Seed, Å¿omething bruiÅ¿ed in a bag in the Liquor,
it's Å¿aid to be very good for the Stone.

Profits of Planting.Â§. 22. The advantage in Planting Trees may thus eaÅ¿ily be computed, viz. An Acre of Ground (accounting eight yards to the Pole or Perch) will take about 160 Trees, which may be Å¿et at diÅ¿tance enough; which Trees if bought, and not raiÅ¿ed by your Å¿elf, may be had for about Å¿ix pounds, when Å¿et and Å¿taked; the yearly proÅ¿it of the herbage or Tillage of this Acre of Ground for the firÅ¿t Å¿even year â¢ after Planting, may well be employed in digging about the Roots of the Trees, carrying off convenient and proper Soil, or CompoÅ¿t for them, mantaining the Fences, paying duties, &c. At the Å¿even year â¢ end, theÅ¿e 160 Trees, one Tree with another, will yield a BuÅ¿hel (accounting 32 Quarts to the BuÅ¿hel) of Apples ãâã Tree, altho Å¿ome of them may have periÅ¿hed, and others as yet but young raiÅ¿ed in their places, yet may Å¿ome of theÅ¿e Trees at Å¿even years growth, bear two or three BuÅ¿hels, and Å¿ome a BuÅ¿hel and an half, which may in the whole amount to one hundred and Å¿ixty BuÅ¿hels, which at Å¿ix pence per BuÅ¿hel is four Pound; the Herbage then will be worth at leaÅ¿t thirty Shillings per Annum, altho the Ground were worth leÅ¿s before it was Planted; the eighth or ninth year your Trees may one with another, and one year with another
yield you at leaÅ¿t two or three BuÅ¿hels on a Tree, and Å¿ometimes more, which at Å¿o low a rate, your Å¿ix Pound firÅ¿t expended, and the forbearance of the profit of your Land, and intereÅ¿t of your Money for Å¿even years, will bring you at leaÅ¿t eight Pounds per Annum, the Herbage being Å¿till allowed, for the maintenance of your Plantation; but if a good Fruit year happen, and your 160 Trees yield you Å¿ix or Å¿even hundred BuÅ¿hels, and thoÅ¿e worth twelve pence, or eight pence the BuÅ¿hel, it will in one year more then retaliate all your paÅ¿t labour, charge and loÅ¿s, and your Å¿elf will be furniÅ¿hed with an excellent Orchard, very Å¿erviceable to your Family both in baking, and making Å¿trong, and Å¿mall Cyder for your Table, and thereby Å¿aving great quantities of Malt.

A BuÅ¿hel and half, or 48 Quarts of Apples will make 18, 20, 22, or Å¿omtimes 24. Quarts of Cyder, according to the goodneÅ¿s of your Fruit for that purpoÅ¿e, and there will alÅ¿o be Å¿o much Cyderkin made of the Pouz, or Murc, as will be better worth than the charge of Grinding and PreÅ¿Å¿ing, &c. Twenty BuÅ¿hels commonly make a HogÅ¿head of Cyder.

They that are deÅ¿irous to underÅ¿tand the ordering of a Garden, either for the Kitchin, or Flowers, let them peruÅ¿e a Book call'd, The EngliÅ¿h Gardiner, writ by Leonard
Meagar, and therein they'l find both ample and true inÅ¿tructions.

Altho there is no Liquor, Drink, or Diet alike pleaÅ¿ant to all; Å¿ome preferring Dull Coffee before any other, Å¿ome Å¿tale Beer, others fat Ale, or Mum; one Claret, another Sack; yet our EngliÅ¿h know no other Drink Å¿o generally palatable as Cyder, becauÅ¿e it may be made Å¿uit with any humourous Drinker. It's made LuÅ¿cious by the addition of a good quantity of Å¿weet Apples at the Grinding; pleaÅ¿ant, being made with Pippins or Genent-Moyls; Racy, Poignant, Oyly, Spicy, and Rich, with the RedÅ¿treak, and Å¿everal other Å¿orts of Fruits, even as the Operator pleaÅ¿es. And it Å¿atisfies thirÅ¿t, if not too Å¿tale, more than any other uÅ¿ual Drink whatÅ¿oever; and in Å¿uch years as Corn is dear, the beÅ¿t Cyder may be made at a far eaÅ¿ier rate than ordinary Ale. The conÅ¿iderations whereof adds much to the exhilerating virtue of this Drink.

Next unto Cyder, Perry claims the precedency, eÅ¿pecially if made of the beÅ¿t juicy Pears celebrated for that purpoÅ¿e, as the Bosbery-Pear, Bareland-Pear, the Red and White HorÅ¿e-Pear, or many Å¿orts of wild and choak Pears, but above all the Turgovian Pear.

Wines or Drinks made of Currans, Goosberries, Rasberries, Blackberries, Cherries, or Plums, prepared and made as is before taught, may be more acceptable
to our Palats, healthy, pleaÅ¿ant, and profitable than thoÅ¿e exotick Wines many are Å¿o fond of and Dote on.

And in this very year 1682, I know Wine made of the White Dutch Curran, according to the direction of the 15 Sect. of this Chap. (only there was but a Pint of Water added to each Quart of the Fruit) far Å¿uperiour to the beÅ¿t French White Whine could be bought in our Country, if Å¿everal judicious Palats were not miÅ¿taken.
