div.head: An Abridgment of the Statutes of 43, Eliz. Cap. 7. and 15, Car. 2. Cap. 2.
div.p:
Laws againÅ¿t breaking Orchards and Å¿tealing Trees and Wood, &c. IF any Å¿hall be Convicted by his own ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, or by the TeÅ¿timony of one WitneÅ¿s upon Oath, before one JuÅ¿tice of Peace, or Head Officer, to have unlawfully cut and taken away, any Grain growing, robbed any Orchard or Garden, digged up or taken away any Fruit Trees, broken any Hedges, Pales, or other Fences, cut or Å¿poiled any Woods or under Woods, Å¿tanding and growing, or the like, or to have been acceÅ¿Å¿ary thereunto, Å¿hall for the firÅ¿t offence pay unto the party grieved, Å¿uch damages and within Å¿uch time, as by the Å¿aid JuÅ¿tice, or head Officer Å¿hall be appointed: And in caÅ¿e the pary offending Å¿hall not by the Å¿aid JuÅ¿tice or Officer, be thought able to diÅ¿charge the Å¿ade damages, or Å¿hall not diÅ¿charge them according to the Å¿aid Order, then Å¿hall
the Å¿aid Offender be by them, or either of them (reÅ¿pectivly) committed to the ConÅ¿table, or other Officer of the place, where the Offence was commited, or the party apprehended, to be Whipped, and for every other offence committed afterwards, and proved as aforeÅ¿aid, the party offending Å¿hall receive the like puniÅ¿hment of Whipping.

The ConÅ¿table, or other inferior Officer that herein refuÅ¿eth or neglecteth to do his duty, Å¿hall by any Å¿uch JuÅ¿tice of Peace or Head Officer be committed to PriÅ¿on without Bail, till he Whip, or cauÅ¿e to be Whipped the party offending, as is above limited.

No JuÅ¿tice of Peace Å¿hall execute this Statute for Offences done to him Å¿elf, unleÅ¿s he be AÅ¿Å¿ociated with one or more JuÅ¿tices of Peace, whom the Offence doth not concern. Vid. the Statute of 43. Eliz. Cap. 7. at large.

Statute, 15. Car. 2. Cap. 2. reciting the Statute of 43. Eliz. Cap. 7. doth not Å¿ufficiently prevent, nor puniÅ¿h the Cutting and Å¿poiling of Woods, Enacts, that ever ConÅ¿table, Headborough,
and other perÅ¿on in every County, City, or other place, where they Å¿hall be Officers or Inhabitants, Å¿hall and may Apprehend, or cauÅ¿e to be Apprehended, every perÅ¿on they Å¿hall Å¿uÅ¿pect having, carrying, or conveying, any burden or Bundle of Wood, Poles, young Trees, Bark, BaÅ¿t of Trees, Gates, Stiles, PoÅ¿ts, Pales, Rails, or Hedg-wood, Broom, or Furze.

And by Warrant under the hand and Seal of any one JuÅ¿tice of the Peace, directed to any Officer, Å¿uch Officer may enter into, and Å¿earch the HouÅ¿es, Yards, Gardens, and other places belonging to the HouÅ¿e or HouÅ¿es, of every perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons they Å¿hall Å¿uÅ¿pect to have any kind of Å¿uch Wood, or other the Å¿aid Trees, &c. and where they Å¿hall find any Å¿uch, to apprehend evey perÅ¿on Å¿uÅ¿pected for Cutting and taking the Å¿ame, and as well thoÅ¿e apprehended carrying any kind of Wood or other Trees and premiÅ¿Å¿es; as thoÅ¿e in whoÅ¿e HouÅ¿es or other places belonging to them, any of the Å¿ame Å¿hall be found to carry before any one JuÅ¿tice of the Peace of the Å¿ame County: and Å¿uch perÅ¿ons Å¿uÅ¿pected do not give a good accompt how they came by the
Å¿ame by the conÅ¿ent of the owner, Å¿uch as Å¿hall Å¿atisfy the Å¿aid JuÅ¿tice, or within Å¿ome convenient time to be Å¿et by the Å¿aid JuÅ¿tice, produce the party of whom they bought the Å¿aid Wood, or Å¿ome credible witneÅ¿s upon Oath, to prove Å¿uch Å¿ale, which Oath the Å¿aid JuÅ¿tice may AdminÅ¿ter, then Å¿uch perÅ¿ons Å¿o Å¿uÅ¿pected, and not giving Å¿uch good accompt, nor, producing Å¿uch witneÅ¿s, Å¿hall be adjudged as convicted, for cutting and Å¿poiling of Woods, Æ²nderwoods, Poles, Trees, Gates, Stiles, PoÅ¿ts, Pales, Rails, Hedg-wood, Broom, or Furze, within the meaning of the Statute of Queen Elizabeth, and lyable to the PuniÅ¿hments therein, and of this Act appointed.

Every perÅ¿on Å¿o Convicted, Å¿hall for the firÅ¿t offence, give the owner Å¿atisfaction for his damages, within Å¿uch time as the JuÅ¿tice Å¿hall appoint, and over and above, pay down to the OverÅ¿eers of the Poor of the PariÅ¿h where Å¿uch offence is, Å¿uch Å¿umm of Money (not exceeding ten Å¿hillings) as the JuÅ¿tice Å¿hall think meet, in defalt of either of which payments, the Å¿aid JuÅ¿tice may commit Juch offender
to the HouÅ¿e of Correction for Å¿uch time (not exceeding one Month) as he Å¿hall think fit, or to be Whipt by the ConÅ¿table or other Officer, as in his judgment Å¿hall Å¿eem expedient.

And If Å¿uch perÅ¿on Å¿hall again commit the Å¿aid offence, and be thereof Convicted as before, that then the perÅ¿ons offending the Å¿econd time, and Convicted, Å¿hall be Å¿ent to the HouÅ¿e of Correction for one Month, and there be kept to hard labour, and for the third offence, Convicted as before, Å¿hall be judged and deemed as incorrigible Rogues.

Provided alÅ¿o whoever Å¿hall buy any Burdens, or any the premiÅ¿Å¿es mentioned in this Bill Å¿uÅ¿pected to be Stolen, or unlawfully come by, the JuÅ¿tices, Mayors, or chief Officers, or any one of them within their reÅ¿pective juriÅ¿dictions, upon complaint may examine the matter upon Oath, and if they find the Å¿ame was bought of any Å¿uÅ¿pected to have Stolen, or unlawfully come by the Å¿ame, then any one of the Å¿aid JuÅ¿tices or chief Officers, Å¿hall and may award the party that bought the Å¿ame, to pay treble the vavalue
thereof to the party from whom the Å¿ame was Stolen or unlawfully taken, and in default of preÅ¿ent payment, to IÅ¿Å¿ue out their reÅ¿pective Warrants to levy the Å¿ame by diÅ¿treÅ¿s, and Sale of the Offenders Goods, rendring the overplus to the party, and in default of Å¿uch diÅ¿treÅ¿s to commit the party to the Goal, at his own charge, there to remain one Month without Bail.
Provided no perÅ¿on be queÅ¿tioned for any offence within this Act, unleÅ¿s within Å¿ix weekes after the Offence committed.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Brief Monthly Memorials for the Planter.
JANVARY.
div.p:
DIg, Trench, and Dung Ground, and make it ready for the Spring; prepare Soil, dig Borders; uncover as yet the Roots of old unthriving, or over-haÅ¿ty Blooming Trees; Plant QuickÅ¿ets, tranÅ¿plant Fruit-trees, if not finiÅ¿hed; Å¿et Vines, and Prune the old; Prune eÅ¿pecially the Branches of old Planted Fruit-trees, about the decreaÅ¿e of the Moon; but Prune not the newly Planted till the Sap begin to Å¿tir. CleanÅ¿e Trees from MoÅ¿s, the Weather moiÅ¿t. Nail and trim the Wall-fruit-trees, and EÅ¿palirs. Gather towards the end of the Month Cyons for Grafts of Cherries, Plums, and Pears, before they begin to Å¿prout and any Å¿peck of White appears on the Buds, if the Weather be open. In over-wet or hard Weather cleanÅ¿e, mend, Å¿harpen and prepare all your Grafting and Garden Tools: DeÅ¿troy Vermin in your
Seminary of Kernels and Stones for Stocks.

div.head: FEBRÆ²ARY.
div.p:
COntinue yet to Prune Fruit-trees, and bind, PlaiÅ¿h, Nail, and dreÅ¿s the moÅ¿t delicate Wall-fruit, if not finiÅ¿hed before, but be exceeding careful of injuring the Å¿welling Buds, and Bearers; cut and lay Quick-Å¿ets, trim up the Hedges and eÅ¿paliers; Plant Vines as yet and Hops; Å¿et Kernels, and Stones of all Å¿orts. Sow and Å¿et Beans, Peas, RadiÅ¿h, ParÅ¿nips, Carrots, Onions, Garlick. Now is the Å¿eaÅ¿on for circumpoÅ¿ition by Tubs or BaÅ¿kets of Earth, and laying of Branches to take Root; rub MoÅ¿s from your Trees after a Å¿oaking Rain, and Å¿crape and cleanÅ¿e them of Cankers, draining away the Wet (if need require) from the too much moiÅ¿tened Roots. Mold and Earth up the Roots of Å¿uch Fruit-trees as were bared. Pull off the Webs of Caterpillars from the Tops and Twigs of Trees, and burn them. Gather Worms in the Evening after Rain. Plant Cabbage Plants, Colliflowers, ParÅ¿ly, Spinage and other hardy Pot-herbs. Graft Cherries, Plums, and Pears, and towards the end of the Month, Apples if a forward Spring. Get Cyons for Apple-grafts. You may yet tranÅ¿plant Trees, tho it had been better done in October, or November. Slit almoÅ¿t
through, the Bark, your Bark-bound and Canker'd Trees. Plant Potatos, but not amongÅ¿t your Fruit-trees.

div.head: MARCH.
div.p:
DUnging is yet Å¿eaÅ¿onable, and you may tranÅ¿plant what Trees are yet left, tho it be dangerous and full late enough, unleÅ¿s in very backward, or moiÅ¿t places. You may Graft' Apples all this Month, and in the begining of it Plums, Cherries, and Pears; you may as yet cut QuickÅ¿ets, and cover Å¿uch Tree-roots as were bared in Autumn. Prune laÅ¿t years Grafts, and cut off the heads of your Budded Stocks. Now is beÅ¿t time for raiÅ¿ing on Hot Beds, Melons, Cucumbers, Gourds. Slip and Å¿et Sage, RoÅ¿emary, Lavender, Thyme, &c. Sow in the beginning Endive, Succory, Leeks, RadiÅ¿h, Beets, Chardbeet, Scorzonera, ParÅ¿nips, Skerrets, ParÅ¿ley, Sorrel, BugloÅ¿s, Borrage, Chervil, Sellery, Smallage, AliÅ¿anders, &c. Sow alÅ¿o Lettuce, Onions, Garlick, Orach, PurÅ¿lane, Turneps, to have early, Beans, and Peas towards the full Moon, Carrots, Cabbages, CreÅ¿Å¿es, Fennel, Majoran, Dill, ScurvygraÅ¿s. Set Cabbage-plants, and Colliflowers. TranÅ¿plant any Å¿ort of Pot or Medicinal Herbs; Mid-march dreÅ¿s up and Å¿tring your Strawberry Beds. Uncover AÅ¿paragus, and TranÅ¿plant AÅ¿paragus-roots to make new Beds. This is the prime
Month for Botling Cyder, and if you put in about half a Å¿poonful of Spirit of Clary, it will make the Liquor Å¿o perfectly to reÅ¿emble the very beÅ¿t Canary, that few good and exerciÅ¿ed Palats will be able to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h it. Set Potatos, but not amongÅ¿t your Fruit-trees; Sets them thus, Plow or Dig Ground into Buts or Borders about Å¿ix Foot broad, but leave two Foot intervals; then Harrow or Rake it well, then Å¿pread Rotten Dung thereon, on the top whereof lay Potato Sets, then Shovel up the Earth in the intervals, and cover the Sets two or three Inches thick. MoÅ¿t Å¿orts of Sallet, Pot, and Å¿weet Herbs may be Å¿own from the firÅ¿t of March, to the end of July, and moÅ¿ts Å¿orts of Å¿etting Herbs may be removed, Å¿lipt and parted the Å¿ame time.

div.head: APRIL.
div.p:
PLant Artichock Slips, Å¿et great Beans, and Å¿ow Carrots; if the Spring be not forward you may yet Graft Apples in the beginning of the Month. Gather Worms, Snails, after evening Å¿howers and after all the Summer Rains: and deÅ¿troy Caterpillare Webs, and Å¿moak Caterpillars and black Flies from your Trees. Mow Carpet Walks. Weed your Currans, Goosberries, &c. From the beginning to the middle Å¿et Potatos, but not amongÅ¿t Fruit-trees. You may yet Å¿lip Lavender, Thyme, RoÅ¿emary, &c. Towards the middle begin
to Plant forth your Melons, Cucumbers and Å¿o to the later end, your Ridges well prepared. Sow Å¿weet Majoran, HyÅ¿Å¿op, BaÅ¿il, Winter Savory, Scurvy-graÅ¿s, Lettuce, PurÅ¿lane, Coliflowers, RadiÅ¿h, Thyme, and all fine and tender Seeds. Clip Shrubs after Å¿howers.

div.head: MAY.
div.p: COntinue your Weeding before they run to Seeds, and with Sheers top your Currans, and Goosberries. Sow Å¿weet Majoran, BaÅ¿il, Thyme, hot and Aromatick Herbs and plants which are moÅ¿t tender. Sow PurÅ¿lane to have young, Lettuce, large Å¿ided Cabbage, Painted Beans. Look to your Melons, and towards the end of the Month forbear any longer to cover them.

div.head: JÆ²NE.
div.p: SOw Lettuce, Chervil, RadiÅ¿h, &c. to have young and tender Salleting, Spinage. CleanÅ¿e Vines of exuberant Branches cropping not cutting, and Å¿hopping the joint immediately before they BloÅ¿Å¿om, and Å¿ome of the under Branches that bear no Fruit, eÅ¿pecially in young Vineyards when they firÅ¿t begin to bear, and thence forwards. Gather Herbs in the full to keep dry, they keep and retain their Virtue and Å¿weet Å¿mell better dry'd in the Sun, than Å¿hade, whatever Å¿ome pretend.

About a fortnight before and as much after MidÅ¿ummer are the chief and beÅ¿t times to Inoculate Peaches, Apricocks, Cherries, Plums, Pears, Nectarins, and Apples. Water lately Planted Trees, and put moiÅ¿t and half rotten Fearn, Weeds, and Vegatables about the foot of their Stems. Continue Weeding, and gather Snails after Rain. Unbind thoÅ¿e Grafts you bound. About 14 days before or after MidÅ¿ummer, Å¿ow Turneps upon Ground prepared as for Barley; after MidÅ¿ummer makes the better Turnep. Three Pints of Seed will Å¿ow an Acre, accounting Å¿even yards to the Pole; your Seed is to be mixed with dry Sand thus, Three Å¿poonfuls of Seed with a peck of Sand, then Å¿ow; if immediately after Å¿owing a Å¿hower of Rain and hot Sungleams happen, it's Å¿poil'd.

div.head: JÆ²LY.
div.p:
SOw Lettuce, RadiÅ¿h, Spinage, &c. for late and tender Salletting. Sow later Peas to be ripe Å¿ix weeks after Michaelmas. Water young Planted Trees and Layers. Prune now Apricocks, and Peaches, Å¿aving as many of the young likelieÅ¿t Shoots as are well placed, for the now bearers commonly periÅ¿h the new ones Å¿ucceeding: Cut cloÅ¿e and even. Let Å¿uch Pot-herbs run to Seed as you would Å¿ave. About the eighth Inoculate Å¿uch Fruits as in June are directed, and Å¿ow Turneps
alÅ¿o then and towards the full Moon. Towards the later end viÅ¿it your Vineyards again, and Å¿top the exuberant Shoots above the Fruit, but Å¿o as not to expoÅ¿e them to the Sun. Search under Wall-tree-leaves for Snails, they Å¿tick commonly about the Fruit, pull not off what is bitten, for then the'l begin afreÅ¿h. Now (in the drieÅ¿t Å¿eaÅ¿on) with Brine, Pot AÅ¿hes and Water, or a decoction of Tobacco refuÅ¿e, Water your Gravel Walks, &c. to deÅ¿troy both Worms, and Weeds, of which it will cure them for Å¿ome years. Continue Weeding; gather Currans to make Wine of. Make ready your Cyder Mill and PreÅ¿s, &c.

div.head: AÆ²GÆ²ST.
div.p:
INoculate now early if you began not before. Prune off yet Å¿uperfluous Branches and Shoots of this Å¿econd Spring, but leave Å¿ome Leaves to Å¿creen the Fruit from the Sun, furniÅ¿hing and nailing what you will Å¿pare to cover the defects of your Walls. Pull up the Suckers. Sow RadiÅ¿hes, tender Cabbages, Colleflowers for Winter Plants, Corn-Å¿allet, Marigold, Lettuce, Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, Turnips, Spinage, Onions, alÅ¿o curl'd Endive, Angelica, Scurvy-graÅ¿s, &c. pull up ripe Onions and Garlick, &c. Towards the end Å¿ow PurÅ¿lan, Chard, Beet, Chervil, &c. TranÅ¿plant Å¿uch Lettuce as you'l have abide all Winter. Gather your Olitory Seeds,
and clip and cut all Å¿uch Herbs and Plants within one handful of the Ground. Before the full, unbind and releaÅ¿e the Buds you Inoculated. Gather, your Windfal Apples from day to day, if the Weather be dry. Make Summer Perry and Cyder.

div.head: SEPTEMBER.
div.p: GAther now (if ripe) your Winter-fruit as Plums, Pears, Apples, &c. to prevent their falling by great Winds, alÅ¿o in dry Weather gather Wind-falls from day to day. Sow Lettuce, RadiÅ¿h, Spinage, ParÅ¿nips, Skerrets, Colle-flowers, Cabbages, Onions, Scurvy-graÅ¿s, AnniÅ¿eeds, and Winter Herbs. Now you may TranÅ¿plant moÅ¿t Å¿ort of EÅ¿culent and PhyÅ¿ical Plants, Artichocks, and AÅ¿paragus Roots. Sow Winter Herbs and Roots, and Plant Strawberries out of the Woods: Towards the end Earth up your Winter Plants, and Sallet Herbs, and Plant forth your Colle-flowers, and Cabbages Å¿own in AuguÅ¿t. With a pair of Sheers top Currans, and Goosberries, dig about, Manure and Mold up their Roots towards the end. Make Perry and Cyder.

div.head: OCTOBER.
div.p: TRench, Dig, and Manure Ground for Orchading, and Kitchin. Garden to lye for a Winter Mellowing. Plant and Å¿et Fruit-Trees of all Å¿orts, Standard, Mural, or Shrubs, which loÅ¿e their Leaf, and that as Å¿oon as it falls. ChooÅ¿e no Tree for the Wall above two years Grafting at moÅ¿t. Now is the time for laying bare old unthriving, or over-haÅ¿ty Blooming Trees. The Moon decreaÅ¿ing, gather the remaining Winter-fruit in dry Weather, lay them up clean, leÅ¿t they taint; Plant and PlaÅ¿h QuickÅ¿ets. Sow all Stoney and hard Kernels and Seeds, Å¿uch as Cherry, Pear, Plum, Peach, Almond-Å¿tones, &c. AlÅ¿o all Å¿orts of Nuts, Haws, AÅ¿hen, Sycamore, and Mapple-keys; Acorns, Beech-maÅ¿t, Apple, Pear, and Crab-Kernel for Stocks; or you may defer it till towards the later end of the next Month. Keep your Stones and Nuts in Sand till Å¿et. Yet Å¿ow Lettuce. Make Winter Cyder, and Perry. Sow as in September. Sweep and cleanÅ¿e your Walks of Autumnal fallen Leaves.

div.head: NOVEMBER.
div.p:
Carry CompoÅ¿t out of your Melon Ground, or turn and mingle it with the Earth, and lay it in Ridges ready for the Spring; Trench and fit Ground for Artichocks,
Mold them up, and cover them in the beginning of FroÅ¿ts with HorÅ¿e-dung. Continue Å¿etting and TranÅ¿planting Trees; loÅ¿e no time, hard FroÅ¿ts come on a pace; yet you may lay bare old Trees. Plant young Trees, Standard, or Mural. FurniÅ¿h your NurÅ¿ery with all Å¿orts of Stocks to Graft in. Sow and Å¿et early Beans, and Peas till Mid-March. Now lay up in your Cellars for Seed to be TranÅ¿planted at Spring, Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, Cabages, Colliflowers, &c. In a dry day gather your laÅ¿t Orchard Fruits. Take up your Potatos for Winter Å¿pending, there will enough remain for Stocks, tho never Å¿o exactly gatherd, Å¿ave the Å¿mall ones for Sets. Cut off the tops of AÅ¿paragus and cover them with long Dung, or make Beds to Plant in Spring. Set yet all Å¿orts of Kernels and Stones to raiÅ¿e Stocks for NurÅ¿ery. In FroÅ¿ts Cover the Windows of your Fruit Room, and the Fruits, with Mats of Straw, &c.

Now order Turneps for Seed thus, viz. about the Tenth get up Å¿ome of your largeÅ¿t and beÅ¿t Turneps, (20, will yield about a Quart of Seed) but waÅ¿h them not, then cut off the top of the BuÅ¿h or Stalk, leaving five or Å¿ix Inches to grow to the Turnep, lay theÅ¿e about 14 days in a cool Room, then prepare a convenient Plot of Ground by Diging and Trenching good Å¿tore of rotten Muck, then Å¿et Turneps
half a yard diÅ¿tant from each other, and Mould up the Earth three Inches high on the Stalk about each; in April, place Å¿mall HaÅ¿el Rails about them to keep them up, and thy'l be Seed in June, if you can preÅ¿erve them from Birds, which is done by placing a live Catling tied near i â¢ daily fed with Milk, and the old ones reÅ¿orting to it. If you Å¿et not theÅ¿e Turneps till January, the Seed produces a Watery, but larger Turnep. Take up Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, &c. to be kept in Cellars in Sand for Å¿pending.

div.head: DECEMBER.
div.p: PRune and Nail Wall-fruit and Standard-trees, and Plant Vines, &c. AlÅ¿o Stocks for Grafting. Sow and Å¿et all Å¿orts of Kernels, Seeds, and Stones; Trench Ground and Dung it, to be ready for Bordures or Planting of Fruit-trees. Turn and refreÅ¿h your Autumnal Fruits, leÅ¿t they taint, and open the Windows where they lye in a clear and Å¿erene day. PreÅ¿erve your Fruit from FroÅ¿ts.

Let Planters note that the Wood of the Pear-tree, Plum-tree, Black-cherry-tree, Walnut-tree, and CheÅ¿nut-tree, are excellent for Stools, Chairs, Tables, Cabinets, and many other Works for the
Joyner, and Sculptor; and tho the Wood of Å¿ome of them be Å¿ubject to the Worm and putrefaction, that may be both prevented, and cured if not too far gone, by anointing three or four times with LinÅ¿eed Oyle; it has been experimented in a Walnut Table, where it deÅ¿troy'd Millions of Worms immediately, and is to be practtiÅ¿ed for Tables, Tubes, Boxes, Mathematical InÅ¿truments, BedÅ¿teds, Chairs, Rarities, &c. Oyl. of Walnuts will do the Å¿ame, is Å¿weeter and a better VerniÅ¿h, but above all is commended Oyl of Cedar, or that of Juniper. But the more curious may uÅ¿e this great Å¿ecret (diÅ¿cover'd by Mr. Evelin, Page, 70 of his Sylva) viz. put common Yellow Sulphur into a Cucurbit GlaÅ¿s, upon which pour Å¿o much of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Aqua Fortis, as may cover it three fingers deep, diÅ¿til this to dryneÅ¿s, which is done by two or three Rectifications: Let the Sulphur remaining in the bottom (being of a BlackiÅ¿h or Å¿ad Red Colour) be laid on a Marble, or put into a GlaÅ¿s where it will eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿Å¿olve into Oyl: With this Anoint either what is infected, or to be preÅ¿erved of Tymber, it tinges Wood with no unpleaÅ¿ant Colour, by no Art to be WaÅ¿hed out, and Å¿uch a preÅ¿ervation of all manner of Woods, nay of many other
things as Ropes, Cables, FiÅ¿hing-nets, MaÅ¿ts of Ships, &c. That it defends them from putrefaction, either in Waters, under, or above the Earth, in the Snow, Ice, Air, Winter or Summer, &c.

div.head: ADDENDA.
div.p: 1. TO the end of the firÅ¿t Chapter, Å¿hould have been added the following, viz. And when Stocks are removed out of the Seminary into the NurÅ¿ery, or elÅ¿where, be Å¿ure to cut off as well the greateÅ¿t part of the down right Tap, or Heart-root of Stocks; as alÅ¿o the ends of all other Roots, and then to Å¿et them as Å¿hallow as poÅ¿Å¿ible, Å¿o as they may be able to take good Rooting.

2. AT the end of the 6th Sect. in Chap. Second, this Å¿hould have been added, viz. Be Å¿ure therefore to let your Stocks for Pears and Apples be well grown before they are Grafted, that they may be able to make Å¿trong, and tall Shoots the firÅ¿t year after Grafted; for if Grafted the Å¿ame year they are removed, or the next year, not one of many makes a good Tree; beÅ¿ides there are Å¿everal Å¿orts of Fruit-trees, as Pearmains, Winter-queenings, and July-flower-apples, &c. that will not make a Tree worth your labour, unleÅ¿s Grafted on a luÅ¿ty plump Stock; becauÅ¿e they naturally
Shoot weak and crooked; Å¿o divers Å¿orts of Pears, of which the Wardens are the worÅ¿t to make a handÅ¿ome Tree of.

3. AT the end of the firÅ¿t Sect. in Chap. Å¿eventh, the following Å¿hould have been added, viz. And indeed all Land proper for Corn, as Wheat, Barley, Rye, Beans, and PeeÅ¿e are proper for Fruit-trees: but the moÅ¿t improper are extream hot and dry Sands, and on the other Å¿ide grounds very Wet and cold.
4. AT the end of the Å¿eventh Chap. page 86, the following Sect. Å¿hould have been added, viz.

Â§. 23. After your Trees are tranÅ¿planted into Orchards, the greateÅ¿t care and charge is to keep them Å¿afe from being abuÅ¿ed, either by Weeds that may grow about them, Suckers that may grow out of them, between the Roots, and Å¿preading Boughs, and from all Cattle, Hares, Coneys, and Canker (for which Å¿ome affirm Hogsdung either mixed with the Earth, or Å¿ome laid on the top about the Å¿tem to be an excellent remedy) and in caÅ¿e where they are digged or Plowed about the Roots, your Trees will thrive much better, and grow twice as faÅ¿t.

5. IN Page 99, at the end of the tenth Sect. the following Å¿hould have been added, viz. ObÅ¿erve in Å¿etting Fruit-trees to cut off the greateÅ¿t part of the downright Tap, or Heart-root, and alÅ¿o the ends of all the other Roots of the Tree, and let not the top of the uppermoÅ¿t Roots be above two Inches under the Surface, and the bottom of the Roots not more than nine or ten Inches below the Surface of the Earth; and if the Hole the Tree is to be Å¿et in, be digged deep, and fill'd up again with good Earth before the Tree is Planted (unleÅ¿s the Earth be very well trod down) the Tree and all will Å¿inck together, and never proÅ¿per: therefore in Å¿uch a caÅ¿e, 'its beÅ¿t to Å¿et the Tree Å¿o Å¿hallow as to raiÅ¿e the Earth Å¿ix or Å¿even Inches above the Roots about the Å¿tem, and to cover the uppermoÅ¿t Roots with good Earth, to prevent that misfortune.

6. AT the end of the third line in Page 163, the following Å¿hould have been added, viz. You may alÅ¿o obtain many excellent Sets of Currans and Goosberries, if in January, or beginning of February, when the weather is open, you lay down Å¿everal Limbs and Twiggs of them, flat and cloÅ¿e to the Earth, and Å¿o keep them down by a hooked Å¿tick driven into the Earth, or a Brick Å¿tove; then cover every Limb and Twigg Å¿o laid down, all along
two Inches thick with good Earth, except the top Branch or Twigg, which muÅ¿t lye, out and be uncover'd, and by that time the next year, you'l have abundance of well Rooted Plants, fit to tranÅ¿plant: take care to keep that part of the uncover'd Stock, which is between the old Root and the Cover'd part, that it run not out in Buds or Branches, for if it do, the Twigs will be rob'd of that nouriÅ¿hment which Å¿hould feed them: AlÅ¿o remember to keep them clear of all GraÅ¿s and Weeds that may in the leaÅ¿t annoy them.

7. AT the end of the 22 Chap. Page 167, the following Å¿hould have been added, viz. Peaches and Nectarins are Propagated only by Inoculating, and that on Stocks raiÅ¿ed either on Peach-Å¿tones, or Plum-Å¿tones; But obÅ¿erve that Stocks raiÅ¿ed of Peach-Å¿tones will be Å¿ooner ready to Inoculate, and the Buds will take very Å¿ure that are Inoculated into them; but they muÅ¿t be carefully and tenderly uÅ¿ed in the removal, and muÅ¿t not be expected to make long laÅ¿ting Trees.
Stocks from Plum-Å¿tones, and Budded with a Peach will make a more firm and laÅ¿ting Peach-tree; and Å¿uch as will bear Fruit well.

Therefore rather raiÅ¿e Stocks for Peaches, Nectarins, Apricocks, and Plums from Stones of the Wheat-plum, which is a White Plum ripe in AuguÅ¿t, (if you can have them) or in want of them from the Stones of the White Pear-plum, which is generally commended and uÅ¿ed, or of other good White Plum whoÅ¿e Tree puts forth large Shoots or Branches.
The Suckers likewiÅ¿e from the Roots of the Å¿aid Wheat Plum make excellent Stocks for Peaches, Nectarins, Apricocks, and Dwarf and Wall Plum-trees.

8. AT the end of the 23 Chap. Page 169, the following Å¿hould have been added, viz. Strawberries are increaÅ¿ed by Å¿etting the young Roots, which increaÅ¿e from the Å¿trings which run from the elder Plants, they are to be found in Woods and Å¿uch like Places, from whence many provide themÅ¿elves as well as in Gardens; they are Planted at divers SeaÅ¿ons, but principally at the Spring and Fall; but many refuÅ¿e to Å¿et them in the Spring, becauÅ¿e then ther's a Summers Weeding, and little or no Fruit the firÅ¿t year, Å¿o that moÅ¿t Plant about the 24th of AuguÅ¿t, or Michaelmas, and Å¿ometimes later, but Å¿omething Å¿ooner is better; for then they'l have got Å¿trength, and bear
both more, and fairer Fruit. Set them about half a foot aÅ¿under, which is near enough; and if you'l have fair Fruit and your Bed laÅ¿t longer without renewing, or new Planting; often cut away the Å¿trings that run from the Roots, otherwiÅ¿e they'l Å¿tarve one another; alÅ¿o every Winter, not Summer, new mold them, and in dry Weather often Water them, chiefly in Blooming and Fruit time, but do it throughly; where not carefully looked after, a Bed of Strawberries laÅ¿ts not above two or three years at moÅ¿t.
The ordering of great Strawberries differs but little, only to be Å¿et at a larger diÅ¿tance, and the Root kept molded up, and the Stalks for Fruit tied up, and often Watered in dry Weather.

9. AT the end of the 25th Chap. page 174 the following Å¿hould have been added, viz. Cherries are propagated by Grafting or Inoculating on Stocks raiÅ¿ed from Cherry-Å¿tones, Å¿et or Å¿owed, or young wild Chery-trees got out of Woods, &c. or Suckers from the common harÅ¿h Red Cherry. The wild Stocks make large handÅ¿ome Standard. Trees, but though Grafted with a good kind, do not bear Fruit Å¿o plentifully as the Suckers of the Red being Grafted do, which
Suckers are fitteÅ¿t to Graft Cherries on for Wall or Dwarf-trees, being of much Å¿maller growth than thoÅ¿e of the wild kind are. No Fruit-trees proÅ¿per under the dripping of Walnut-trees, and Cherry-trees. Note that Suckers of Pears, Cherries, and Wheat Plums, make good Stocks to Graft Pears, Cherries, and Plums on, for Wall-trees, or Dwarf-trees.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THere are PerÅ¿ons who perÅ¿wade themÅ¿elves that its a crime to add any thing to Antiquity, and who Å¿ay, That nothing can be invented of new more than what the Ancients have Å¿aid; and that it is a vain Glory and PreÅ¿umption to imagine we can Å¿ay any thing which has not been written. But if it were free for me to AnÅ¿wer this Opinion, I would Å¿ay, That Arts are not of thoÅ¿e things to which nothing can be added, and that the Older the World grows, the more they are carryed on to perfection. Anatomy did not appear in Å¿o
great a LuÅ¿ter in the Time of Galen, as in our Days: and the Art of Pruning Fruit-trees was not Å¿o perfect in the Time of the Curate of Henonville, as at preÅ¿ent. We are like a Dwarf on a Giants Å¿houlders. We Å¿ee much farther than our Fathers, and we daily diÅ¿cover things which they knew not. I will not Å¿ay for this, that there are not any precepts or Rules found for Pruning Trees in the Books of Agriculture and Gardening which have been Printed within Twenty or Five and Twenty Years, I candidly own that there are Å¿ome; but in truth they are Å¿o few in Number, and the greateÅ¿t part Å¿o obÅ¿cure, and Å¿o little to be rely'd on, that I very much doubt whether they may be followed without committing faults. If on the contrary you Å¿tick to thoÅ¿e which I give in this Tract; many Years experience has aÅ¿Å¿ur'd me, that Trees Prun'd according
to the Rules which I EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h, will produce great Fruits in abundance. I have therefore reduc't The Art of Pruning Fruit-Trees into four Chapters; and I have caus'd Å¿even Figures to be Grav'd which I Judg'd neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the underÅ¿tanding of what I Å¿ay: The firÅ¿t Chapter Treats of Pruning Trees in the Month of February. The Å¿econd explains that of the beginning of May. The third teaches the Pruning at the end of May and the beginning of June. LaÅ¿tly the Fourth compriÅ¿es the Pruning of July. I thought fit to reduce this Book into a form of precepts, without forming a continued DiÅ¿courÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e often we have need of one precept, without having need of another: and I have writ it after Å¿o popular a manner that the moÅ¿t Illiterate Gardiners might comprehend what I would Å¿ay.

div.head: THE Art of Pruning, OR Lopping Fruit-Trees.

div.p: I SuppoÅ¿e that a Tree has been well Planted, and Å¿et in a fertile Soil, that the Root of it has been well cut, that good choice has been made of the Plant and of its kind; and that it has Å¿ome years Growth, to be able to endure the Pruning-knife.

div.head: CHAP. I. The Pruning or Lopping of Fruit-trees, for the Month of February.
div.p: ALmoÅ¿t all Trees begin to Å¿prout forth in France toward the end of February, or the beginning of March; and this is the motion which we call the riÅ¿e of the Sap, or the Å¿hooting of Trees. This nevertheleÅ¿s happens variouÅ¿ly, the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Air, the goodneÅ¿s of the Soil, the vigour or the kind of the Tree, make the Saps or Å¿hootings to come earlier or later: They come early in a dry year, and are backward in a moiÅ¿t.

This riÅ¿e of the Sap invites then Gardiners to Prune or Lop Trees in the Month of February, which is the moÅ¿t proper time for this work; and tho' it may be done all the Winter, however the Moon be diÅ¿pos'd, Trees being then at reÅ¿t as to their Branches; nevertheleÅ¿s it is much better to Å¿tay for this till the Colds are paÅ¿t, and that the Rains no longer infeÅ¿t the wounds which
are made on Trees; by this means they Å¿eal themÅ¿elves in a little time, and Å¿oonner cover the wound which has been made on them.

Before you Prune or Lop a Tree, you ought to conÅ¿ider the Å¿trength and kind of it for rendring it beautiful and fertile; for all Trees are not to be Lopt after the Å¿ame faÅ¿hion: We Lop diverly (for inÅ¿tance) a Peach-Tree and a Winter Pear-Tree; and its by Lopping of this laÅ¿t, that the skill of the Gardiner Å¿hews it Å¿elf the moÅ¿t conÅ¿picuouÅ¿ly, and that we judge beÅ¿t of his ability.

There are Trees which we dare not Lop, by reaÅ¿on of the abundance of their Sap; for the more we Lop them, the more Wood they Å¿hoot forth, and the leÅ¿s Fruit; even the Flower-buds yield Wood, which happens often to the Tree, which yields the delicate Pear call'd the little RouÅ¿Å¿elet; to the lateward Bergamot, to the VirgoleuÅ¿e, to the St. Lezan, &c. But when theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Trees have Å¿hot forth their full, after this they bear but too much. In this occaÅ¿ion Lop Å¿ometimes Å¿hort, and Å¿ometimes long, or not at all: take away Å¿ometimes the young Wood, and preÅ¿erve the old; another while cut away the old, for the Tree to grow young again; at another time cut away the Branches, and all the falÅ¿e
Sprouts, but remember never to diÅ¿garniÅ¿h the Stock, by Lopping away all the little Branches of the Å¿ides of the Tree, and making the Trunk bare.
Gardiners have a very true Maxim, Lop in fair Weather, in the decreaÅ¿e of the Moon, and in the end of the Saps, or rather when Trees are at rest.

The decreaÅ¿e of the Moon of January, which happens in February, is the true time for Lopping Trees, and for preÅ¿erving Grafts; not but this Rule has Å¿ome exception; for weak Trees, and thoÅ¿e that are Planted but of that year, ought to be Lopt at the new Moon, to make them Å¿prout vigorouÅ¿ly: And we muÅ¿t remember that Trees ought not to be cut when we Plant them, but we ought to Å¿tay till the Month of February following.

When you Plant a Graft of three years, which has Flower-buds, preÅ¿erve Å¿ome to Å¿ee the Fruit in the firÅ¿t year: It is of theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Trees that you muÅ¿t always make choice, they Å¿hew from their beginning an aÅ¿Å¿ured fruitfulneÅ¿s, and bear afterward a great deal of Fruit as long as they live.

BecauÅ¿e it is known that an abundance of Sap makes but Branches, and that a little or mean Sap makes Fruit: and moreover that the Moon has leÅ¿s influence on Å¿ublunary things, when Å¿he begins to be in
the Wain, than when Å¿he IncreaÅ¿es; experience has taught us that the decreaÅ¿e of the Moon is the moÅ¿t kindly time for Lopping Trees, which have then leÅ¿s of motion. The decreaÅ¿e is from the time of the Full to the New, nevertheleÅ¿s Å¿ome will have it that we may Lop Trees during the time that the Moon is not horned, that is to Å¿ay, from her eighth day to her one and Twentieth. They Å¿ay that it is not only the Moon which cauÅ¿es Fruit on Trees, but the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Branches; and that it Å¿uffices that the Moon has Å¿trength, provided that on the other Å¿ide Å¿he finds in a Branch, Fibres tranÅ¿verÅ¿e and diÅ¿pos'd to cauÅ¿e Fruit-buds to be there form'd. True it is, experience has taught me that the Seeds of Flowers caÅ¿t into the Earth during all this time, turn double Å¿ooner than thoÅ¿e that are Sown in another time.

We ought firÅ¿t to Lop Apricock, Nectarin, and Peach-trees, &c. becauÅ¿e they Å¿hoot forth the firÅ¿t; the Winter Pear-trees follow next, after theÅ¿e thoÅ¿e of Autumn and of Summer, and the Portugal Quince-trees: We ought Å¿hortly after to Lop and Prune Plum-trees, and Apple-trees, and laÅ¿tly SpaniÅ¿h Pomegranet-trees, becauÅ¿e all theÅ¿e Trees Å¿hoot forth the one after the other; but above all, we ought not to Lop this laÅ¿t till it has Å¿hot forth a
little, that we may the better diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the weak or dead Branches.

After the ObÅ¿ervations which we even now made, we ought to begin to Lop and Trim up a Tree by one of its Å¿ides from the lower part to the top, and we ought afterward to carry on our Work without confuÅ¿ion, and to take one Branch after the other. This Å¿ide being thus Lopt and paled, we deÅ¿cend on the other Å¿ide from the top to the bottom in the Å¿ame Order.

We muÅ¿t here remember always to cut the Branches in the form of a Hinds foot, Å¿o that the Sun may not dry the wound, which ought to be as far as we may on the North Å¿ide; but after Å¿uch a manner that the Å¿loping Å¿ide of the wound be not too Å¿traight downward, to the end that the knot be not endammag'd; otherwiÅ¿e the eye which ought to puÅ¿h forth wood, being cut too much by the Å¿lope of a too Å¿treight deÅ¿cent (chiefly in tender Trees) will not puÅ¿h forth at all or weakly, and will communicate ev'n to five or Å¿ix eyes the evil of a wound ill made.

We muÅ¿t further remember to cut always a Branch near a Wood-bud, and never near a Flower-bud; becauÅ¿e in this laÅ¿t Lopping, the Fruit which would come there, would not be Å¿ecured by the Leaves againÅ¿t the injury of the Air. Moreover the Branch
would be expos'd to the Air, and finally the wound would not cloÅ¿e it Å¿elf, nor ever come to an EÅ¿char the Pears carrying away all the Sap, that ought to make it:

We ought not moreover to leave a Stub to a Branch which we cut at a Wood-bud, that we may give way to the Branch to cloÅ¿e it Å¿elf in a Å¿hort time by the Å¿prout that ought to grow there; I Å¿ay not the Å¿ame of a Branch which we cut an Eye or two from the Trunk; this may put forth near the Stub, which we leave there, Å¿ome Fruit. buds, or Å¿ome Branches which will have diÅ¿poÅ¿itions to produce them, at leaÅ¿t if the Branch be little or of a mean Å¿ize; for if it be great, it ought to be cut near the Tree. If in Lopping where we leave a Stub, nothing Å¿hoots forth there, the year following the Stub muÅ¿t be cut Å¿mooth to the Tree.

I Å¿peak not here only of Fruit with Kernels, we ought ev'n to leave a Stub to Fruits with Stones, not to make them puÅ¿h forth Wood there, for this is not their Genius, but to keep them from being corrupted by the Weather, and not to cauÅ¿e them to puÅ¿h forth Gum there, which is their Sap, and in this occaÅ¿ion their Capital Enemy.

When the little Branches are too confus'd, care muÅ¿t be taken to cut them off
an Eye or two from the main Branch, or near the Trunk as I have Å¿aid, both to disburthen the Tree, and to make it puÅ¿h forth Å¿ome Branches anew, but after Å¿uch a manner, that there be always room for placing the Sprig which will come.
We ought alÅ¿o to ObÅ¿erve that to fill out a Tree well, its Branches ought not to be diÅ¿tant from each other above a Fingers breadth.

You muÅ¿t never cut Fruit-buds whatever reaÅ¿ons are alledged thereon; Trees at that time do what they are ordain'd for, by diÅ¿playing their Riches, and Nature gives us what we demand of her for recompence of our cares and Labours.
We know a Fruit-bud by its Figure, by the Å¿mall bearer where it comes, by the motion it makes in the Å¿hoot of the Tree or finally by the abundance of Leaves that accompany it.

If a little and long Branch be well Å¿tor'd with Flower-buds, do not cut any of them (I Å¿ay it once again) and do not Å¿o much as touch the Branch, wait rather till the Flowers are come forth of the Bud to deÅ¿troy them, or till the Fruit are kern'd to cut with SciÅ¿Å¿ars the Stems of the leaÅ¿t and worÅ¿t form'd; by this means you will not cut away the Bud which will produce other
Fruit the following years when the Branch has fortified it Å¿elf.

NevertheleÅ¿s, if for Å¿ome great reaÅ¿on, we are Obliged to cut Flower-buds in a Branch bared of Å¿hoots, for drawing thither the Sap, and to cauÅ¿e Å¿ome void Å¿pace to be fill'd, and that there are no other Branches found for Å¿upplying this Default, we muÅ¿t cut the Branch at a Wood-knot to fill out the Tree, and we muÅ¿t take good heed not to cut it near the Flower or Fruit-buds, for the reaÅ¿ons which we have mentioned, and after this we muÅ¿t take away the Fruit-buds to give it more Å¿trength to puÅ¿h forth.

The old Buds which have yielded Fruit for many years together, and which give us no longer hope of producing more, muÅ¿t be cut away to embelliÅ¿h the Tree, and to disburthen it of Å¿omewhat which is uÅ¿eleÅ¿s and Å¿uperfluous.

The bearers which are two, three, or four Inches long are the beÅ¿t, eÅ¿pecially when they IÅ¿Å¿ue from the great Branches near the top of the Tree; they bring forth many years one after the other, and bear very great Fruit. ThoÅ¿e which are bared of Branches laÅ¿t indeed a long time; but they do not bear Å¿o Beautiful Fruit, and often they are drain'd, unleÅ¿s you cut the Stems of the Pears with SciÅ¿Å¿ars; and thoÅ¿e which are
not above a nail in length, and which come from the Trunk, bring forth very great Fruit; but ordinarily they laÅ¿t but a year
A Shoot of AuguÅ¿t never yields Fruit, the Wood is not then well fill'd with Sap, it ought always to be cut away, unleÅ¿s it be extreamly neceÅ¿Å¿ary for filling a void Å¿pace.

If a uÅ¿eleÅ¿s or irregular Branch grows behind, it is always cut away, ev'n tho' it has on it a Flower-bud; for the Fruit which would come of it, would be Å¿poil'd by the Å¿hadow of the Tree, and would be good for nothing: if it be before, we cut it an Eye or two from the Mother Branch, to try to make Å¿ome Flower-buds Å¿pring forth there.
A Branch bent by force bears much Fruit, but it is Å¿mall, unleÅ¿s it were plyed Å¿o the firÅ¿t year; the reaÅ¿on is evident, its Fibres are bent, and the Sap does not carry it Å¿elf briskly to it.

Sometimes forked Å¿prouts, or knots of Scions Å¿hoot forth from certain places of Trees, when they are Old and at a Å¿tand that they need to be cut to renew them. In this occaÅ¿ion we ought to cut at a good length a MaÅ¿ter Sprig in Pear-trees and Apple-trees, and to cut Å¿ome an Eye or two from the Mother Branch, and cut others near the Trunk, but in Nectarin
and Peach-trees, we ought to cut all the leÅ¿Å¿er Branches an Eye or two from the Mother Branch, and let the longeÅ¿t and Å¿treighteÅ¿t run on, tho' it would be the Å¿horteÅ¿t way in theÅ¿e laÅ¿t Trees, to cut a great Branch near the Trunk, or to cut the Trees two or three Fingers breadth from the Earth to renew them.

You muÅ¿t cut one Branch Å¿hort betwixt two long to fill out the Tree. The year following the Å¿hort Branch muÅ¿t be cut long, and the long Å¿hort: It is the Å¿ecret to have much Fruit, and to preÅ¿erve Trees; there are Å¿ome who Å¿ay that a Tree Lopt after that manner is not agreeable to behold: but I deÅ¿ire them to Å¿tay to conÅ¿ider them till the Month of May; and I am well aÅ¿Å¿ur'd they will change their Å¿entiment.
A Tree is ordinarily compos'd of three Å¿orts of Branches, we find on it Ravenous or Prodigal, Indifferent, and Fertile.
1. The Ravenous grow moÅ¿t commonly at the top of the Tree, and Å¿ometimes they Å¿pring from an Old Branch; they are finely even and without MoÅ¿s, greater and more Å¿mooth than the others.
2. The Indifferent are of a mean Å¿ort, among which there are Å¿ometimes Å¿ome well Å¿upply'd with Juice, they bearing Å¿ometimes Fruit within three or four years.

3. The Fertile are ordinarily Å¿mall, and
growing athwart; Å¿ometimes there are found of them great and long; they always bear Fruit; there are counted five Å¿orts of them.

1. The firÅ¿t have in their Å¿ource, and in the place whence they Å¿pring, little Wrinkles like Rings; which Å¿hew that in this place there are tranÅ¿verÅ¿e Fibres in the Wood. Its in theÅ¿e Fibres where is made a Å¿low circulation of the Sap of the Tree, which produces the Flower-bud, whereas when the Fibres are all Å¿treight, the Sap is carryed upward vigorouÅ¿ly and without reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and not Å¿taying it Å¿elf in any place, it produces nought but Wood: We may ObÅ¿erve theÅ¿e tranÅ¿verÅ¿e Fibres in cutting the Wood where there are of theÅ¿e Rings, the cut will not be cloÅ¿e and even as elÅ¿ewhere.
The Figure following will RepreÅ¿ent to you the Fertile Branch.
A. The Wrinkles and Rings of a Branch of a Bon-ChrÃªtien Pear-tree.

2. The Second Fertile Å¿prouts have no Rings in their Origine, where they IÅ¿Å¿ue from their Mother Branch; but they have in the middle, that is to Å¿ay, when an Indifferent Branch, having not been cut in February, Å¿hoots forth Wood in May, and forms Wrinkles at the beginning of its Å¿hoot; or when a Branch in its middle forms Rings betwixt the end of its Å¿hoot of May, and the beginning of that of June, which may be known eaÅ¿ily, if a Man will make the experiment; for in cutting the wood in this place, as I ev'n now mention'd, the cut will not appear
Å¿mooth as elÅ¿ewhere, but uneven by the tranÅ¿verÅ¿e Fibres that are there.
The following Figure RepreÅ¿ents the Second Fertile Branch in a Bon-ChrÃªtien.
A. Rings, and Wrinkles at the beginning of the Shoot of May, or betwixt the end of the Shoot of May, and the beginning of that of June.

3. The third kind of Fertile Branches IÅ¿Å¿ues from a Flower-Bud, which has fail'd to blow Å¿ometimes for outward cauÅ¿es, and often through the abundance of the Sap of the Tree: They IÅ¿Å¿ue alÅ¿o from a Bud which has yielded Pears; they are call'd Fertile, becauÅ¿e they come of a Flower or Fruit-bud which experience diÅ¿covers
to us to have tranÅ¿verÅ¿e Fibres.
The third Figure Å¿hews it us in a little Branch with Flower and Fruit-buds of a Bon-ChrÃªtien.
A. The Bud which has yielded Pears, or has fail'd to blow.
B. The Fertile Branch which we muÅ¿t let grow on.
C. The leÅ¿Å¿er Branch which we muÅ¿t cut away.
D. Where it ought to be cut at two knots:
E. The Bearer.

4. The Fourth kind of Fertile Branches are thoÅ¿e which the year before were Indifferent, and which are become Fertile through the little Sap that is come to them, and by the Buds which are grown to a fulneÅ¿s.
5. Finally, the Fifth are thoÅ¿e which have a Flower-bud at the end of the Branch.

1. Of theÅ¿e three Å¿orts of Branches, that is to Å¿ay, of the Prodigal, Indifferent, and Fertile, the Prodigal are always cut very Å¿hort at the firÅ¿t or Å¿econd knot, to make the Sap paÅ¿s to another Å¿ide of the Tree, and produce there Branches Indifferent or Fertile. This Lopping reiterated many times, makes the Prodigal Dye, or at leaÅ¿twiÅ¿e hinders the Tree from puÅ¿hing them Å¿o vigorouÅ¿ly. Its by reaÅ¿on of this experiment that we ought not to cut Trees much, becauÅ¿e by cutting them in all their Branches, they are made to LanguiÅ¿h and afterwards to Dye. The Prodigals which have been cut many times the precedent year, ought to be Lopt at the firÅ¿t knot near the Mother Branch whence it grows, as the Fourth Figure Å¿hews.
A. A Prodigal cut in February at the Second knot.
B. A Prodigal cut in June at the Second knot.
C. A Shoot of the Prodigal in July which has not been cut, becauÅ¿e it has Å¿hot very little.
D. Where we muÅ¿t cut a Prodigal in February, of the following year at the firÅ¿t knot.

Lop therefore the top of the Tree, where the Prodigal Branches are Ordinarily found, and Å¿pread it at the bottom and at the Å¿ides; this Lopping gracefully fills a Tree, and hinders it from Growing to too great a height and from deÅ¿troying it Å¿elf in a Å¿hort time.

2. As for the Indifferent Branches, Å¿ome
of them ought to be Lopt, others not; that is to Å¿ay, we ought in the Month of February to let thoÅ¿e grow on which have Buds for Wood very near each other, and which iÅ¿Å¿ue from a good place, as alÅ¿o thoÅ¿e which have two great Leaf-buds which touch each other at the end of the Branch; to the end we may know their Genius at the Lopping of June. The greateÅ¿t and beÅ¿t Å¿upply'd with Juice will be the beÅ¿t for keeping. The Indifferent which we ought to cut at the third or fourth knot, are thoÅ¿e which are leaÅ¿t diÅ¿pos'd to bear Fruit, and which have the Leaf-buds far from one another.

3. The Fertile ought never to be Lopt, tho' they are as long as the Arm; Trees left to run up from which we Lop no Branches and which bear Å¿o much Fruit, Å¿hew us well that we ought never to Lop the Fertile: nevertheleÅ¿s, if there be need of them for filling up a void Å¿pace where it happens, and that no other Branch can be found for this purpoÅ¿e, I permit them to be cut for embelliÅ¿hing the Tree.

And to explain my Å¿elf farther in Å¿peaking concerning a Fertile Branch, I Å¿ay that that which has Rings in its Å¿ource, Wrinkles at the beginning of its Å¿hoot of May or of June, or finally knots near each other, ought not to be cut without a great
neceÅ¿Å¿ity; for experience has taught me that all theÅ¿e Branches bear Infallibly their Fruit toward the end of their Branches, which our ill Gardiners always cut away, So at the beginning of February ObÅ¿erve exactly the end of the Å¿hoots of the precedent year, that you may always cut the Branch when the Saps are at a Å¿tand at the firÅ¿t or Å¿econd knot in the Wood which comes after, and to leave all the knots which will be as many Flower-buds, that will not fail to form themÅ¿elves there in two or three years. Its an ObÅ¿ervation which will embelliÅ¿h your Trees by the abundance of Fruits which they will produce. That which I Å¿ay being Å¿omewhat difficult to comprehend without Å¿eeing it, the fifth Figure will make you underÅ¿tand it.
A. The Lop of February in an Indifferent Branch.
From B. to C. three Branches of the Å¿hoot of May.
D. The Lop of June in Indifferents.
From D. to E. The Å¿hoot of June.
From E. to F. The Å¿hoot of AuguÅ¿t, the Wood of which is very full of Sap.
G. Where we muÅ¿t Lop in February, of the following year when the Saps are at reÅ¿t.
H. Where in two years Fruit-buds will be form'd in a Branch which from indifferent is become Fertile.

The Fertile Branches which IÅ¿Å¿ue from a Bud which has yielded Fruit, and which have not been cut at the beginning of May, ought not to be cut in February, unleÅ¿s they are double. In this occaÅ¿ion we muÅ¿t let run the better, and Lop the other at the firÅ¿t or Å¿econd knot. Experience has taught me that theÅ¿e Branches never fail of bearing Fruit the Å¿econd or third year. See the third Figure.

Finally, the Å¿ame Experience has taught me that the Fruit-buds which come at the end of the Branches in Trees whoÅ¿e Genius is often to bear their Fruit in this place, ought not to be cut, eÅ¿pecially if they produce little, and we Å¿hould have but few Gracioli, Coins Francs, nor Grenades d'EÅ¿pagne, if we Å¿hould cut theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Trees at the end of their Branches.

It is Å¿aid that the Fruits which come at ends of Branches are Å¿mall, and that the Wind blows them down. I own that the firÅ¿t default is without remedy, but the
Second is not Å¿o, for we may bind up the Branch laden with Fruit againÅ¿t the Wind. Nature doing well what Å¿he does, when Å¿he places a Fruit-bud at the end of a Branch of a Pear-tree, has an intent to render this Branch Fertile; for the Fruit which Å¿he produces there, Å¿eals that Branch, and hinders it from puÅ¿hing forth afterward; this Branch receiving not then much Sap, forms in all its length an Infinite number of Fruit-buds, and two or three years after it is all deckt with them; which it continues to do for five or Å¿ix years following, till the Branch is worn out; if this Flower-bud be cut away the Sap will come freely and vigorouÅ¿ly into the Branch cut, and inÅ¿tead of the Fruit which Nature had there deÅ¿ign'd, we Å¿hall have nought but Wood through the Gardiners Ignorance.

When we will have larg Fruit, eÅ¿pecially in the Bon-Chretien and in other Trees, which bear great, we ought to Lop Å¿hort, the nearer the Fruit-buds are to the Trunk, the greater the Fruit is, for it receives more of the Juice.

There are Gardiners who make the BuÅ¿h of a Tree too thin by cutting away the little Branches, and leaving the Trunk almoÅ¿t bare: we might leave in it Å¿ome clear Å¿pace in the middle and the Å¿ides, to
give entrance to the Sun which muÅ¿t colour the Pears, but we ought not to cut it too much: the Å¿hadow of the Leaves ought to Å¿ecure the Trunk of the Tree againÅ¿t the parching heat of the Sun which makes it chop, and which breeds the Scab and the Canker by the dryneÅ¿s of its Bark. Tree it is that we ought to cut Å¿horter Trees with a round BuÅ¿h head than EÅ¿paliers, and that we ought not to let them run up too much: In a Å¿trong and moiÅ¿t Soil we muÅ¿t keep a BuÅ¿h head thinner of Branches than in another Soil, which is poor and dry; but in all places we ought to keep it well filled, and not cut away the Branches in the midÅ¿t of it as much as is done at this day.

The niceÅ¿t Trees do not delight in this Figure, Pear-trees do not much take to it, and Apricock-trees leÅ¿s. Trees Grafted on the great Quince-tree, are more proper for it than thoÅ¿e which are Grafted on a Pear-tree, theÅ¿e later cannot be reduc't, the more you cut them the more they Å¿hoot of Wood; and beÅ¿ides with this, they do not bring forth much Fruit, their nature being to be always high.

Cherry-trees which bear Å¿harp Cherries, grow very well with a BuÅ¿h head, provided that they are Grafted on the Å¿mall bitter Cherry-tree; and they take to it
better yet if they are permitted to grow up, for they do not much delight in the Pruning-knife, and leÅ¿s when they are old.
The Plum-tree is of the Å¿ame nature with the Cherry-tree; it is ordered alÅ¿o after the Å¿ame manner.

We ought rather to cut a Branch away, than to cut it in many places; the divers wounds which we give Trees, decay them, and make them dye languiÅ¿hing, witneÅ¿s the Prodigal, which we kill by often cutting.
Experience has taught me for many years following, that Fruit with Å¿tones (that is to Å¿ay the Apricock-tree, the Nectarin, and the Peach-tree) ought not to be Lop't as Pear-trees.

We ought only to cut away Branches, and Å¿ometimes the greateÅ¿t to make them renew themÅ¿elves: and contrary to the cuÅ¿tome of other Trees, they bear in young Å¿hoots which lade themÅ¿elves with Fruit the firÅ¿t year. Its after this manner that they laÅ¿t Twenty or Thirty years; the more therefore that a Peach-tree Å¿hoots forth, the more Fruit it bears.

We never ought in theÅ¿e Sorts of Trees to cut a Branch in the middle, tho' the Apricock-tree is not Å¿o much damnified by it as the others; becauÅ¿e they have a larg
Pith very Å¿uÅ¿ceptible of the injuries of the Air. The wound often cauÅ¿es five or Å¿ix knots to dye in a Branch, which has been cut after that manner, and by taking off with the Pruning-knife the end of the Branch, as is ordinarily done, we carry away at the Å¿ame time the Fruit that ought to form it Å¿elf there, and we leave but an end of a Branch which brings nought but Wood.

I Å¿ay it once again; the Fruit comes but at the end of the Å¿hoot of the two firÅ¿t Saps; if we Lop away this end, we carry away the Fruit, and we blockiÅ¿hly deprive our Å¿elves of that which we Å¿eek with Å¿o much paÅ¿Å¿ion. Its a remark which we ought well to ObÅ¿erve, for the Sap having Å¿pent and as it were wearied it Å¿elf after having paÅ¿t all along a Branch, does not exert it Å¿elf with Å¿o much vigour, and its motion is not Å¿o impetuous, nor Å¿o nimble at the end of a Branch as in the beginning of it; alÅ¿o it employs it Å¿elf rather to form Buds for Flowers when it acts mildly, than when it agitates it Å¿elf with Å¿o much praecipitation.

BecauÅ¿e Fruit with Stones Å¿hoot more briskly and more in confuÅ¿ion than Pear-trees, we muÅ¿t alÅ¿o take good heed to Lop them with diÅ¿cretion. TheÅ¿e Trees having Å¿hot forth vigorouÅ¿ly a Branch during one
year, and having produced Fruit there, loÅ¿e their force in this Å¿ame Branch the year following, and Å¿hoot forth nought but Scions here and there, but which are laden with an infinite number of Fruit; and the greateÅ¿t part of theÅ¿e Å¿ame Scions dye the year following as well as all the annual buds of the Tree. When a great Branch is old we ought to cut it in its Source, as you may Å¿ee in the Figure following.
A. Wood worn out of three or four years.
B. The place where it ought to be cut.
C. Young Wood of the year which ought not to be cut in the middle.
D. Flower or Fruit-buds of the precedent year, which are dry.

The Nectarine and the Peach-tree, being of the nature of thoÅ¿e Trees which Å¿hoot much in their tops, we muÅ¿t not hope to be able to Å¿ubdue them as Pear-trees, and force them to fill themÅ¿elves well in the lower part: if we Lop them as theÅ¿e Trees, that is to Å¿ay, if we Lop their Branches in the middle we hinder them indeed from Å¿hooting in their tops, but they do not fill themÅ¿elves for this in their lower part; they mount always, and by cutting them after that manner, no Fruit comes of it, and we kill them in a Å¿hort time.

In general, the Plum-tree and the Cherry-tree delight more in Lopping than the Apple-tree: but all three of them do not delight in it as much as the Pear-tree, which is the only Tree that endures it beÅ¿t. We muÅ¿t take nought from theÅ¿e three firÅ¿t Trees but the dead Wood, unleÅ¿s we will form them at firÅ¿t for BuÅ¿h-trees or EÅ¿paliers.

BecauÅ¿e the Corand-tree has much Pith, and that it comes eaÅ¿ily of a Å¿lip, its nature does not endure it to be Lopt in the middle of its Branches, no more than the
Peach-tree; above all we muÅ¿t take good care of cutting it, when we Å¿et it. We ought in an old Corand-tree to cut near the Root a Branch paÅ¿t bearing, in order to renew it, and to cut alÅ¿o from the lower part Å¿ome young Å¿hoots of the year to hinder it from being too much confus'd. The young Å¿hoots which we preÅ¿erve, Å¿erve to renew it when we cut it in its old Wood. NevertheleÅ¿s, tho' it does not delight in being Lopt, we make BuÅ¿hes of it, and form it in an EÅ¿palier, which is beautiful to behold, at the time that it is laden with Fruit.

I Å¿ay the Å¿ame of the Mulberry-tree, and of the Fig-tree, which cannot endure the knife by reaÅ¿on of the abundance of their Pith; the laÅ¿t eÅ¿pecially is viÅ¿ibly damnified by it, unleÅ¿s we Lop from them great uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches, for rendring them regular: and neither of them can be made to grow low, they love too much the free and open Air.
Medlar-trees and Service-trees naturally grow high, the former endure the knife much more than the latter.

The Portugal Quince-trees, and the Pomegranate-trees of Spain will not be Lopt, becauÅ¿e they bear their Fruit at the end of their Branches. NevertheleÅ¿s we may take from them entire Branches, which cauÅ¿e a
confuÅ¿ion, and which are old; and cut near the Trunk the uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Prodigals, which are uÅ¿ual enough in theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Trees. As for the other Prodigals which embelliÅ¿h the Tree, and which in four or five years will yield Fruit, we ought not to Lop them.

Care muÅ¿t be taken to cover the great Wounds of Trees with a PlaiÅ¿ter made of a pound of Drogue a flambeau, four Ounces of RoÅ¿ine, and two Ounces of Sheeps Sewet. When we walk in our Garden in a fine day of the Month of April, we muÅ¿t have in our hand a Magdaleon of the PlaiÅ¿ter ev'n now mentioned, we muÅ¿t cut a little of it with a knife, and after having wrought it betwixt the moiÅ¿tn'd Fingers, for rendring it a little Å¿oft, we muÅ¿t apply it on the great Wounds, which we had forgot to Å¿eal in the Month of March. And to the end that this PlaiÅ¿ter may keep the longer on the Wounds, we muÅ¿t put on it a bit of paper as a binder, which we muÅ¿t preÅ¿s on Å¿oftly with the Finger, to the end that the heat of the Summer making the PlaiÅ¿ter melt, the paper may preÅ¿s it, Å¿tay it, and glew it more to the Wood: it is what we ought to do in the two other Loppings following.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Lopping of Fruit-trees, at the beginning of the Month of May.
div.p: PRoperly Å¿peaking, it is not a Lopping that is done to Trees at this time; they are as yet in the motion of their Sap. We cut but Scions, which tho' Fertile of themÅ¿elves, bring in the mean time a great prejudice to the Fruit; at the beginning of May we muÅ¿t therefore take a particular care to cut away the uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches which grow by the Buds for Fruit, and eÅ¿pecially in Pear-trees; that is to Å¿ay, to cut away at the Å¿econd knot a little Scion which comes among the cluÅ¿ters of Pears: to delay this is not good, the Sap which ought to Communicate it Å¿elf to the Fruit, is carried into the Å¿hoot, which draws a part of the humour of the Fruit-bud, where the Pears are faÅ¿tn'd, which cauÅ¿es either that their Stem drys for want of Sap, or that they come very Å¿mall.
You may Å¿ee what I mean in the following Figure.
A. A Å¿hoot which comes on the Fruitbud through the abundance of the Sap.
B. The place where you muÅ¿t cut it.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Lopping of Fruit-trees at the beginning of June.
div.p: IN the DecreaÅ¿e of the Moon of May, which happens often in June, you muÅ¿t Lop Trees for the Å¿econd time; but with more moderation than in February: for we ought never in June to cut great Branches, and properly Å¿peaking, it is but a relopping of Trees.

We muÅ¿t wait above all till the Sap be ended, according to the Maxim which we have alleag'd before, and it will be good to repeat it here: Lop in Fair weather, in the DecreaÅ¿e of the Moon, at the end of the Saps; or rather when Trees are at reÅ¿t.

The reÅ¿t of a Tree is known by a bud GarniÅ¿h't ordinarily with two Leaves, which forms it Å¿elf at the end of the Branches, and we obÅ¿erve chiefly this bud at the end of May, or at the beginning of June, that is to Å¿ay, after the firÅ¿t Sap or Å¿hooting.

The Å¿econd Sap or Å¿hooting of Trees begins ordinarily in the middle of June, and ends a Month after, towards Magdalen-tide, Å¿o that betwixt the end of the firÅ¿t Sap, and the beginning of the Å¿econd there is about a Month: and its at this time that we muÅ¿t cut Trees again.

The effect of this re-cutting is to make the Buds of the firÅ¿t Sap to fill up, to force Trees to make Fertile Branches, or to form Flower-buds for the following year; whereas the Lop of February, furniÅ¿hes but Wood to yield Fruit three years after, if we except the Orange, the Bergamot, the Double-flower, the Summer Bon-Chretien, and Å¿ome others.
You ought here to call to mind that we have diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿ht the Branches of Trees Into Prodigals, Indifferent and Fertile.

There are few Trees Grafted on cultivated Trees, and on Trees come of Kernels, which do not yield Å¿ome Prodigal in the firÅ¿t Sap, and which do not continue even to yield of them in the others. Care muÅ¿t be taken therefore to cut them at the Å¿econd Leaf-bud, and thus to correct the Å¿hoot which tranÅ¿ports it Å¿elf, and which draw a great part of the Sap of the Tree. O â¢ this matter you may Å¿ee the fourth Figure

As for Trees Grafted on the great Quince trees, they have not often of theÅ¿e Å¿orts o â¢
Prodigal Å¿hoots: and Å¿ome Gardiners are ev'n of the mind that they ought not to be Lopt at this time, and that the tops of them ought only to be pincht off with the Nails.

We muÅ¿t not deal with the Indifferent Branches as with the Prodigal: for we ought to keep the beÅ¿t without touching them, and obÅ¿erve exactly thoÅ¿e which we permitted to run on in the Month of February. If theÅ¿e have good marks for proving Fertile, we muÅ¿t cut nothing there; but if they have not, they muÅ¿t be cut Å¿hort enough to make them yield Å¿ome; that is to Å¿ay, they muÅ¿t be cut at the fifth or Å¿ixth knot for Leaves: As for the other Indifferents, we ought to cut them at half a foot, or ev'n a foots length, for rendring them Fertile the year following. The Indifferents which we muÅ¿t not cut, have particular marks which we have obÅ¿erv'd in the firÅ¿t Chapter.
We ought not to touch the Fertile Branches for the reaÅ¿ons mentioned elÅ¿ewhere, unleÅ¿s it be Å¿ometimes thoÅ¿e which IÅ¿Å¿ue from a Flower-bud which has fail'd.

Before I paÅ¿s farther, it will be proper for me to explain my Å¿elf on what I pretend to Å¿ay by a Flower-bud which has fail'd; and you muÅ¿t give me leave to make two Å¿orts of Flower-buds. One Å¿ort is certain
and never Å¿hoots forth Wood: they are theÅ¿e which will yield Fruit in a Å¿hort time. The others Å¿hoot forth Wood when the Sap abounds too much, or when we cut a Tree too Å¿hort, and that by this means we draw the Sap too much toward theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Buds. They are theÅ¿e Buds which will not blow under two or three years. Their Origine, their Å¿ituation, and their-Figure make them eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hable to a Gardiner which has experience and a good Å¿ence. This being thus eÅ¿tabliÅ¿ht, I may Å¿ay that a Scion which Å¿hoots in a Fruit-bud which has fail'd, is Å¿ituated in a good place for being called Fertile as I have Å¿aid it elÅ¿ewhere; and that if the Sap of the Tree had not been Å¿o abundant, to make this Bud Å¿hoot which yielded the Scion, doubtleÅ¿s this Bud would have become the year following a Flower-bud; beÅ¿ides the Fibres of the Bud being tranÅ¿verÅ¿e, cauÅ¿e the Sap to circulate more Å¿lowly, and during all this time the Sun concocts and digeÅ¿ts the humour to form there Fruit-buds for Fruit.

I thought good to alledge all this, to Å¿hew the errour wherein Å¿ome are, who will have us always to cut this Scion, ev'n when the Fruit has fail'd, and for this they call it a falÅ¿e and an ill Å¿hoot. But experience has taught me that it has marks of
FertileneÅ¿s, and that two years, or at fartheÅ¿t three years afterward, if it were not cut away, it would furniÅ¿h it Å¿elf with Flower-buds; and would bear during Å¿ix or Å¿even years an infinite number of Fruit.

If therefore the Flower-bud which is on a little bearer, that has fail'd, which would yield Fruit the next year or two years after, Å¿hoots Wood; it ought to be cut Å¿hort in June, to make it form there Fruit-buds, which happens Å¿ometimes otherwiÅ¿e through the abundance of the Sap; for a Scion or two form themÅ¿elves there as may be Å¿een in the third Figure.

NevertheleÅ¿s, there are Å¿ome who will not have us to cut this Scion in June; they preÅ¿erve it for the Fruit, and cut it long in the Month of February following, or do not Lop them at all; and if there are two, they let the beÅ¿t grow, and cut the other an Eye or two from the Mother-Branch.

But however, I think we muÅ¿t here diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h two Å¿orts of Scions which come in a Flower-bud which has fail'd. There are bearers and vigorous Buds, which Å¿hoot forth two or three Scions, whereof Å¿ome are long and Å¿lender, others Å¿hort and Å¿lender, and others again Å¿hort and thick: We muÅ¿t not touch theÅ¿e laÅ¿t; becauÅ¿e moÅ¿t commonly a Flower-bud forms it Å¿elf there,
and we muÅ¿t not always cut the others an Eye or two from the Mother-Branch: If Å¿ome diÅ¿poÅ¿ition for a Flower-bud forms it Å¿elf near the Scion, cut within an Eye or two of the Mother-Branch, we muÅ¿t accept of it from the liberal hand of Nature; if none be form'd there, and that another Scion grows there, they muÅ¿t be left for the Months of July or February following. If the Bud which produces the Scion, be weak, we muÅ¿t not touch it, but we muÅ¿t preÅ¿erve the Scion for the Fruit, at leaÅ¿t if it appears well furniÅ¿ht with Sap in AuguÅ¿t; for if we cut it, it will be at a Å¿tand and will not Å¿hoot.
We muÅ¿t cut larger in June than in February; becauÅ¿e it is at that time that we give the Figure to the Tree for the year following, and that we cauÅ¿e Fruit-buds to be form'd for two years after.

If Grafts within a cleft made in the top of a Stock; are vigorous the year that they are Grafted, it is better (as Å¿ome think) to pinch the ends of them away with the Nails at the beginning of June, than to cut them. But experience has taught me that if we deÅ¿ign a Graft which Å¿hoots vigorouÅ¿ly either for a BuÅ¿h head or for an EÅ¿palier, we ought to cut it at the New of the Moon, three or four Months after it is Grafted, to make it Å¿pread below,
and to Å¿ecure it from the Wind: We gain a year by Å¿o doing.
As for Trees which we deÅ¿ign to let run up to a height it will be good not to cut them at all till the Å¿econd year.

We muÅ¿t not touch the firÅ¿t year a Bud Grafted, be it never Å¿o vigorous; we muÅ¿t wait the year following to cut the Stump of the Tree come of Seed, mean while care muÅ¿t be taken to Å¿tay it up againÅ¿t the Wind.

I repeat it once again here, that we ought never to cut Flower-buds, becauÅ¿e we take away the Buds which bring a great deal of Fruit during Å¿ix or Å¿even years following. When the little Branches, where the Buds are fixt, are fortified by the hardneÅ¿s of the Tree, it is then that we muÅ¿t no longer cut off with Sheers, neither Flowers nor Pears.

There are Å¿ome who Å¿ay, that we ought to cut Apricock, Nectarin and Peach-trees, four or five times a year, to wit, in February, in May, in June, and in July: but Experience has taught me, as well as Father FeÃ¼illant, who has writ of Fruit-trees, that theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Trees do not much love the knife; otherwiÅ¿e, they do not laÅ¿t long, and we deÅ¿troy them in the end, by much cutting them: We are oblig'd in this Month to nale them up, and to cut at the Å¿ame
time the Branches which cannot be apply'd to the EÅ¿palier. Some preÅ¿erve them to be cut in the Month of February, according to the Maxim that theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Trees, being very nice, do not love to be cut, or rather, they pull away with the Finger the Branches, as faÅ¿t as they come againÅ¿t order, and in an Irregular place.

After the firÅ¿t Lopping of February, I am not of opinion that we ought to cut any thing from Apple-trees, or Plum-trees, or Cherry-trees, or Goosberry-trees, or Portugal Quince-trees, or SpaniÅ¿h Pomegranate-trees, unleÅ¿s we take from theÅ¿e two laÅ¿t Trees Å¿ome Prodigals, which ordinaly grow there, and which do not fill, nor embelliÅ¿h the Tree.

Tho' I reÅ¿olv'd to Å¿peak here but of Lopping Trees, nevertheleÅ¿s it may be allow'd me to Å¿ay Å¿omewhat curious concerning their watering, which contributes much to the abundance and greatneÅ¿s of their Fruit.

It will be proper in the Evening at Sun Å¿et, during the great heats of the Summer to Å¿prinkle with Water Å¿ometimes the Branches and the Fruit of Trees with a Dutch Pump. The Tree will be greener, and the Fruit better Å¿upply'd with nouriÅ¿hment: it is far better to do Å¿o than to Water them at the Root; for this laÅ¿t watering renders Peats unÅ¿avory, and of an ill
taÅ¿te, whereas the firÅ¿t, anÅ¿wering to an Evening Rain, or the due of the Night, keeps the Tree Å¿upply'd with nouriÅ¿hment, which afterwards gives its Fruit the Juice, which is meat for them, for rendring them good and delicious.

For this we ought to ObÅ¿erve that the Water which we will make uÅ¿e of, ought to be drawn in the Morning, and to have been a little expos'd to the Sun, Å¿o that it Å¿hould not be cold in the Evening when we would uÅ¿e it: Moreover that the Pump has three or four little holes, that it may make the Water which iÅ¿Å¿ues from it to divide it Å¿elf into a ThouÅ¿and little drops. Finally, that we ought to place our Å¿elves at fifteen or twenty Foot from the Tree which we will Water.

div.head: CHAP. IV. The Lopping of Fruit-trees at the end of July.
div.p: WE Å¿aid in the foregoing Chapter, that the Å¿econd Sap or Å¿hoot began in the middle of June, and ended at the end of July; and we Å¿ay at preÅ¿ent, that the third manifeÅ¿ts it Å¿elf in the Month of AuguÅ¿t, and Å¿ometimes in the Month of September according to the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Air, and the difference of the Å¿eaÅ¿ons: Å¿o that it is at the end of the Å¿econd Sap that we ought to meddle with Trees; for in the Month of AuguÅ¿t we muÅ¿t take good heed not to cut any thing there, and if we cut then any Branch, the Wound does not cicatrize it Å¿elf all the year, the heat drys it, and the approaching Winter incommodes it with the exceÅ¿s of its Rains and colds.
This Lopping is not performed but to cauÅ¿e the Branches to be fortified, to make the Flower-buds to fill themÅ¿elves, and to cauÅ¿e the Fruit to be nouriÅ¿ht the more.

If we ought to be Å¿crupulous in the Month of June to Lop Trees, we ought to be Å¿o for a much greater reaÅ¿on this Month, for at preÅ¿ent we muÅ¿t but pinch away with the nails the ends of, or cut a little Å¿ome Branches.
We muÅ¿t chooÅ¿e then in July a fine day and the decreaÅ¿e of the Moon to viÅ¿it the Trees: and we muÅ¿t call to mind the diviÅ¿ion which we have made of the Branches of Trees.

We muÅ¿t Lop again at the Å¿econd knot the Prodigals a third time, if they have Å¿hot vigorouÅ¿ly, that we may wound Å¿o often the Branch which receives much of Sap, that its divers Wounds may weaken it, and divert by this means the Sap to other places, that it may be divided into many Branches. TheÅ¿e Prodigals come not much but in Trees Grafted on the Pear-tree; and Planted in a good Soil, as I have Å¿aid: and Å¿o we muÅ¿t not Å¿eek for them elÅ¿ewhere, for thoÅ¿e which are Grafted on the great Quince-tree do not Å¿hoot much: and in this Month we ought to cut nothing in theÅ¿e laÅ¿t Å¿orts of Trees.

In this Month we muÅ¿t not touch the Indifferent Branches, which we judg'd to be Å¿o in the Months of February and of June, we muÅ¿t Å¿tay till the Month of February following to Lop them, if they ought to be Lopt.

Neither muÅ¿t we touch of thoÅ¿e which are Fertile: but concerning thoÅ¿e which iÅ¿Å¿ue from a Flower-bud which has faild, there are differing Å¿entiments. The Å¿hoot which iÅ¿Å¿ues from this Bud having been cut at the Å¿econd knot in the Month of June, Å¿hoots Å¿ometimes at the Å¿econd Sap, and yields one or two Scions. Some will have it that we Å¿hould cut theÅ¿e alÅ¿o at the Å¿econd knot: becauÅ¿e they pretend that Nature ought to form there Å¿ome diÅ¿poÅ¿ition to make Buds. Others Lop at the Å¿econd Eye the leaÅ¿t, and preÅ¿erve the faireÅ¿t and beÅ¿t fed and knotted, to Å¿ee in February following if it will Å¿hew its Genius, and at that time they leave it all entire, becauÅ¿e it comes from a Fertile place, or cut it very long. They have obÅ¿erv'd by experience that three years afterwards it brings a great many Buds, whence iÅ¿Å¿ue an infinite number of Fruit.
If in this Month there are found Å¿ome uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches beÅ¿ides, they muÅ¿t be cut an Eye or two from the Mother-Branch, to make them Å¿hoot forth Å¿omewhat that is good.

There come often on Peach and Nectarin-trees, and Å¿ometimes on Pear-trees a cluÅ¿ter of Branches, which happens often to Trees grown old, and fit to be cut for renewing themÅ¿elves. We muÅ¿t do at this
time as we did in the February before: that is to Å¿ay, we muÅ¿t make choice of the MaÅ¿ter Sprig to preÅ¿erve it, and cut away the others. NevertheleÅ¿s there are Å¿ome who Å¿tay till the Month of February enÅ¿uing to do this, becauÅ¿e that in July the heat penetrates to the quick into the Wounds of nice Trees; and beÅ¿ides that which Trees Å¿hoot after this Å¿eaÅ¿on ought not to be preÅ¿erv'd. They cut therefore Trees at this time the leaÅ¿t they can, relying doubtleÅ¿s on experience which has obliged them Å¿o to do.

Toward Magdelan-tide, in the DecreaÅ¿e of the Moon, which happens in the Month of July, we muÅ¿t nail up again Peach-trees, Nectarin-trees, &c. and we muÅ¿t cut all the Branches which are not flexible, and which are grown contrary to Order, tho' with this diligence, that we muÅ¿t cover as Å¿oon as may be with a PlaiÅ¿ter, and paper the Wounds which have been there made.

ThoÅ¿e who are for the laÅ¿ting of theÅ¿e Trees, pale them up at this time, but they Å¿tay to cut them till the Month of February; theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Trees (according to their Å¿entiment) being Å¿o nice, that they cannot endure the Summer, the great heat penetrating into their Wounds, cauÅ¿es five or Å¿ix Eyes to dye. Which we perceive dryed the year following:
this is the way (Å¿ay they) to make them laÅ¿t forty years, as experience Å¿hews it. They choÅ¿e much rather (as I have Å¿aid) to pull away with the Finger, as they walk, the Branches which come contrary to order, than to cut them, and if there are found Å¿ome which ought to be cut, they keep them for the Month of February following. NevertheleÅ¿s, if they are too much confus'd, and that their Å¿haddow hinders the Sun from heating the Fruit, we Å¿hall be oblig'd to cut them away.

The abundance of Pears being ordinarily the Enemy of EÅ¿paliers, and making the Trees often dye, we muÅ¿t cut with Sheers the middle of the Å¿talk of the Pears, to disburthen the Trees. This ought to be done when the Fruit is a quarter or a third part as big as it ought. This Rule is only for great Winter-Fruit, and chiefly for the Bon-Chretien: we muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve alÅ¿o not to leave above one or two Pears on a weak Branch, a Å¿trong one being able to bear more.

Its alÅ¿o in this Month that Fruit enter into Juice, and begin to take a colour through the light of the Sun: but becauÅ¿e often there are Leaves, which hinder the rayes fron touching the Fruit, care muÅ¿t be taken in July to take away Å¿ome from before
them, and in the Month of AuguÅ¿t following we muÅ¿t cut away the reÅ¿t with Sheers, Å¿o managing the Light by reaÅ¿on of the burning heat of the Sun.

div.head: An Explanation of Å¿ome words which Gardiners make uÅ¿e of to expreÅ¿s themÅ¿elves in Å¿peaking of Fruit-Trees.
div.p: CAnker, or Scab is often caus'd by the heat of the Sun, or through the taint of the Tree which is in an ill Soil,
EÅ¿palier, is an edge row of Fruit-trees Å¿et cloÅ¿e together, their Boughs interlac'd one within another, and held with Stakes, Railes, or Pales.
FalÅ¿e Shoots, are little uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches, or Sprouts of the Å¿hoot of August, turning yellowiÅ¿h, and ill Å¿upply'd with Juice.

Franc, is Å¿aid of Fruit, when they are cultivated and domeÅ¿tick, or of a Tree Grafted, or laÅ¿tly of a young Tree come of a Kernel, Sown, which has no thorns, and which has large Leaves, for there are excellent Fruit which come of Seed Å¿o Sown. We Å¿ay to Graft a Franc on a Franc, Coin Franc.
Fertile, Fertile Å¿hoots are the Branches which always bear Fruit.
Indifferents, are Sprouts which Å¿ometimes yield Fruit within three or four years. A knot is the place where a Tree Å¿hoots forth Wood.
Prodigal or Ravenous, are great and Å¿mooth Å¿hoots, which draw the Sap of the Tree, and which bring not Fruit in a long time; they diÅ¿Å¿ipate all the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of their Mother.

Sap, is taken for the humour which riÅ¿es betwixt the Wood and the great Bark, by the little Bark which is betwixt both, it anÅ¿wers to the Blood of Animals: It is RoÅ¿in in the Pine-tree, Turpentine in the Larch-tree, Gum in the Apricock and Cherry-trees, Milk in the Fig-tree, Water in the Vine and in the Pear-tree.
Scion, is a little Fertile Branch.
Void Å¿paces, when there are no Branches to fill out the EÅ¿palier.

Worms call'd Tygres, Lutins, Diablotins, are thoÅ¿e Worms which come in the Month of AuguÅ¿t and gnaw the Leaves of Trees; they have the Head great and black; the vapour of Quick Lime, or the decoction of Wormwood kills them.

div.head: The Second PART.
Of the uÅ¿e of the Fruits of Trees, for preÅ¿erving us in Health, or for Curing us when we are Sick.
div.p: IT is not enough for us to have Writ concerning the Lopping of Trees, to have Fruit in abundance, we muÅ¿t alÅ¿o teach the way and the time of eating them without being offended thereby.

If our Stomach were as good as that of our Fore-fathers, it would be uÅ¿eleÅ¿s for us to Write on this matter; but becauÅ¿e it is weakn'd by the pleaÅ¿ures which men of late have taken in their way of living, there Å¿eems and Obligation upon us to give precepts concerning the uÅ¿e of Fruits, either for preÅ¿erving us in Health, or for deÅ¿troying our DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es when we are afflicted with them.

There is nothing Å¿o uÅ¿efull in PhyÅ¿ick, as to know the qualities of things which we make uÅ¿e of in Life, either for avoiding
thoÅ¿e which offend us, or for taking thoÅ¿e which do us good: it is what has oblig'd Learned men to deliver their Å¿entiments concerning all that we eat, they making uÅ¿e always of ReaÅ¿on and experience, which we Å¿hall alÅ¿o follow in this Tract of The uÅ¿e of Fruits of Trees: for it is only of thoÅ¿e whereof we deÅ¿ign to Å¿peak.

We Å¿hall make therefore three different Chapters: We Å¿hall Å¿hew in the FirÅ¿t the time and the way of uÅ¿ing thoÅ¿e Fruits which are eaÅ¿ily corrupted, as Figgs, Nectarins, Peaches, Plums, Apricocks, Mulberries, and Cherries, which we ought always to eat faÅ¿ting, on an empty Stomach, and before Meals.
The Å¿econd Å¿hall Treat of thoÅ¿e which are not eaÅ¿ily corrupted, and which we ought to eat the laÅ¿t thing after Meals, as Pears, Apples, Portugal Quinces, Medlars, and Services.

LaÅ¿tly, the third Å¿hall explain how we may eat before or after Meals RaiÅ¿ins, Portugal and China Oranges, SpaniÅ¿h Pomegranates, and Corands. But before I enter upon this matter, I think fit to lay down Å¿ome general Maxims, without which we cannot know the good uÅ¿e which we ought to make of Fruits.

We ought then in the firÅ¿t place to obÅ¿erve all the qualities of the Fruits before mention'd,
that we may uÅ¿e the one and the others at divers times, according to the precepts which we Å¿hall give in the Sequel.
