We find of Sweet, of Sugar'd, of Amber'd, of Musked, of Vinous, of Aqueous or InÅ¿ipid, of Sharp, of Acerb, and of AuÅ¿tere, and to Å¿peak in a few words, there are of Å¿weet, Å¿harp, and auÅ¿tere.
There are found moreover of Red, of Yellow, of Green, of Tawny, of Violet, of White and of Black.

Again there are of CaÅ¿Å¿ans or harÅ¿h, of Burez, of Fondans or melting and tender; finally we find Å¿uch as paÅ¿s quickly through the Bowels of thoÅ¿e that eat them, and theÅ¿e are the Fruits which are eaÅ¿ily corrupted: there are others which Å¿tay a long time in the Stomach, and they are thoÅ¿e which are corrupted with difficulty.

All the Fruits whereof we deÅ¿ign to Å¿peak in particular, cool and moiÅ¿ten much, becauÅ¿e they are but Water gathered together, and paÅ¿Å¿ed through the Trunk of the Tree, which produces them; but nevertheleÅ¿s with this difference, that there are Å¿ome colder and moiÅ¿ter than others.

Fruit that have a quality which is Å¿weet, and pleaÅ¿ant to the taÅ¿te, are leÅ¿s cold than others: thus, tho' Figgs, RaiÅ¿ins, the Bon-ChrÃªtien, the SpaniÅ¿h Renet, and other Fruit of the like nature, moiÅ¿ten much, they have
nevertheleÅ¿s but a coldneÅ¿s, which does not paÅ¿s the bounds of the firÅ¿t degree, its for this reaÅ¿on that they dulcifie much, and that they nouriÅ¿h a little more than the others, their matter having more affinity with our parts. But if with their natural Å¿weetneÅ¿s they have an odour of Amber or of Musk, then they have I know not what Å¿ubtle and penetrating parts, which exhilerate our Heart and Brain, and which make us digeÅ¿t them better than others.

Sharp Fruit cool more than Å¿weet: but they do not moiÅ¿ten Å¿o much, they powerfully penetrate and attenuate the thick and earthy matters, Å¿o that afterward they are no longer capable of doing us hurt. They qualifie our heated Bowels; they deÅ¿troy the Flame there, which often all the remedies of PhyÅ¿ick have not been able to quench during many Months: they cool our Liver, remove all the ObÅ¿tructions of our Bowels, and give our Blood a more free motion: finally they appeaÅ¿e fluxions, if we apply them outwardly, and they Å¿tay a Flux of Blood from whatever part it comes.

Fruits which are auÅ¿tere and acerb, and which differ but in more or leÅ¿s, reÅ¿tringe the Tongue and the Palate when we eat them: it Å¿eems that they Å¿top the Orifices of the threads that terminate there, by the blunted and obtuÅ¿e particles of their matter.

I do not pretend to Å¿peak here of Fruit which are not Ripe, that have all theÅ¿e qualities. I baniÅ¿h them entirely from this Book as very pernicious to the Life of Man; but I Å¿peak only of thoÅ¿e, which being in a perfect maturity, retain Å¿omewhat of auÅ¿tere, acerb, or aÅ¿tringent, as the Rake Pear, the great DÃ©gue, the Quince, and other Fruits of the like Nature. All theÅ¿e Fruits are alÅ¿o more cold than the Å¿weet and the Amb'red, but they do not moiÅ¿ten Å¿o much: and becauÅ¿e their Å¿avour is in a more Earthy matter, ev'n in this reÅ¿pect they do not penetrate Å¿o much as the Sharp. They reÅ¿tring however the Stomach and the Bowels, and withÅ¿tand a LooÅ¿neÅ¿s and a DiÅ¿Å¿entery, and being apply'd outwardly they hinder Vomiting, retard growing Inflammations, and eaÅ¿ily cicatrize the Skin, which has been open'd by a conÅ¿iderable Wound.

After all, a Fruit which has been brought to perfection by the heat of the Sun, and which has not been Å¿hadowed by the Leaves of its Tree, will be always of better taÅ¿te than another. A red Apple or Pear, and a yellow RaiÅ¿in will always be better than others; becauÅ¿e their Juice will be better digeÅ¿ted, and their uÅ¿eleÅ¿s moiÅ¿ture will be eaÅ¿ily evaporated by the heat of the Sun.

You muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve in the Å¿econd place,
that I give not here precepts concerning the uÅ¿e of Fruits, for Å¿ound and robuÅ¿t PerÅ¿ons, on whom Fruits make no ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion; Let Å¿uch eat of them at all times, and as much as they pleaÅ¿e, without diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing their Nature and Temperament, they will not find any inconvenience: but becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e Å¿orts of PerÅ¿ons are very rare, and that in the Age we Live, there are more Valetudinarians than others, I may be allow'd to Write only for thoÅ¿e who have their Entrals tender, and who are often incommoded by eating Fruits.

The greateÅ¿t part of men at preÅ¿ent are of a hot and dry Complexion; we have all of us the inward parts very hot, through the exceÅ¿s of a burnt Choler, and through the redundancy of a troubled Melancholy. With difficulty are we able during the Summer to Å¿upport the heat of the SeaÅ¿on, without being exhauÅ¿ted of our Å¿trength: We have the Stomach Å¿o weak and Å¿o tender through our natural diÅ¿temperature, that we have need of much precaution for the good uÅ¿e of Fruits.

In the third place, we muÅ¿t remember, that in walking in a Garden full of excellent Fruit, which are perfectly Ripe; we muÅ¿t not eat one which has not firÅ¿t been waÅ¿ht with freÅ¿h Water, and eÅ¿pecially
if the heat of the Sun, or of the day be exceÅ¿Å¿ive.

It is not of to day that experience has taught me, that Fruit newly gather'd, and eaten without precaution, cauÅ¿e the Feve â¢ s which we call putrid, which always begin with Å¿hiverings and tremblings, becauÅ¿e all the Juices of Fruits being then through the heat of the day, and of the SeaÅ¿on in a conÅ¿iderable motion, they cauÅ¿e in our Stomach Å¿o great a diÅ¿order at the time that the fermentation is there made, that the Chyle becoming crude and undigeÅ¿ted, often gives Birth to great DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es, whereas the motion of the Juice of Fruits being calm'd by the cold of the Water, of the Night or of the Å¿eaÅ¿on, the Fruits make no diÅ¿order in our Stomach, which then digeÅ¿ts them better, and which performs its Office much better, when it is not interrupted by unuÅ¿ual cauÅ¿es.

After all, we ought to know that our Å¿ood being in Å¿ome Å¿ort like our Å¿ubÅ¿tance, changes it Å¿elf eaÅ¿ily within our parts imperceptibly to us: Its thus that Bread, FleÅ¿h, an Egg, have no Predominant quality when we put them into our Mouth, and we do not Å¿enÅ¿ibly feel the Vertues when we have them in the Stomach. We muÅ¿t not Å¿ay Å¿o of Aliments which we call medicamental; they nouriÅ¿h little, and on the other Å¿ide they
have Å¿enÅ¿ible qualities, which affect our Tongue and our Palate. We may perceive that a Vertelongue, or a Pear Portail will cool and moiÅ¿ten our heated Stomach, that it will qualifie the Gall of our Liver, and the heat of our Reins, and that by cooling this laÅ¿t part, it will hinder Stones from being form'd there.

Finally, its a grand Å¿ecret for our good Health, to keep what we eat, from corrupting in the Stomach. The things of a different Nature which we put into it, daily cauÅ¿e diÅ¿orders, whereof our Å¿elves are too often WitneÅ¿Å¿es; if experience did not convince us of this truth, there would doubtleÅ¿s be a great deal of pleaÅ¿ure in eating many things one after the other; but it Å¿hews us that eating before or after Meals Fruits of a different Nature, that is to Å¿ay, Å¿uch as are eaÅ¿ily corrupted, as Peaches, &c. and Å¿uch as have a more firm Å¿ubÅ¿tance, as Pears, &c. The Coction which is made in the Stomach is not laudable, and that it is thence that often proceeds the little Health of thoÅ¿e who over looÅ¿ly indulge themÅ¿elves to the pleaÅ¿ure of the taÅ¿te.

If therefore we eat at the end of Meals Peaches and Pears, as it often happens, the Peaches being of a Å¿ubÅ¿tance to be Å¿oon digeÅ¿ted, and to paÅ¿s off quickly, and the Pears of a pretty firm matter, requiring more
time to Concoct, two great inconveniencies follow; the firÅ¿t, that the Peaches trouble the Belly, and make the Food taken at the Meal to deÅ¿cend, without being fully digeÅ¿ted: the Å¿econd, that they haÅ¿tily drag along with them the Pears, which require a longer time for digeÅ¿tion, and thus there comes of it but crudities, and afterward obÅ¿tructions, which are the cauÅ¿e of Å¿ome troubleÅ¿ome DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e.

It is not the Å¿ame when we eat before Meals Mulberries and Peaches, or after Meals Pears and Quinces; the two firÅ¿t Fruits and the two laÅ¿t have a matter and qualities near alike: the former paÅ¿s quickly through the Belly by reaÅ¿on of their great humidity: and the later digeÅ¿t themÅ¿elves afterward at leaÅ¿ure, by conÅ¿tringing after the Meal the Å¿uperior Orifice of the Stomach, which by this means acquits it Å¿elf much better of its office.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of Fruits which ought to be eaten before Meals.
div.p:
I Say in the firÅ¿t place that good Fruit which are Ripe, never do hurt, unleÅ¿s we miÅ¿uÅ¿e them, or commit faults in eating them; there are none but ill and unripe Fruit which cauÅ¿e Crudities, IndigeÅ¿tions, Colicks, and Fevers. I Å¿ay much more; experience daily teaches us, that by the moderate uÅ¿e of them we prevent an infinite number of DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es, and that we Cure as many. Our Gardens fail not of Remedies to relieve us, and I wonder we go Å¿o far into Forrein Countrys to Å¿eek for Drogues, which are muÅ¿ty or rotten, when they are brought to us, Å¿ince we have Å¿o excellent at home. Our Fruits have many more Vertues and Charms than all thoÅ¿e Diogues, and there are Å¿een few PerÅ¿ons who refuÅ¿e Peaches, Mulberrys, or Pears, to appeaÅ¿e the burning of the Bowels; Whereas we daily Å¿ee PerÅ¿ons have in horror
Tamarinds, CaÅ¿Å¿ia, Rhubarb, and the other Drogues which are brought us from Å¿o far.

BecauÅ¿e I am oblig'd to follow the Order which I have preÅ¿cribed to my Å¿elf, I Å¿hall treat in this Chapter of the good uÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e Fruits which ought to be eaten at Break-faÅ¿t, or before Meals: and I Å¿hall begin with Figgs, which among all Fruits have always been the moÅ¿t eÅ¿teem'd.

div.head: ART. I. Of Figgs.
div.p:
A Mong all the Food wherewith Men nouriÅ¿h'd themÅ¿elves at the beginning of the World, there is not one which deÅ¿erves a greater praiÅ¿e than Figgs. The Ancients have made Encomiums on them in many of their Books; and the Lacedemonians Å¿o far eÅ¿teem'd them, that they would never go to any FeaÅ¿t where they were not provided in a great plenty. AlÅ¿o Å¿ome have compar'd them to Gold, nay have eÅ¿teem'd them far better than this Mettal. Its doubtleÅ¿s
by reaÅ¿on of their Å¿ugary Å¿weeteÅ¿s, which is the Symbol of peace, that men formerly wiÅ¿ht their Friends a happy year, by Å¿ending them at the beginning of it Figgs and Honey.

In truth, they have admirable Vertues in CaÅ¿e they are eaten with Bread, for Break-faÅ¿t, or before Meals. For it is thus that they qualifie the Bowels, and that they appeaÅ¿e the exceÅ¿s of a troubleÅ¿ome heat. They do not fail of producing other good effects, they quench drought, lenify the BreaÅ¿t, and give a more eaÅ¿y reÅ¿piration. They clear the Liver and the Spleen of the ObÅ¿tructions wherewith they are afflicted. They diÅ¿charge the Reins and the Bladder of their Å¿lime and Gravel: They looÅ¿en the Belly, be it never Å¿o tardy: finally they nouriÅ¿h and fatten both together, witneÅ¿s the famous WraÅ¿tlers, who perform'd moÅ¿t couragiouÅ¿ly, when they liv'd but of Bread and Figgs. WitneÅ¿s alÅ¿o the Keepers of Figg-Gardens, who (according to the Relation of Galen) ate in a manner nought but Figgs, and who in the mean while were Å¿o fat, that a man would have Å¿aid that nothing was wanting to them in their way of living.

Figgs alÅ¿o have this peculiar to them, that they contribute to the vigour of young People, and to the Health of Å¿uch
as are Old, Å¿o that thoÅ¿e who uÅ¿e of them often, have no Wrinkles in their Face. A better ReaÅ¿on cannot be given than that Figgs, by their fat Å¿ubÅ¿tance engender a Blood which dulcifies much, and this Å¿ame matter being carried to the Å¿uperficies of the Body is there clear'd as well as the Blood of all its Å¿erous and Å¿uperfluous excrements, Å¿o that what remains Å¿erves as a natural Paint, and renders the Face Å¿mooth, and free from all Å¿orts of Wrinkles.

After all, they have the property of Penetrating, CleanÅ¿ing and DigeÅ¿ting; for no man doubts but they are hot in the firÅ¿t degree, and moiÅ¿t in the Å¿econd; the great humidity they have make them Å¿oon corrupt, and obliges us to eat them with Bread before Meals; for its the Leaven of the Bread which corrects all the ill qualities.

Its a Maxim among PhyÅ¿icians, That we ought always to begin with the things that are moiÅ¿teÅ¿t and eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t of digeÅ¿tion, when we Dine, or when we Sup. And this is alÅ¿o another, That after Fruits that are Sweet and LuÅ¿cious, and which withall paÅ¿s quickly through the Belly, we ought rather to Drink pure Water, or Water mixt with a little Wine, than Wine alone. Pure Wine carrys haÅ¿tily into the Lacteal Veins the matter of the Figgs before it be digeÅ¿ted, and Å¿o cauÅ¿es winds, and
IndigeÅ¿tions in thoÅ¿e who Å¿o do: Whereas Water is the cauÅ¿e of a Å¿lower fermentation, by the means of which the Figgs are perfectly digeÅ¿ted and make afterward a very laudable Blood, which eaÅ¿ily becomes our Å¿ubÅ¿tance.

They are not proper only for Å¿uch as are in Health, but likewiÅ¿e for thoÅ¿e who have a Fever and are coÅ¿tive, and I cannot imagine to my Å¿elf that a Learned PhyÅ¿itian can refuÅ¿e his Patient a Figg half dryed on the Tree by the heat of the Sun.

Dry Figgs have much more Vertue than thoÅ¿e which we gather; we may eat of them ev'n after Meals, without offence; alÅ¿o they are more penetrating and hotter than the others through the Å¿ubtilty of their parts, but they are not Å¿o moiÅ¿t. If they are apply'd in the form of a CataplaÅ¿m with Bread and a little Vinegar, haply they are the quickeÅ¿t and moÅ¿t certain remedy for opening an abÅ¿ceÅ¿s, for killing a Carbuncle, or the Å¿welling of the Kings-Evil, or laÅ¿tly to withÅ¿tand the progreÅ¿s of a Latent Cancer.
They do much more, if we will believe DioÅ¿corides, for they tear from the FleÅ¿h (as we may Å¿ay) a piece of a Bone broken, if we mix them with wild Popy Flowers.

The German PhyÅ¿icians have not found a better remedy in the Small-pox, or MeaÅ¿les than the decoction of theÅ¿e Fruits
dry; experience has Å¿hewn them that this decoction, by Purging by Urine, carrys away all the Malignant Å¿eroÅ¿ity which is the cauÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e troubleÅ¿ome DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es.
But among all the good qualities which theÅ¿e Fruits enjoy, there are obÅ¿erv'd Å¿ome ill: they cauÅ¿e Winds which Å¿well the Stomach; they breed Lice, and makes us fond in careÅ¿Å¿ing Women.

The Spirits irritated and Å¿et in motion by the Winds which they engender, and a viÅ¿cous humidity which they cauÅ¿e, are two things which diÅ¿poÅ¿e us to be fond of a Woman, as we have prov'd at larg in a DiÅ¿Å¿ertation we caus'd to be Printed the laÅ¿t year; which has for Title, Whether thoÅ¿e who Drink Water alone are more amorous than others?

The Lice which they Å¿ay Figgs breed in thoÅ¿e who uÅ¿e them in exceÅ¿s, proceed but from the filth of the Skin, and from our excrements which they evacuate by the pores: and the evils they cauÅ¿e in us by the Winds they engender, proceed but from the ill uÅ¿e we make of them; if we eat them with Nuts or Almonds, we Å¿hall correct all the diÅ¿orders they can bring us; and I can aÅ¿Å¿ure you that being Å¿o eaten, they will be without fault, and will do us no hurt, Å¿till provided that we uÅ¿e them with moderation.

div.head: ART. II. Of Nectarins and Peaches.
div.p: I Cannot bear the contempt Å¿ome PerÅ¿ons have for Nectarins, Alberges, Brugnons, Melicotonys, PerÅ¿es and Peaches, nor be Å¿atisfied with the reaÅ¿on they bring for blaming them. They Å¿ay among other things that theÅ¿e Fruits are corrupted Å¿o eaÅ¿ily in the Stomach, that it is almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible to Å¿ecure them from it; that they produce ill Blood, that they cauÅ¿e Fevers; that they injure the inward parts; that the PerÅ¿ians, from whoÅ¿e Country they were brought, dare not eat of them by reaÅ¿on of their Malignity, and finally that Galen, the moÅ¿t knowing of the Greek PhyÅ¿itians, always condemn'd them.

But if it were free for me to explain my Å¿elf at large thereon, and to break off the deÅ¿ign which I propos'd to my Å¿elf; I would Å¿hew that the ill uÅ¿e which is made of the moÅ¿t excellent things, is often the cauÅ¿e that they are deÅ¿pis'd and blam'd.
Peaches, not to Å¿peak of the other kinds, are a Fruit Å¿o excellent and Å¿o delicious to the taÅ¿te, that I could freely prefer them before Figgs and RaiÅ¿ins, which (according to the Å¿entiment of Å¿ome) ought to hold the firÅ¿t rank among Fruits.

Very far from cauÅ¿ing all the evils whereof they are accus'd, they cool the Stomach when heated, quench the heat of the Liver, allay the burning of the Blood during the extremity of the Summer heats, and moiÅ¿ten the matter which is then very thick through the drought of the SeaÅ¿on.

If we obÅ¿erve well their praecautions, they do not corrupt in the Stomach, provided that they are eaten before Meals, and that after having eaten them we drink only Water, if we find a burning in the Bowels; or excellent Wine, if we find our Å¿elves to have a very moderate heat; It is then that they will engender a better Blood than the Herbs we uÅ¿e every day.

I own that in PerÅ¿ia theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Fruits have Malignant and purgative qualities, but Å¿ince the Trees were tranÅ¿ported into Aegypt, and have been re-planted in Italy, and Å¿ince cultivated in France, they have loÅ¿t all the Malignity which they had, and have retain'd but the purgative Vertue, which they have Å¿till, and which they Communicate to their Fruit.

Its this purgative Vertue which cauÅ¿es them to be Å¿o much eÅ¿teem'd of by the Healthy and Valetudinarians, who had much rather eat faÅ¿ting four or five excellent Peaches, and drink after them Water or Wine, to looÅ¿en the Belly; than to take a doÅ¿e of PhyÅ¿ick, the very name of which raiÅ¿es a horrour in thoÅ¿e that take it the moÅ¿t couragiouÅ¿ly.

Its this Å¿ame property which reÅ¿ides in the Leaves, the Flowers and the Fruit of the Peach-tree, which kills the Worms in the Bowels, which Purges Choler and the SeroÅ¿ities of the Body, and Å¿tops ev'n Vomitings at Sea, as we Å¿ee written in the Works of Julius of Alexandria.

If Galen had Liv'd in our days, and had taÅ¿ted Peaches, which the Art and InduÅ¿try of our Gardiners have rendred Å¿o recommendable, I am certain he would have had quite another opinion of theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Fruit: the Peaches which were carryed to Rome in the Time of this PhyÅ¿itian, coming by Sea from Sicily or from about Naples, were partly rotted before they came thither, which made Galen at that time to deÅ¿piÅ¿e them, and to condemn them ev'n as a Food very pernicious for Man.

Some PerÅ¿ons will correct the ill quality, and the great humidity of the Peach; by eating it with Bread, by expoÅ¿ing it
two or three days to the Å¿corching heat of the Sun, by eating its Kernel, or finally by drinking pure Wine with it.

True it is, experience has taught me, that Bread eaten with Fruits which we ought to uÅ¿e before Meals, corrects their ill qualities, and that by expoÅ¿ing Peaches to the Sun, they loÅ¿e a Å¿uperfluous humidity which often incommodes us. But the Å¿ame experience has alÅ¿o given me to underÅ¿tand, that Peach and Apricock Kernels much charge the Stomach, and that beÅ¿ides their great bitterneÅ¿s they are alÅ¿o very difficult to digeÅ¿t: that moreover, tho' pure Wine be the Å¿ole thing which oppoÅ¿es it Å¿elf to the coldneÅ¿s, and humidity of this Fruit; nevertheleÅ¿s if we drink much of Å¿uch as is Å¿mall or of a mean Å¿trength, we fall into Vomitings and LooÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿es, which Å¿ometimes degenerate into a Bloody-Flux. Whereas a little of excellent pure Wine corrects by its noble heat the ill qualities of the Peach: Its haply this experiment which gave occaÅ¿ion for this Latine VerÅ¿e.
div.q: Petre, quid eÅ¿t PeÅ¿cha? Cum vino nobilis EÅ¿ca.

div.head: ART. III. Of Plums and Apricocks.
div.p: THere are Å¿ome who prefer the Plum before all other Fruits with Stones, and Å¿ay that there is nothing more delicious to eat than a Black DamÅ¿on, a Great Date, or a Perdrigon. The Apricock does not come near them, it has I know not what of unÅ¿avory when it is ripe, and of Å¿harpiÅ¿h when it is not Å¿o; mean while, both have very near the Å¿ame qualities; they are both hot in the mean, and moiÅ¿t in the Å¿econd Degree.

The Å¿weet Plum rejoyces a hot Stomach, lenifies the BreaÅ¿t, LooÅ¿en's the Belly, and nouriÅ¿hes much more than the Peach, provided however that it be eaten before Meals, otherwiÅ¿e it corrupts, and by moiÅ¿tning too much the Å¿uperiour Orifice of the Stomach after Meals, it makes the Food deÅ¿cend too Å¿oon, and Å¿o cauÅ¿es Crudities, which it is difficult afterward to deal with.

I Å¿hall not repeat here the different Maxims which I have laid down in the precedent DiÅ¿courÅ¿es concerning the UÅ¿e of Fruits, which ought to be eaten faÅ¿ting, and before Meals. I Å¿hall only Å¿ay that its good to caÅ¿t Plums into freÅ¿h Water before they are eaten, to the end they may cool and moiÅ¿ten more; but provided that they are very ripe, and that all have their Stems, leÅ¿t the Water enter there, and render them InÅ¿ipid. Its doubtleÅ¿s in order to be more cooled, and more moiÅ¿tn'd, and to keep the Belly more Å¿oluble that Å¿ome Men eat often Prunes with their Meat, and that there are ev'n Å¿ome who diÅ¿like their Pottage if it has not of them.

If dry'd Plums may be given to Å¿ick PerÅ¿ons, I do not doubt alÅ¿o but I may be permitted to give of them to mine, after having gather'd them very ripe in a clear day; the Choler which is often the cauÅ¿e of all Fevers, looÅ¿es its edg by the cumbrance which it receives from the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of Plums: and becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e Fruits oppoÅ¿e the heat and drought of theÅ¿e DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es, they are eÅ¿teem'd excellent for encountring Bilous Fevers, provided that the uÅ¿e be regular, and that we take a Å¿eaÅ¿onable time to give them.

div.head: ART. IV. Of Mulberries.
div.p: OF all the Fruits that are eaten there are none but Mulberries which are fit for Men when unripe: theÅ¿e ought only to be Red, drawing toward the Black, to be eaten. If they are throughly ripe, they corrupt Å¿o haÅ¿tily in the Stomach, that Å¿hortly after they cauÅ¿e in thoÅ¿e who eat freely of them, DiÅ¿tempers of the Stomach, LooÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿es, Carbuncles, Malignant Swellings, and often pernicious and Epidemick DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es, eÅ¿pecially if Rains have been rife during the Summer.

There is nothing which changes it Å¿elf Å¿ooner into Choler, and which becomes Å¿ooner poyÅ¿on within our Body than a Black Mulberry. ThoÅ¿e who have the Stomach foul ought to take good heed of eating them, unleÅ¿s they have a mind to be Å¿ick in a Å¿hort time. The Red-blacks withÅ¿tand Corruption more, and tho' they are very moiÅ¿t, they have nevertheleÅ¿s I know not
what of drought through their Å¿harpneÅ¿s and aÅ¿triction, which hinders them from corrupting Å¿o Å¿oon.

To uÅ¿e them well, we ought nevertheleÅ¿s to mind the praecautions belonging to them, and never to eat of them but when the Stomach is empty, clean, and hot; for if a heat be not felt in the Bowels, how young and Cholerick Å¿oever a PerÅ¿on be, I do not adviÅ¿e him to eat of them, unleÅ¿s he has a mind to fall into Å¿ome one of the DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es which we have Å¿poken of before.

Mulberries carry their Liquor with them, and nothing ought to be Drank after they are eaten; they excite the appetite, cool the Stomach, appeaÅ¿e drought, allay the heat of the Liver, Purge the Blood of its Å¿uperfluous Å¿eroÅ¿ities, carrying them off by Urine. They blunt the edg of the Choler, moiÅ¿ten thoÅ¿e that are troubled with Melancholy and Choler: finally they make the Belly Å¿oluble in thoÅ¿e who are naturally CoÅ¿tive. I will Å¿ay much more, if Mulberries gather'd from the Tree and eaten in a good plenty can cauÅ¿e the Bloody-flux; as we Å¿ee it every year, nature which moÅ¿t commonly has plac't the remedy in the cauÅ¿e of our evils, has not forgotten to teach us by experience, that theÅ¿e Fruits Å¿erve for an aÅ¿Å¿ured remedy againÅ¿t the inveterate
Bloody-flux, if they are given dry to the weight of a Crown in Gold in Red-Wine.

Since the chief Vertue of Mulberryes is to cool and to keep the MaÅ¿s of Blood from fermenting, by qualifying the parts which Å¿erve for Å¿anguification, there may be cauÅ¿e to believe that they may be a Remedy appropriated to the Gout as well as all other Fruits. For the pain which Gouty PerÅ¿ons feel in the ligaments of their Joints, is caus'd but by a Blood and a Å¿eroÅ¿ity too Å¿harp, which Å¿harpneÅ¿s is blunted by the great humidity of Mulberries, they inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly evacuating it by Urine. We need not Å¿eek for other proofs than daily experience, and that which HegeÅ¿ander has left us in Writing. He relates that the Mulberry-trees did not bear Fruit for Twenty years together, and that during all that time Men, Women, and Children, were Å¿o troubled with the Gour, that other cauÅ¿es could not be then diÅ¿cover'd, than the Å¿carcity of theÅ¿e Fruit.

div.head: ART. V. Of Å¿harp Cherries.
div.p: SHarp Fruits in general are enemies to Old and Melancholick PerÅ¿ons, when they do not find within themÅ¿elves an exceÅ¿Å¿ive heat; they are not edulcorated in their Stomach (if I may Å¿o call it) and are diÅ¿tributed into their Veins without being Concocted and blunted. Which is not done without cauÅ¿ing in the Mouth little Å¿harp belchings, and in the Stomach troubleÅ¿ome prickings, and in the whole Body an inÅ¿upportable heavyneÅ¿s.

It does not happen Å¿o to young People that are Sanguine and Cholerick who have the Entrals heated: but if caÅ¿ually the Å¿harpneÅ¿s of Cherries with Å¿hort Stems eaten faÅ¿ting, cauÅ¿es Å¿ometimes in theÅ¿e prickings in the Stomach, they need then but to mix Powder Sugar with them, to blunt the point of it.

The moÅ¿t refined Sugar and the whiteÅ¿t, which we call Royal, is the leaÅ¿t proper for
the uÅ¿e of Man; it heats and drys us too much, and through the abundance of its Sulphur and Salt, it is entirely oppoÅ¿ite to the principles of our Life: The finer Sugar is the leÅ¿s Å¿weet it is, and the leÅ¿s alÅ¿o it quenches thirÅ¿t. Lime which is a capital Enemy of Man, if it be taken inwardly, or outwardly apply'd, is the chief matter which Refiners make uÅ¿e of, for rendring Sugar whiter and more Å¿olid; and tho' Powder Sugar be made by many repeated Lixivium's, nevertheleÅ¿s it ought always to be preferr'd before Loaf Sugar, and if we will chooÅ¿e the beÅ¿t of all, we muÅ¿t always take that which is the whiteÅ¿t among the browns. It is that which is extremely Å¿weet, which quenches thirÅ¿t, which moiÅ¿tens, and which lenifies the BreaÅ¿t: I thought it proper to make this digreÅ¿Å¿ion for PerÅ¿ons who loveÅ¿weet things, becauÅ¿e Sugar is often Å¿et at our Tables, for rendring our Fruits more agreeable to the taÅ¿te.

Sharp Cherryes exhilerate the Stomach, they excite there the Appetite, and appeaÅ¿e the drought. They diÅ¿Å¿ipate the thick humours, and by their Å¿harp quality, they cut them (as I may Å¿ay) and divide them, either that they may Å¿erve afterward for Food, or be evacuated with more eaÅ¿e.

By all theÅ¿e Vertues they are very proper as well as Mulberries, to oppoÅ¿e the
cauÅ¿e and the progreÅ¿s of the Gout, and experience Å¿hews us that Gouty PerÅ¿ons receive a Å¿enÅ¿ible relief by the uÅ¿e of Fruits, which qualify the Liver, and which correct the Acrimony of the Blood.

Moreover they powerfully looÅ¿en the Belly, if they are freely eaten faÅ¿ting while the Dew is yet on the Fruit; and experience teaches us every year that they carry off by a LooÅ¿neÅ¿s long DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which all the other Remedies of PhyÅ¿ick have not been able to Cure.

The moÅ¿t proper time to eat them is in the Morning faÅ¿ting, either with or without Bread. They have moiÅ¿ture enough to oblige us not to drink any Liquor after them. As for the lateward Cherries which we call at Rochelle des Guignes with long Stems, tho' they may be eaten before Meals; nevertheleÅ¿s I allow them to be eaten after Meals: they have an agreeable AÅ¿triction, which contributes to Concoction, and which cloÅ¿es the Å¿uperiour Orifice of the Stomach, that it performs its Office afterward much better.

The Å¿weet Cherries, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e which we call in this Town Guindoux and Guigneaux, are much better than the Å¿harp for old PerÅ¿ons and for theÅ¿e who have a nice Stomach; they do not prick Å¿o much the inward parts, and they nouriÅ¿h more.

Haply there is not any Remedy more agreeable and more excellent for qualifying the Reins, and for clearing thence the Gravel, Slime, and little Stones, than the Wine of Å¿harp Cherries: We muÅ¿t take off them therefore in the Months of June or July, twelve or fifteen Pounds, we muÅ¿t cleanÅ¿e them of their Stems and Stones, and caÅ¿t them and their Stones broken through the Bung-hole of a Barrel, (a VeÅ¿Å¿el containing Å¿omewhat more than our Barrel) of good White-wine. After that they have been there for a Month, and have Communicated to the Wine their cooling and opening quality, you may pierce the VeÅ¿Å¿el and drink the Wine with pleaÅ¿ure. The colour will be agreeable to the Eye, the taÅ¿te delicious, and the effects admirable.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Fruits which ought to be eaten after Meals.
div.p: THo' the Fruits which ought to be eaten after Meals are of a matter more firm, which nouriÅ¿hes more, and which does not corrupt Å¿o eaÅ¿ily as that of the others, nevertheleÅ¿s we muÅ¿t remember to uÅ¿e them with the Å¿ame precautions which we gave in the Preface to this Tract: theÅ¿e precautions ought to be Å¿tood too as ReligiouÅ¿ly in uÅ¿ing theÅ¿e Fruits, as in eating the others. The faults which are committed in their uÅ¿e are very conÅ¿iderable, and that PerÅ¿on whom I Cur'd not long Å¿ince of Vertigo's which threatn'd her with Å¿ome Å¿evere DiÅ¿temper, has been thankful to me Å¿ince, for having forbidden her the uÅ¿e of Apples, which Å¿he are irregularly after Meals.

div.head: ART. I. Of Pears.
div.p:
NEver has the InduÅ¿try of our Gardiners appear'd more admirable than in the divers kinds of Pears which we have in France. They have taken a particular care to Sow Seeds, and to preÅ¿erve Å¿uch Trees, as in their Wood and Leaves gave them marks of a good hope: For as by Sowing a great many Flower Seeds, there come of all kinds, and ev'n Å¿ome that are beautiful and double, Å¿o by Sowing a great Å¿tore of Pear Kernels, it Å¿eems that Nature pleaÅ¿es her Å¿elf in giving us a grand variety of Pear-trees, which produce all new Fruits, and Å¿ome of them delicious to the taÅ¿te: haply it is becauÅ¿e the Pear is the moÅ¿t excellent Fruit of all, that Å¿he delights in multiplying its kinds ev'n to an infinite number: It is thus that the MeÅ¿Å¿ire Jean, the Dame Houdote, or the Amadote, the Gabriel Egand, the Micet, the MartinÅ¿ire, and a great many other excellent Pears
are come of Kernels, and that they have had the honour to bear the Names of thoÅ¿e who rais'd them.

But not to Å¿top at this DiÅ¿courÅ¿e, which Å¿eems to contribute nothing to my deÅ¿ign, I may Å¿ay that the artifice of our Gardiners has multiplyed for us Pears of Summer, of Autumn and of Winter; that it has given us more of CaÅ¿Å¿antes and of Burez, that it has Å¿hewn us more of Sweet, of Å¿harp and of Acerb, and that finally it has procur'd for us more of Vinous, of Ambred and of Musked, than we had before.

Among all theÅ¿e Pears the Å¿weet and melting are eÅ¿teem'd the beÅ¿t, they nouriÅ¿h more than the others which are a little Å¿harp or Acerb, and they are much more friendly to the nature of Man. NevertheleÅ¿s there are Å¿ome who prefer before theÅ¿e firÅ¿t Pears the Sweet and CaÅ¿Å¿ant â¢ s, becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e for the moÅ¿t part are odoriferous, and the others are not. They priÅ¿e therefore much more the Bonchretien-Pioulier, or the great Winter Musk Pear, than the Vergoulette, or the Bergamot of Autumn.

Be it how it will, the Pear in general cools and moiÅ¿tens the heated Entrals, and by its gentle AÅ¿triction contributes much to the Concoction of the Stomach, by gently cloÅ¿ing its Å¿uperiour Orifice, and by
LooÅ¿ning a little the Belly; its the reaÅ¿on for which it ought always to be eaten after Meals, for if it be eaten the Stomach being empty, it cumbers us, and loads us much, and moreover it binds the Belly; but however we eat of it after Meals, it always has very good effects, provided that we have the Stomach diÅ¿pos'd to receive it: for be it that we eat it Crud, or Baked, or RoÅ¿ted, or Boyl'd, with Powder Sugar and Cinnamon, as old People ought to eat it, after all theÅ¿e manners it always Å¿olaces the Stomach drain'd of its Å¿trength and weaken'd by the exceÅ¿s of heat.

That which is to be ObÅ¿erv'd in the uÅ¿e of Pears, is, that after Meals we ought to eat fewer Beurees than Caffantes, the former being more digeÅ¿ted, and more ready to corrupt through the leaÅ¿t fault that we commit in our way of living. Moreover we ought always to make choice of the moÅ¿t coloured, and reject thoÅ¿e which we find Worm eaten. Finally we ought after Pears to drink a good Cup of pure Wine, letting this Latin Maxim have its force, PoÅ¿t Crudum, merum. But above all we ought to remember not to drink much Wine, nor to drink Å¿uch as is Å¿mall; Å¿mall Wine through its defect of heat not cauÅ¿ing the Pear to be Concocted, and the other cauÅ¿ing crudities by its redundancy,
make both of them diÅ¿orders in a Stomach the moÅ¿t ev'n tempered and the moÅ¿t Å¿trong. It is what experience Å¿hew'd us not long Å¿ince in a PerÅ¿on, who fell into inÅ¿upportable pains, having drank much Wine; and Rodolphus Goclenius aÅ¿Å¿ures us, that another dyed having drank much Beer, both, after having eaten Pears to an exceÅ¿s.

BecauÅ¿e our Stomach is much hotter in Winter than in Summer, our heat not diÅ¿Å¿ipating it Å¿elf during that firÅ¿t Å¿eaÅ¿on through the pores of our Body, there are PerÅ¿ons who rather eat Pears in Winter than in Summer, and who do not find themÅ¿elves Å¿o much incommoded by them. Haply theÅ¿e Pears have Å¿weated in the heap, and have there Å¿eaÅ¿on'd themÅ¿elves; whereas the Pears of the Summer, having their Sap Å¿till in motion, and having not loÅ¿t their Å¿uperfluous humidity, trouble rather the Coction of the Stomach than the Pears of Winter.

div.head: ART. II. Of Apples.
div.p: SInce Apple-trees have been cultivated in the Pais des BaÅ¿ques, and in the Province of Normandy, Men have had a greater eÅ¿teem for their Fruits. Trees have been Sown, and afterward Grafted; they have been after that planted and re-planted: Finally they have been Å¿o often chang'd in their Soil, Countrys, and Climats, that the Fruit are become Å¿weet and pleaÅ¿ant.

I own that Apples were a long time deÅ¿pis'd, and that in Arabia they have ev'n been accus'd of Contributing to the Prizick, and to the drying of the whole Body. It has been Å¿aid alÅ¿o that they caus'd weakneÅ¿s in the Joints, and that conÅ¿equently they increaÅ¿t the Gout and other Fluxions, that they engendred Worms in the Bowels, and that finally they caus'd Vertigo's, as experience Å¿hews it us, and as it happen'd formerly to Scipio Gentilis a famous
Civilian, who after Meals abus'd theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Fruits.

But if Men have talkt after this manner, either it has been becauÅ¿e they knew not Apples well, and that they have been taken for other Fruit, or they judg'd of them, as Men do of all other things, by the ill Å¿ucceÅ¿s of thoÅ¿e who have abus'd them: for if we will examine the thing very narrowly, we Å¿hall find that the Arabians had none but Apples that were wild, acerb and very unpleaÅ¿ant to the taÅ¿te; that the weakneÅ¿s of the Joints, the Worms of the Bowels, and the Vertigo's are caus'd but by the exceÅ¿Å¿es which are committed with them, or by the ill praecautions that are taken in their uÅ¿e.

On the contrary, Apples which are Å¿weet and LuÅ¿cious, Odoriferous and firm, exhilerate the Heart, and allay the exceÅ¿s of its beat; they correct the Gall of the Liver, they dilute the Blood, which is too thick and groÅ¿s: in a word they cool and moiÅ¿ten the heated ViÅ¿cera: Moreover, whatÅ¿oever is Å¿aid, they oppoÅ¿e the drying of the Body and the PtiÅ¿ick, and we Å¿ee but very few of theÅ¿e Å¿orts of evils where Cyder is common: For this drink is friendly to the Stomach, which it heats in a moderate way; it revives the Heart, and opens the ObÅ¿tructions of the Entrals:
In a word it is of wonderfull uÅ¿e to Melancholick and atrabilarious PerÅ¿ons; that which iÅ¿Å¿ues the firÅ¿t from Apples Å¿quees'd in a PreÅ¿s is not Å¿o excellent as the Å¿econd: and the third reÅ¿embles the Demy-wine of our PeaÅ¿ants.
If we mix among Apples a little Powder Sugar, they make us Å¿pit, and cool our BreaÅ¿t.

But they muÅ¿t be us'd with precaution, that is to Å¿ay, that they muÅ¿t be eaten after Meals, becauÅ¿e they are heavy and difficult to digeÅ¿t, that they ought to be forbidden Old People, unleÅ¿s they find themÅ¿elves heated, or that they are prepar'd as Pears with Powder Sugar, Cinnamon and Water, and that finally we ought to drink a little of good Pure Wine after having eaten them.

In the DiÅ¿tempers which are accompanyed with a conÅ¿iderable heat and drought, they give a great relief, if we eat a little of them Crud, or Boyl'd, or that we put of them in Water: and I wonder that in France we give our Å¿elves Å¿o much trouble in Å¿eeking Oranges and Citrons for our: DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es, when we have a Å¿hort-Å¿tart Apple or a SpaniÅ¿h Rennet: Haply things which coÅ¿t much, and are often difficult to be had, are much better than the common, and that they much more Å¿atisfy the mind of
the DiÅ¿eaÅ¿ed; for it is this part which we ought often to Cure in thoÅ¿e who find themÅ¿elves ill.

Finally, Apples do not profit us only by taking them at the Mouth, they are a Å¿overeign Remedy for Heart-burnings and for the heats of the Stomach if they are outwardly applied: for if a CataplaÅ¿m be made of Boyl'd Apples, and apply'd hot on the Region of the Heart, or on the pit of the Stomach, haply we may not find an Epithem more Sovereign in thoÅ¿e CaÅ¿es. AlÅ¿o experience has Å¿hewn us that the pulp of a boyl'd Apple put hot on Blood-Å¿hed and inflam'd Eyes, is almoÅ¿t the only Remedy for this evil.

div.head: ART III. Of Grafted Quinces.
div.p: ITs a pleaÅ¿ant Medicine to Purge ones Å¿elf by eating after Meals Portugal Quinces: The Fruit which I Å¿o call, are the Quinces whoÅ¿e Grafts were brought from that Kingdom, and which are almoÅ¿t as pleaÅ¿ant to eat and to behold as a Bon-Cretien Pear, at leaÅ¿t they have an odour more Å¿weet and LuÅ¿cious; they are yellow as Gold, and yield in nothing to thoÅ¿e Pears in greatneÅ¿s, Figure and Beauty.

Quinces are cold and dry, they reÅ¿tringe alÅ¿o manifeÅ¿tly the parts of the Body where they are apply'd; and 'tis by this aÅ¿tringent quality, that conÅ¿tringing the Stomach in the upper part, and afterward the InteÅ¿tines, after that they are eaten, they Å¿queeÅ¿e, and force out all they meet within their cavity, be it Excrement, Choler or Phlegm. Its what happend to an Advocate of Pergamus, of whom Galen Å¿peaks, who was pleaÅ¿antly Purg'd after having
eaten Quinces after a Meal, and having walkt a little upon it: Å¿o that after all the experiments that we have had of them, we ought no longer to doubt of their Vertues.

Mean while the Å¿tirring of the Belly which they cauÅ¿e, does not happen but to PerÅ¿ons who have the Stomach weak and nice, and who have need by reaÅ¿on of this to fortifie it; for theÅ¿e Fruits do not work the Å¿ame effects in a young robuÅ¿t Man; and on the other Å¿ide, if they are eaten before Meals, being very far from moving the Belly, they make it tardy; and it is Å¿o that thoÅ¿e do who have it ordinarily too moiÅ¿t.

Quinces have alÅ¿o other excellent Vertues; if they are eaten Crud, Boyl'd, or preÅ¿erv'd with Sugar, they give an appetite, they Å¿top a LooÅ¿neÅ¿s, appeaÅ¿e Vomiting, withÅ¿tand an old DyÅ¿entery and a Bloody-Flux; and if weÅ¿crape off them Crud, and put the pulp of them hot on the Region of the Heart in the form of an Epitheme, when a Malignant Fever attacks us, they contribute not a little toward the Å¿ubduing itâª Their penetrating and Å¿weet odour revives the Heart and the Brain, and it has not been heard Å¿aid hitherto, that Quinces corrupt in the Stomach.

I very much approve the method which
Å¿ome have of making Wine and Water of Quinces. TheÅ¿e two Drinks have near the Å¿ame Vertues, unleÅ¿s it be that the Water is moÅ¿t proper for thoÅ¿e who find themÅ¿elves much heated, and the Wine more meet for thoÅ¿e who do not find any praedominant quality, and who are old or Phlegmatick.

The Water of Quinces which the Greeks call ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , is made after this manner. We take in the Month of October fifty or: Å¿ixty pints of Fountain-Water, of Paris MeaÅ¿ure [which comes near to our Quart] we put into it ten or twelve Pounds of Portugal Quinces, pared, cleans'd, and cut in Å¿lices; they Å¿teep there till the Water has a yellow colour like that of SpaniÅ¿h Wine; after which we Å¿train this Water, and then let it Å¿eeth ore a gentle Fire till the fourth part be conÅ¿um'd, Å¿cumming it often, and after having put it in a VeÅ¿Å¿el well fill'd and well Å¿topt, we preÅ¿erve it for the Month of March following.

The Wine is made after this manner; we take at Vintage time Ten or Twelve Pounds of Portugal Quinces, prepar'd after the Å¿ame manner as I have Å¿aid, we throw them into fifty or Å¿ixty pints of good Claret MuÅ¿t, and after that they have wrought for thirty days, we Å¿train the Liquor, we put it into another VeÅ¿Å¿el which we Å¿top
up cloÅ¿e, and we preÅ¿erve it for uÅ¿e.

TheÅ¿e two Drinks produce good effects in PerÅ¿ons who uÅ¿e of them; they fortify the inward parts, oppoÅ¿e a LooÅ¿neÅ¿s and a DyÅ¿entery, cleanÅ¿e the Reins of their filth, hinder the Vapour of Wine from offending the Head, and Å¿ecure us from PeÅ¿tilential Vapours: Finally, they cauÅ¿e Å¿o many good effects, that I muÅ¿t paÅ¿s the bounds of an abÅ¿tract if I would name them all

div.head: ART. IV. Of Medlars and Services.
div.p:
THeÅ¿e Fruits are Å¿eldom at our Tables, and they are eaten moÅ¿t commonly but in a fancy; they are not very agreeable, and there is but little pleaÅ¿ure taken in eating them. Mean while they are not without their uÅ¿e, and contribute Å¿omething to our Health. They are both Å¿o near ally'd in qualities that a PerÅ¿on will not deceive himÅ¿elf if he takes the one for the other. They are cold and dry when they are hard, but when they are Å¿oftiÅ¿h they acquire a better heat, by a Å¿ort of Corruption, that is to Å¿ay, that they are not Å¿o cold; after
the firÅ¿t way they reÅ¿tringe more and nouriÅ¿h leÅ¿s: and they ought to be uÅ¿ed as Quinces, and to be eaten after Meals Å¿oft, Crud, RoÅ¿ted, Boyl'd in Wine with Powder Sugar and Cinnamon, or finally Fryed in freÅ¿h Butter, which does not render them diÅ¿agreeable to the taÅ¿te through the Skill of the Cook.

But becauÅ¿e after all theÅ¿e manners they produce the like effects as Quinces, this will oblige me to paÅ¿s in Å¿ilence what I have Å¿aid in the precedent Article: I Å¿hall only add here, that the Stones of Medlars being powdred, and then taken by the Mouth to the weight of a Gold Crown in White-wine, cleanÅ¿e the Reins of their Impurities, and ev'n drive forth Stones which are Å¿mall enough to paÅ¿s through the Æ²reters, and afterward through the PaÅ¿Å¿age of the Urine.

In reality theÅ¿e Stones are extreamly dry, and they have in their matter particles which powerfully penetrate; for experience has taught me that the Stones of Fruits, and the hardeÅ¿t bones of BeaÅ¿ts and FiÅ¿hes provoke Urine as Å¿pecifick Remedies. I do not doubt but that which BraÅ¿Å¿avolus has left us in Writing concerning the Vertues of the Stones of Medlars, is true, Å¿ince he proves it by two Å¿ick PerÅ¿ons who were Cur'd thereby.

But we ought not to Å¿uffer our Å¿elves to
be abus'd on this account by the promiÅ¿es of Quacks and Mountebanks, who boaÅ¿t to have certain Remedies for breaking the Stone in the Reins or in the Bladder: I know not whether the Stones of Medlars have more Vertue in Italy than in France, but at leaÅ¿t I know by experience and reaÅ¿on, that neither the Stones of Medlars, nor all other Remedies have the force to break the Stone, nor to drive it forth of the Bladder, when it is to big too paÅ¿s forth.

The chief Vertue of Services is to cool and to reÅ¿tringe, as we have Å¿aid: its through theÅ¿e qualities that they Å¿erve for powerful Remedies againÅ¿t moiÅ¿t DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es, againÅ¿t inveterate LooÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿es, and againÅ¿t long DyÅ¿enteries. Perhaps the Learned Bruyerius had not been Cur'd of a Malignant DyÅ¿entery which laÅ¿ted him above a Month, if he had not eaten a great many Services; Å¿o true it is that the preÅ¿umptuous boldneÅ¿s which we have in trying Remedies in our long DiÅ¿tempers, often Å¿ucceeds much better with us than prudence it Å¿elf.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of Fruits, which may be eaten before, or after Meals.
div.p: THere are Fruits which may be eaten at all times, becauÅ¿e they do not corrupt in our Stomach, but through our fault: Wherefore we ought to have a peculiar deÅ¿ign, and different praecautions in uÅ¿ing them. One PerÅ¿on would only cool and moiÅ¿ton himÅ¿elf. And beÅ¿ides this, another will have a farther deÅ¿ign of rendring the Belly Å¿oluble: thus there may be need of theÅ¿e Fruits in different occaÅ¿ions.

div.head: ART. I. Of RaiÅ¿ins.
div.p: THe moÅ¿t excellent RaiÅ¿ins which our Province furniÅ¿hes us with, and which are ordinarily Å¿erv'd at our Table, are thoÅ¿e which are Å¿weet, taÅ¿ting of Sugar and Amber: many prefer them to all other Fruits; and they yield us a Liquor, which is the moÅ¿t agreeable and richeÅ¿t preÅ¿ent that ever God gave to Man. If I would extend my Å¿elf here on the Encomium of RaiÅ¿ins, I perÅ¿wade my Å¿elf that I Å¿hould find but too much matter to Å¿ay fine things of them; but, becauÅ¿e I propos'd to my Å¿elf to Write only concerning the uÅ¿e of the Fruits of Trees as briefly as poÅ¿Å¿ible; I muÅ¿t be allow'd to deliver my thoughts in a few words concerning the uÅ¿e of RaiÅ¿ins eaten before or after Meals.
But before I explain my Å¿elf thereon, I fancy that I ought to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h Å¿ome general Maxims, for well uÅ¿ing them, without being damnified thereby.

A Woman who has the Stomach nice and weak muÅ¿t never eat RaiÅ¿ins newly gather'd; they puff up the Belly, they cauÅ¿e a rumbling and winds, and trouble the Concoction of the Stomach: moreover Å¿he muÅ¿t not eat but of Å¿uch as are excellent and very ripe, and again Å¿he muÅ¿t not Å¿o much as look on thoÅ¿e which have grown in the Å¿hade, and which the Sun has not heated with its rays.

To correct the ill quality of RaiÅ¿ins, they muÅ¿t be gather'd Å¿ome days before you will eat them, or elÅ¿e you may take Å¿uch as have been hung up in a Chamber, or if at time of Vintage you have an inclination for eating Å¿uch as are freÅ¿h, they muÅ¿t be dipt into boyling Water, and then into freÅ¿h Water, and Å¿o they muÅ¿t be Å¿erv'd to Table.

RaiÅ¿ins are moiÅ¿t and moderately hot, and by theÅ¿e two qualities they are proportionate to the Principles of our Life; they nouriÅ¿h much more than other Fruits, if we except Figgs: they revive the Spirits by their Å¿weet and odoriferous Å¿avour, they cheer up a Stomach which is languiÅ¿hing and heated through Labour, and moiÅ¿ten the ViÅ¿cera, and Å¿o correct by their pleaÅ¿ant moiÅ¿ture the drought and which the heat of Autumn has there caus'd.

Nay there are PhyÅ¿itians who do not deny them to their Å¿ick Patients when they begin
to amend, tho' on condition that they eat them with Bread, and throw away the Stones and the Skin, as two parts which cannot be digeÅ¿ted by a Stomach how robuÅ¿t Å¿oever.

It they are eaten faÅ¿ting, without Bread, as they come from the Tree moiÅ¿tned with the Dew of the Night, they purge the Belly ev'n of thoÅ¿e who have it naturally tardy; there is neither Water of CaÅ¿Å¿ia nor Manna which ought to be preferr'd to RaiÅ¿ins Å¿o eaten.

We ought here to remember not to drink Wine unleÅ¿s it be well diluted, after having eaten RaiÅ¿ins faÅ¿ting: Nay it would be better not to drink at all, or to drink only pure Water; pure Wine mixt in the Stomach with the new Juice of the RaiÅ¿ins makes Å¿o extraordinary a fermentation, that the accidents which ariÅ¿e from it are much greater than you may imagin: For the Wine carrys the Chyle and the Juices into the Bowels and into the Reins, before they are digeÅ¿ted, and Å¿o cauÅ¿es impurities and indigeÅ¿tions in the Blood; whereas Water hindring the great ebullition of the Stomach, contributes to a good Concoction; it cauÅ¿es the Chyle to become more pure, and that we are more refreÅ¿ht and moiÅ¿tn'd by the uÅ¿e of the RaiÅ¿ins.

We ought not Å¿o to do when we eat them after Meals, for we may drink a good GlaÅ¿s
of pure Wine, and not conÅ¿ider Å¿o much the RaiÅ¿ins prepar'd as we have Å¿aid before, as the food which we have taken at our Meal.

Tho the Stones cannot be digeÅ¿ted, yet we ought not to throw them away when we eat RaiÅ¿ins after Meals: For Å¿ince they are aÅ¿tringent, they correct the great humidity, which is the cauÅ¿e of the evils which they bring upon us. We muÅ¿t chew them therefore very Å¿mall, and reduce them to minute parts betwixt the Teeth, that they may contribute to the Coction of our Stomach, and correct the ill qualities of the RaiÅ¿ins: It is thus we ought to eat after Meals the dry RaiÅ¿ins which are brought from Spain; for by nouriÅ¿hing and lenifying our inward parts they Å¿olace them by their Å¿weetneÅ¿s, and fortifie them by the aÅ¿triction of their Stones.

I Å¿hall not paÅ¿s by here the excellent drink. which is made with dry RaiÅ¿ins, and is call'd de Cabat. The Stones muÅ¿t be taken away from fifteen or twenty Pounds, and then the RaiÅ¿ins muÅ¿t be bruis'd a little: and in the Month of January or of February, which is the time that they are brought to us from Spain, they muÅ¿t be put in an excellent Barique (a VeÅ¿Å¿el Å¿omewhat more than our Barrel) of White-wine to drink at EaÅ¿ter. This Wine will have the colour of a SpaniÅ¿h Wine, it will be pleaÅ¿ing to the Palat, and will have qualities not to be contemn'd; for it lenifies
the BreaÅ¿t, appeaÅ¿es the Cough, helps reÅ¿piration, and fortifies the Stomach and the Liver, creates an Appetite, oppoÅ¿es inclinations to Vomit, Å¿tops a LooÅ¿neÅ¿s; in a word, it is an excellent Remedy againÅ¿t the DropÅ¿y, it agrees admirably with Old men, with Valetudinarians, with Phlegmatick or Melancholick PerÅ¿ons, and finally with Women of a tender ConÅ¿titution.

div.head: ART. II. Of China and Portugal Oranges.
div.p: THe Grafted Orange-trees which were brought from China into Portugal, and which have been multiplied in the later Kingdom, produce Oranges which have a fine Rind, a vinous Juice, and which are very pleaÅ¿ant to eat; they may be us'd before or after Meals, for being more moiÅ¿t than cold, they qualify alÅ¿o after Meals a Stomach too hot and too dry, and Å¿o help Concoction.

ThoÅ¿e which are brought us ordinarily from Portugal are Å¿harp or aigres-douces, they are colder than the former, and they refreÅ¿h
more, and more oppoÅ¿e the Corruption of our humours.

Sharp Oranges ought never to be us'd after Meals, they hinder the digeÅ¿tion of the Stomach by their coldneÅ¿s, but they are very proper for quenching the heat of our Liver, and to give us an appetite, if we take the Juice before Meals with Water and a little Powder Sugar, but eÅ¿pecially when the great heats of the Summer or of Autumn exhauÅ¿t our Å¿trength.

I Å¿ay no more here, for that I will not repeat what I have Å¿aid in the Article of Cherries, where you may Å¿ee what Å¿harp Fruits are capable of doing within us, and the precautions we muÅ¿t take to uÅ¿e of them. I Å¿hall only Å¿ay that the Rinds of Å¿harp Oranges being Å¿quees'd a little into Wine, renders it more agreeable to the taÅ¿te of many PerÅ¿ons, and makes it paÅ¿s more readily by Urine.

Our Å¿ick PerÅ¿ons uÅ¿e both the one and the other, and if you will believe them on their own experience, they will tell you that there is not a better Remedy than theÅ¿e Fruits for quenching ThirÅ¿t, cooling the Stomach, qualifying the Liver, provoking Urine, taking away the Heart burning, oppoÅ¿ing inward PoyÅ¿ons; in a word, for Curing the DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es which are accompanied with an inÅ¿upportable heat and drought and indeed, if we cut a China or Portugal, vinous Orange
into four parts, and throw it into a pot of Water with the Rin'd, this drink will have all the Vertues ev'n now mention'd.

div.head: ART. III. Of SpaniÅ¿h Pomegranates.
div.p: WE cultivate in our Gardens Å¿weet, Aigres-doux, and Å¿harp Pomegranate-trees which came to us from Spain; for as for thoÅ¿e of France which are wild, we cannot eat the Fruits: The Flowers and Rinds of Pomegranates are aÅ¿tringent, and both Å¿erve to Cure our DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es which are caus'd through a too great humidity. They have the Vertue of conÅ¿tringing the parts of our Body together, and of giving them the Situation which they had loÅ¿t: The inÅ¿ide of the Kernels of a Pomegranate is uÅ¿eleÅ¿s and undigeÅ¿ted, our Stomach cannot diÅ¿Å¿olve it, and there is no Body who eats it. There is but the pulp which is about the Kernels that yields an agreeable Juice, wherewith we are often Å¿olac'd in our Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿es.

Sharp Pomegranates ought to be us'd before
Meals, when the Stomach is empty; and if the point of their Å¿harpneÅ¿s does us hurt, as it happens in thoÅ¿e who have this part weak and tender, we need but blunt it with Water and Sugar to make a delicious Drink: Then this agreeable Liquor cools the Stomach, quenches thirÅ¿t, qualifies the Liver, weakens the Å¿harpneÅ¿s of the Choler, revives the Heart, reÅ¿iÅ¿ts putrefaction, provokes Urine; in a word, its a Drink proper for the Sick and Å¿ound. It is much better than the BoÃ¼illons of Veal, and of cooling Herbs, which are taken too often in the Summer, and in Autumn to qualify the Entrals, and to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the heat and drought of the SeaÅ¿on: for the continual uÅ¿e which is made of BoÃ¼illons, is wholly an enemy to the Stomach, their Å¿ubÅ¿tance relaxes too much the membranes, and to perform well its Office it muÅ¿t have a certain temperament which is not too moiÅ¿t; whereas the Drink of Å¿harp Pomegranates, by reÅ¿tringing it gently, tempers this part, and at the Å¿ame time all the others.
Sweet and vinous Pomegranates do not cool Å¿o much as the Å¿harp, but they dulcify more, and are more proper for Old and atribilarious PerÅ¿ons.

ThoÅ¿e who find a heat in their Bowels, are very much Å¿olac'd after having Å¿wallowed Å¿ome Spoonfulls of the Juice of theÅ¿e Fruits: It is Å¿o that the Carthaginians us'd of them,
from whoÅ¿e Country Pomegranates were brought: and it were thoÅ¿e alÅ¿o who taught us by their own experience the greateÅ¿t part of the good effects which they cauÅ¿e in us, when we uÅ¿e of them. It cannot be Å¿aid what goods the Juice of Å¿weet and vinous Pomegranates, preÅ¿s'd forth, Å¿cumm'd, and fermented may produce: it Å¿trongly oppoÅ¿es all inward Fluxions, it reÅ¿iÅ¿ts all Fevers which are accompanied with a LooÅ¿neÅ¿s and an exhauÅ¿ting of our Å¿trength, and it has this proper to it, that it fortifies all our languiÅ¿hing parts. If we will make Å¿ome Bottles of it, we muÅ¿t Å¿queeze forth in a PreÅ¿s a Å¿ufficient quantity of Pomegranates, we muÅ¿t Å¿eeth the Juice over a gentle Charcoal Fire to the diminution of the third part, after having well Å¿cumm'd it, and afterward it muÅ¿t be kept for uÅ¿e.

If we put in White-wine the Kernels of Å¿weet or vinous Pomegranates, or after the Å¿ame manner as we have preÅ¿crib'd for Å¿harp Cherries, we Å¿hall have a Wine which will yield in nothing to all the Remedies which PhyÅ¿ick has invented hitherto for allaying the burning of the Reins, for cleanÅ¿ing forth all the filth, and for hindring Stones from being there form'd.

div.head: ART IV. Of Corands.
div.p: THe Red Corands and the White, which we call Gadelles, have very near the Å¿ame qualities, tho' the Gadelles are more Å¿harp, and the Red more pleaÅ¿ant to eat. Both of them cool and reÅ¿tring the parts of the Body through which they paÅ¿s; they hinder Vomiting, quench drought, blunt the Choler, remove ObÅ¿tructions, fortify the parts, and they Å¿olace both the healthy and Sick that are heated, if they are us'd before or after Meals.

Their pungent Å¿harpneÅ¿s ought to be corrected, as that of Cherries and Pomegranates, or we may make them into a Sugar PaÅ¿te or Gelly, which is very proper for thoÅ¿e who have the Stomach weakend by long SickneÅ¿Å¿es; and I have Cur'd many PerÅ¿ons of conÅ¿iderable quality, who had this part very much afflicted by continual Vomitings, and had a troubleÅ¿ome LooÅ¿neÅ¿s of the Belly, by giving only a
PaÅ¿te or Gelly of Corands, and of the moiÅ¿t conÅ¿erve of Provins RoÅ¿es.

In Imitation of the Turks, during the great heats of the Summer, we may make of the greateÅ¿t part of the Fruits before Å¿poken of, a Å¿ort of Sherbet to be drank with Ice: and I allow young Sanguine and bilous People, who have known by experience that drinking with Ice does not incommode them, I allow them, I Å¿ay, to drink of it, with prudence for allaying the exceÅ¿s of their heat: This will be a Å¿ure means to hinder them from being Å¿et upon by continual and Malignant Fevers, and to keep them in good Health during all the Summer and Autumn. As for others who are of another temperament, and of another Age, they muÅ¿t not touch of it, and they muÅ¿t remember that heat, which we muÅ¿t not deÅ¿troy, is one of the Principles of our Life.
